description:
This place is a decent mid tier sushi place.

If you wanted sushi, but didn't want to spend like $80+, and didn't just want to eat rolls, this hits the sweet spot.

FYI: they do run out of sushi sometimes, so don't expect to be able to come late and still get all the items. I think the scallop one was my favorite and I think I tried all of them. The salmon was also really good. The eel....was just too much sauce.

Even if you do AYCE style, the bill will only come out to be around $45.

The sizing of the sushi is also pretty big.
author: Victor D.

description:
This place has a 4star rating? Yelpers definitely misled me. I should have read the reviews first because all the non 4-5 star reviews are spot on accurate. 

Got the 18 piece assorted sashimi and the cuts were cube shaped (-_-). The fish were of poor quality; very watery and mushy (no texture to any pieces at all). Also they were extremely fishy (I had to soak them in wasabi for a few minutes before it can be eaten). 

Side notes: 1.) Chefs are Chinese (it's not a bad thing but should be pointed out nonetheless). 2.) the conveyor belt moves fast; I saw customers having trouble getting plates a couple times. It also made me dizzy..
author: Constance Y.

description:
Overall the food isn't that bad and the service wasn't that bad either, but it wasn't necessarily great. The sushi rotating on the boats (basically a sushi train) was really limited to only a few options, with little sides and mainly just basic rolls. It's not the most convenient to order things if you sit at the bar because they don't even have menus with actual dishes other than the sushi rotating in front of you -- I had to ask if they have sashimi and how much it was. 

Having said that, the food wasn't bad, quite good. Go here if you're just really hungry and not that worried about getting to most tastiest food.
author: Alina Y.

description:
Two stars is an average of the two experiences we had here. The first time we came we were sat and had decent service and average food.  

The pros are since it's on a conveyor belt the food is readily available when you sit especially if you do not mind how long the pieces have been sitting out (we definitely watched several of the same pieces go by the entire time we were there). 

Cons are the food is just average and the specialty ones are few and far between and are pretty pricey for one or two bites.  We also ordered an app of tempura while we were waiting for good options to come around on the boat and it was ridiculously greasy and terrible. 

The worst experience of all was the second time we visited. We arrived around 910 and the restaurant closed at 10. We walked in right after three guys and we all were told to sit and wait and we'd be seated soon. After watching the same few pieces of sushi go by we were a little worried. The three guys got sat 5 mins before us and ate the pieces that had been circling.

When we were seated a few mins later we were starving and ready to eat. Unfortunately no more sushi was placed on the bar. Not a word was said to us when we were told to wait for a table nor when we were seated that no more sushi would be made. We even ordered an app of goyza because we were starving and needed something while waiting for the sushi. The waiter still failed to mention there would be no more sushi. After waiting 10 mins we flagged someone down and questioned the empty bar and they said we have to order from the menu and that they would not be putting out anymore sushi. When we asked why this was not told to us before being sat or for the 10 minutes we sat there they had no response. 

What a waste of time. We left hungry and disappointed and will not be returning.
author: Danielle B.

description:
This is the best revolving sushi place I've been to in the world, period. Yes, that includes Japan (blasphemy... I know). It's pretty unassuming from the outside in a residential area off of market. The interior of the restaurant is great. It's nicely decorated and spaced out from the walls and the waiting area which I feel like a lot of other sushi bars lack. You are close to your neighbor but they did a good job of spacing everyone out even though it was dinner time on a Saturday. 

Firstly, these speed boats come by FAST. It's not so fast that you can't grab what you want. The speed is reassuring however so they can get you the goods ASAP. It's also nice that you can see all there is to offer before you start attacking the boats like the hungry kraken you are, as in, you don't feel forced to take that veggie roll that's inching by when you're dying of hunger. 

The real star of the show is obviously the sushi. Every single dish is gorgeous. The restaurant isn't super bright so it's not a trick of the lighting but the sushi was gleaming, well presented and looked extremely appetizing. The rolls and nigiri had thick cuts of fish on them - they are really trying to feed you. One of the best rolls I had was a maki roll with crab, avocado, and salsa on top! These came with a side of taro fries. I'm a big fan of salmon and also noticed that there was no shortage of it. At a lot of the cheaper sushi bars, you'll see a lot of undesirables going around but not here! The sushi prep is done right in the middle of the revolving bar and the chef will take requests as well. 

I loved this place for the ambiance, great service and delicious sushi! Will definitely be back.
author: Emily L.

description: I really like this place because it's small and local and personal service.  Love the boats of sushi eat what you want and you get to choose different pieces.
author: RICHARD J.

description:
Been coming here since 2006. Consistently good sushi. Definitely a couple of levels above other conveyor belt sushi in San Francisco. As a sushi place this is a four star experience.  As a boat sushi place it's five stars plus. 

As another reviewer noted, don't come here looking for omakase or exotic sashimi. That being said, there's more here than meets the eye

To wit:

The live scallop sashimi is incredible. And seasonal. You have to order it from the specials board. It's served in the shell. 

Same high marks go for the white tuna sashimi. Yes it's heavily sauced but it's a terrific fish and sauce combination. Worth the price. 

Their oysters (seasonal) are also worth snapping up as the come around. 

The spicy seafood salad doesn't roll around on the belt. You have to order it. It's a popular item and truly delicious. The octopus is truly exceptional here. 

When I sit down I check to see what's rolling around. If I don't see my favorites I order them. The spicy tako is like a little octopus and cucumber composed salad in spicy sauce. I eat three no problem. My partner lived the Mayo heavy white tuna sashimi. It comes with a cherry tomato. Tuna tataki is my hands down favorite with its gingery garlicky goodness. Get two. 

Other standouts are the special salmon roll (no cream cheese. It with scallions), the hamachi nigiri and the asparagus tempura roll. 

I always find a good balance of variety in nigiri as well as rolls. 

I like to sit at the front where the "sashimi" guy does his work as opposed to the back where the "roll" guy works. I prefer the fresh fish to rolls.

Pic of spicy tako attached.
author: Tim P.

description: Still good. My only critiquea are the Gomae is way too sweet & servers should give a full menu when you sit down, you shouldn't have to ask for one. Oysters were great, albacore better. Just work on the service.
author: Scott F.

description:
Not a big fan of this place. When I went for dinner on a Sunday night, most of the boats were empty and we saw the same couple rolls go around multiple times, until we couldn't take it anymore and made our own requests. My friends and I had looked through the pictures here before deciding to go, and we didn't see a lot of the cool special rolls when we went! With that said, the service was fine and fast, and the food was still tasty. I would probably go back a different time to see if their selections are better. 

I also would not recommend eating here if you are hungry. With plate had 2-3 pieces, and the prices were not cheap. My guy friend had 7 dishes and that easily went over $40.
author: Hanna K.

description:
Decided to try this place out on a date night. Sushi is always a great option and having it served on a conveyor belt is just so cool. The problem with SF is that we don't have enough of these places. 

For Warakubune specifically, I've ended up coming here twice in a couple of weeks because of the overall experience. The place doesn't seem very big so sometimes a small line forms but don't get discouraged! Everything moves so fast. On my first visit, we were sat right away; the second visit had 3 parties in front of us and we were sat within 10 minutes. The staff is efficient. With having 2-3 servers at all time, you're bound to find the help you need. Within the middle of the conveyor belt are 2 sushi chefs constantly making creations for special orders and for the belt. Anything you can think of and imagine is made and your job is to grab what you want and what looks good. In my mind, it's kind of a production line stretch of omakase, where you eat what the sushi chef makes lol (kind of a stretch of the imagination). 

A normal 2 person party with drinks and sushi will run you about $50-$100; at least it did for me on both occasions. You're billed by the type of plates you grab, prices go as follows: $2.25, $3.25, $4.25, $4.65 and $4.95. When you sit, they give you a paper that shows a picture of each plate so you know what you're grabbing. Grab, eat and stack. Once you're done, the servers will tally the plates and get your bill. Pretty simple process which is probably why parties move in and out fast. The sushi overall seems good and fresh. Some items will go around the conveyor belt many times before getting picked up but overall, pretty satisfied with the flavor and food. 

If you're looking for a great date night or non date night spot that's fun and interactive, come check them out! It's in a great location and offers a great experience.
author: Rockne H.

description: This place is so amazing! I love the sushi boats and they are constantly adding new rolls. If there is one that you specifically want, they'll make it for you. It's pretty affordable, though I wish the service was better. Very rarely did we see the server around, and when we did flag them down, we did not get what we asked for until much later. But since conveyor belt sushi in SF is such a rare find, I would take sub-par service when the food is so great!
author: Swaja K.

description: This is my new goto sushi boat restaurant in San Francisco. The sushi here is really high quality. They feature thick slices of fish over small rice balls. Just how i like it! The yellowtail was super fresh and delicious. So was the maguro, bonita, salmon and halibut.  We honestly had some of the best raw scallops ever. Their sushi rice is also really good. There is usually a wait for a seat at the sushi bar and none for tables. But its way more fun to sit at the sushi bar!  Our wait time was about 20 minutes. The staff is super friendly and fast. Street parking. Double highly recommend.
author: Jerry M.

description:
When I saw such a high rated conveyer belt sushi place I got so excited. I thought either it must either be super cheap, super high quality, or super innovative. Unfortunately it was none of the above. Came on a Friday night with a friend who really wanted conveyor belt sushi. I was reluctant but since this place was 4 stars I gave it a chance. In the end I just left disappointed.

I'll say this. The quality isn't bad. The rice has some flavor and fish quality was your normal restaurant quality. But it's definitely not good enough for the price. Ordering is slightly difficult and we failed multiple times just cause of our seating location. The restaurant itself is decently sized but still not huge. 

Pros:
-Decent portion sizes so you can get full faster
-Very nice and attentive service
-Instant gratification if you're starving

Cons:
-Lacking in options. The conveyer belt basically had a small selection of basic nigiri, a few rolls that were all similar to one another, and an occasional interesting item.
-Prices suck. Paid almost $60 for my half of the meal. I left full mainly cause everything was full of rice.

Overall, if you are looking for good conveyor belt sushi head to Kula. Otherwise take your money and go to one of the million decent sushi restaurants in the city. I'd only consider coming back if I could be seated right away and I was starving or if I only wanted 2-3 plates.
author: Vivian C.

description: Decor and service via boat is fun. Many better options nearby with regards to quality of fish.
author: Theo S.

description:
The moving boats were a really cool concept!

The sushi quality is also not bad. The ratio of fish to rice is pretty good. There's a lot more fish than there is rice, which might be good or bad depending on how you see sushi.

All in all, this is a pretty good place. A little pricey, but good!
author: Alton L.

description:
Overpriced, which wouldn't have been a big deal if it was actually good. And I would've loved to have hot tea like I ordered, instead I received a beverage that tasted like hot tap water. It would also be great to decide when I got wasabi, instead it was snuck into some of the plates -_-
Staff was nice enough, but that can only go so far with crap food.
author: Ashley K.

description:
You must manage your expectations should you visit. They are a conveyor belt sushi joint. So don't come here if you want omakase, sashimi, or really anything without mayo. Why did we come here? Our 4 year old wanted sushi. Her verdict... She loved it. She was so happy watching the sushi boats go by and waiting with anticipation for something she wanted. My wife and I were just happy to have a large Sapporo, grab random plates, and watch our daughter gorge herself.

The sushi wasn't bad, but they are roll/mayo heavy. Plates are priced between $2.25 and $4.95. You pick up what you want and they add up your plates when your done. They do have sashimi options between $15-19, but go elsewhere if that's what your craving. Service was good because the employees stand nearby and watch everything. It's not worth going out of the way, but is an excellent option for kids and convenience. We'll definitely be back if our daughter is craving sushi.
author: Zoran L.

description: I'm a big fan of conveyor belt sushi restaurants. Love the idea of having a bit of everything, instead of maybe being stuck with a roll that might've sounded interesting but ends up being gross (yes, this happens a lot to me). This restaurant is very clean and the staff are very attentive. Overall, the sushi is good. Each piece of sushi looks like it was made neatly and nicely. Needless to say, the quality of the fish is good, considering the prices are more expensive than what I'm fond of. However, I must say that the selection isn't great. Only saw two different types of nigiris. The sushi rolls probably went around many many times before I even saw anything that I wanted. Probably wouldn't come back any time soon but it was worth checking out.
author: Annie H.

description: This place is amazing. Sushi boats that go around and you pick what you like. Love this place so much I just wish they opened longer because it does get packed and busy. That should also let you know that the food is great!
author: Juan H.

description:
Favorite sushi place in SF. 

Is it boats? Yes. Is there a sneeze guard? Yes. If these things bother you, I'm happy to take your place at the bar. The fish is so intentionally presented with both roll and nigiri options. I love to try something new when I come (if that's possible - I've been a regular visitor for over 10 years) but the standards are delicious every time, and if you don't see what you want floating around on this rotating buffet of instant gratification you can always ask. 

Hamachi nigiri, tuna tataki, spicy white tuna, and the grilled hamachi cheek (large special plate best for two if you are having sushi) are must haves for me. Mmmmm...tuna.... The special rolls are great too, and my mom calls the California Rolls fluffy little clouds.

And then the family that runs the place. They are so awesome. So nice. If you've been once before they remember you. They remember that you ate all your pickled ginger and need a bit more. And even if people are queuing up to get a seat they never rush you to finish up and get out of the way. 

Great place for couples, groups of 4 work if you get a curved section, and I eat here alone all the time.
author: Emma L.

description:
This is very fresh sushi at reasonable prices.  Don't be put off that they are on boats - the place is so popular that no roll sits on there very long. (In fact, depending on where you are seated some rolls may never go past you.) You can always request something from the staff if you aren't able to snag what you want from the boats.

As a vegetarian, there are plenty of options but ask for the asparagus tempura roll if you don't see it. Their avocado rolls are always delicious and perfectly ripe.  My fish-eating friends like the spicy white tuna sashimi, unagi is very popular and the tataki (with ginger) is also great.

Complimentary tea.  They also have sake and beer. They total up your bill based on your plates (they are priced based on the pattern, which is printed on your placemat).

It can be very popular so expect a bit of a wait during peak meal times on weekends.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Went here on a Friday night around 6:00pm & it wasn't too crowded. But after 6:30pm, a wave of people came in and the restaurant filled up fast. I recommend you going before 7pm to get seats, especially on weekends.

Conveyer belt sushi is such a rare find in SF, so we were glad we found this place! There are tables near the back of the restaurant if you don't want to sit at the bar, but why wouldn't you?? Boats filled with plates of yummy sushi come circling around and it's so hard to not grab every plate that passes by. 

If you want more options or want a specific roll, ask for a menu. They also sell appetizers and entrees (such as donburi, udon, etc). Each seat has an informational sheet that tells you how much the different plates are (so you can check before you grab all willy nilly). 

The service here is great! We were checked on multiple times, even when it got busy. 

Overall, the sushi wasn't spectacular, but mostly everyone here goes for the concept/experience. Plus the restaurant is fairly close to Castro, so after dinner drinks are a 5 min walk away! I'd definitely come back here next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Danny C.

description:
I went back to Warakabune after a 5 year hiatus (not the restaurants doing, I had a baby) And it was just as amazing as I remembered it. Used to go all the time pre-baby and it is definitely my sushi happy place. 

Some people complain about the selection on the boats and the price. I have never had an issue and please remember you can always order items not seen on the boats. The staff has always been friendly and attentive and its just a great place to have a meal with friends.  I have never felt it was too expensive. Fish quality has never disappointed me, and Im very picky about sushi. 

I highly recommend the seared white tuna ( literally one of the best things I've put in my mouth) and the House Special roll, which I drunkenly dubbed "Shrimpy Bomb Bomb" many years ago. 

I definitely recommend this place if you want a comfortable delicious experience. Ive also seen the same staff/chef for like the last 15 years.
author: Jana C.

description:
Warakubune holds a special place in my heart. I've been eating here for over a year now, and here's the what I like most:

-The staff, including the sushi chef, are pleasant and extremely attentive. Tea? No problem. Soup? No problem. Special sushi order? No problem. And they work with surprising, satisfying speed. My dining experience is grateful for this.
- Delicious sushi dishes of satisfying variety at a reasonable price
- Watching people try (and sometimes fail) to snatch their sushi from the conveyor belt, only to realize that you have to do the same thing.

It's great.
author: Michael J.

description:
Gary H. did his research on good sushi bars and came across Warakubune Sushi. Although there are tons of great Yelp reviews, this place just did not do Japanese food justice. (Could be due to the fact that they're a Chinese/Cantonese owned restaurant. Or could be because they offer the sushi boat experience. You know how that goes...)

Besides seating around the sushi boat, they have 4-5 tables in the back, where it is very dimly lit. You can order off the menu even if you sit in front of the sushi boats!

Their menu consists of: entree items, a few assorted sushi/sashimi/rolls, and nigiris. They also have a special menu hanging on the wall. 

- Spider roll ($12.75): roll wasn't constructed that well, so it insta-fell apart. The breaded soft shell crab was also very dry.
- Special roll ($15): way too saucy
- Uni ($9.50/two pieces): not too bad!
- Assorted Sashimi ($17.95/18 pieces): six different types of fish, but the cuts were a little cube-ish instead of the usual slices

Service here is totally whatever, so don't expect a 5 star restaurant dining experience. For the prices, you could definitely find better Japanese food elsewhere!
author: Christine S.

description:
Boat sushi. Nuff said.

This place is the best deal in town when it comes to cheap sushi. It's quality and chill inside. The sushi chefs will make anything you request and sometimes they get creative themselves. 

There's an oyster shooter they make here that is my favorite thing in the entire world (my gf thinks I'm crazy).

They also have a full menu with noodles and everything but I come here for the boats. Boats boats boats!
author: Taylor S.

description: Came here the other night with my two kids and it was great. The service was quite friendly and the food was good as well. The fish was very fresh and the ambiance was very comfortable. My kids really enjoyed the taro fries as well as the house special roll. Definitely worth coming back next time.
author: Jasmine F.

description: This place is now our new fav sushi spot in SF! Our other favorite closed down and we were sad about it, UNTIL we found this one! We got there early (5:11pm) and they opened at 5:30pm. The door was open when we first arrived and we asked if they were open. They said not yet so we said okay. We waited outside and it was a bit windy (and cold) and after just a min or 2, the hostess told us we could sit inside because it was cold out. Super nice (they did not have to do that!). We were able to sit at the sushi bar in front of the boats and ordered salmon sashimi which was TO DIE FOR. We also had their salmon skin handroll which my husband loved, the scallops (delish) and the "special shrimp tempura" roll which was super yummy with avocado on it. We also had some hot tea and asked for sweet n low. They brought some "sugar" in a small container. I poured some into my tea, and after tasting it, realized it was SALT, and not sugar. That was the only hiccup on that first experience. We loved this place so much that we went back the next night with some friends. The service was worse the 2nd time around but maybe it was because we were a table of 8 (plus a baby) instead of just a party of 2. The food was alot slower coming out and we had to ask multiple times for water refills. Overall, we will definitely continue coming back to this place each time we're in SF!
author: Lysa D.

description:
Food:
Good quality fish, some has the feeling of melting in your mouth. But not enough selection for sushi. Where is the Toro, where is the surf clam, where is the ono or uni? They do have chicken katsu and unagi bowls though.

Environment:
Those boats! They move too fast!! I have decent hand eye coordination but needed to really try to make sure I didn't stop the boat or spill anything when grabbing any plate. It shouldn't be moving that fast, it's not a race! The sushi chefs are in the center of the restaurant, with the belt around them. And people seated around the belt. Good for small parties but not so much for large ones as they do not have any booths next to the belt. The restaurant also didn't feel super clean.

Verdict:
I came to this restaurant hoping to find a new go-to sushi spot as I moved to SF recently, and I don't think I found it here. It gets the job done for a sushi craving and has good quality with what they have, but the limited sushi selection left me feeling unsatisfied. The prices are also higher than the typical conveyor belt style sushi restaurant, and for no valuable reason. I'm not saying you should avoid this restaurant, as I'm probably going to come back eventually. But as for my go-to sushi spot search, I'm just going to move along.
author: Kevin S.

description: I definitely expected insane prices in San Francisco, so this was no surprise. And in fact the only reason this rating is 1 Star is because of price. Quality of sushi was incredible. The boats as a conveyor system were awesome. 5/5 quality. 5/5 ambiance. 3/5 service (a bit short staffed). -5/5 price. When you can count multiple dollars just for every bite? Beyond outrageous. Some of the most insane prices I've ever seen for sushi on a conveyor. If they cut their prices 30-50%, this place would be one of my all time favorites anywhere in the US. Unfortunately, they're charging roughly double what a consumer-friendly sushi market would.
author: Elinor R.

description: No bueno. This is place is bad by landlocked small town standards, let alone foodie SF standards. I've had better sushi at the airport in North Carolina. Left after trying 2 rolls and grabbed Chinese down the street.
author: dena r.

description: The service was fine and we got in the restaurant without waiting. The sushi however was not fresh, and certainly not comparable to the conveyor belt sushi place in little tokyo of LA. It was certainly ovepriced for the quality of the food as the pricing was slightly confusing with the different plates. Would not come back again.
author: Qingbo Z.

description:
Amazing sushi restaurant, hands down. I've been to Kulas and this other . The sushi is extremely fresh, udon is superb, and their service was amazing! We had 10 plates of sushi, and a 12 piece sashimi, and the experience was dead on amazing. 

Their wasabi was excellent and was a great add-on to the sushi. Tea was served every time my cup was near empty, so that was a big plus! All in all for a new years dinner, these guys are the restaurant to go to.
author: Andy L.

description:
Mediocre revolving sushi restaurant in San Francisco. We mostly ordered our nigiri plates from our waitress instead of picking them off the conveyor belt, as most of the items on the belt were cooked rolls, like California rolls. 

Prices and quality were average, but with all the other Japanese restaurants in SF, I most likely won't come back here.
author: Jackie Y.

description:
I would give Warakubune 4 stars, but the service I received was very unsatisfactory. I may be a little too nice with 3 stars with the service... :(  AND it was not even a busy night. 


The LADY who works there is the ONLY person who is doing her job CORRECTLY. 


The service was the most disappointing part of my night. 
1. Getting seated took a while. It took the guy FOREVER to clean the table. I stared at empty chairs with plates on the table for the longest time!!
2. I had to get up myself to go get a menu.
3. No one was helping my side of the sushi boat area. The group on my left tried to get a server's attention a few times but came out unsuccessful. The workers were everywhere else except for my side of the sushi boat table.
4. While I was in the restroom, my friend asked for two separate containers for her ramen (1 for the soup and 1 for the ramen, so the ramen would not get soggy). The guy said NO and he refused until the lady said okay. WHAT THE ?????? 
5. I had to go up to the worker to give them the check. 
 
Nothing I ate there was spectacular, but it was nothing to complain about. My friend and I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen and the spicy white tuna sashimi. The tonakatsu ramen was not bad, but it tasted a bit like kimchi paste. The spicy white tuna sashimi was pretty good though!  

The bad service is all I remember. The food was decent, but the service ruined it and I will not be coming back.
author: Darlene T.

description: i came here excited for a good time at warakubune and was super disappointed.  i will say though, the ladies working here are still super sweet and made the experience enjoyable. they refill your teas with a smile and take your orders with enthusiasm. the spicy seafood salad was still good, albeit too large for the two of us that evening. the oyako don was pretty tasteless, and my friend had to pour soy sauce on it and add wasabi. the sushi boat selections were extremely poor.  restaurant was packed when we got there and when we left, so that was probably why, plus they had so many to-go orders :( i wont be coming back..
author: Christina L.

description: The sushi is fine, but their selection on the conveyor sucks. Most of what I want requires you to order from a server. Just go to a regular sushi place, sit at the bar, and order there.
author: Andrew M.

description: This is probably one of the better conveyor belt type sushi places you can eat at.  Usually people see sushi boats as gimmicky with low quality, but not here!  The fish is big and fresh and the offerings on the boats are simple, which (to me) is a good sign that it's about quality and not about big saucy offerings.  It can get crowded, but when we went on a Friday night, it was pretty quick to seat.  Just keep track of those plates, it can get expensive!
author: Andy V.

description:
Presentation and cleanliness rank high here at this revolving sushi boat. However, it's not cheap. $11.95 for one order, or 5 pieces, of salmon sashimi. The same unwanted items go round and round w/ not much variety. Miso soup was salty and most plates are $4+ for 2 pieces of sushi. 

Was it tasty? It was ok. Worth it? Can't say that it is.
author: Julie L.

description: 4 stars based on the great and fast service, clean place! Now, Sushi... I've had better but it was not bad. I would go back. Nice enviroment.
author: Paula V.

description:
I'm giving it 3 stars because at the moment there was not many selections of sushi to pick from. I ordered a spicy unagi hand roll took them 10 min to make,  they totally forgot about my tuna. So not to happy with service. 
The roll was good, but not 10min waiting for it good. 
The chefs are not concerned about you, they make the sushi in front of you and that's it. If you want to order you need to stand up so they can hear you.
author: Martin R.

description:
I went here with a group of friends and it's definitely fun to pull your sushi off of the boats. However, the sushi was not particularly impressive and the prices do add up, although each little plate is around $4/$5 I ended up spending $20 on mediocre sushi. I thought the tempura was pretty good, but I didn't enjoy the spicy tuna. The rolls were not tightly packed and were quite crumbly. 

Also, for people new to sushi I think this could be confusing because there's not any clear indications of what the sushi is coming around. The servers were friendly but it feels a little disjointed because they stand behind you. 

I could see going back to grab a roll or two for fun, but I don't think I would go back looking for a high quality sushi experience.
author: Anna M.

description:
Warakubune (is it just me or is it really hard to remember this name lol) had insanely fresh and delicious sushi/sashimi! My friends and I got here around 730 pm and the wait wasn't that bad, maybe only 10 minutes max. However, the place is a bit small so it's best to go here with a smaller group. We sat at the sushi boat and the staff (being incredibly friendly and helpful) immediately filled and refilled our waters and teas maybe three or four times, which in my book is pretty damn good.

I ordered the spicy white tuna and grabbed four other plates off the sushi boat and all of them were delicious! The spicy white tuna wasn't actually that spicy and was more wasabi-spicy than anything, and was very tender and fresh with a yummy sauce on the bottom to douse your tuna in. If you're expecting a very heavy, decadent, American style deep-friend sushi with lots of sauces and crunchy flakes on top then this is not your go to place. Their rolls were much more simple, less heavy on the sauces, and felt more authentic to the actual sushi you'd find in Japan, which I really liked. 

The only thing that I didn't like was that it was uncomfortably stuffy in the restaurant, which is understandable since there's no AC in most places in SF, but nonetheless I was pretty hot and was ready to leave at the end. Overall the food was amazing and pretty cheap (if you watch what you eat/count how many plates you get.. I got 5 and it ended up being almost $30 total including tip. yikes) and the service was great. I would definitely come again, but maybe in the back where it might be cooler haha.
author: Joy K.

description: The seafood salad is off the hoooook! Also like the floating sushi environment. Do wish there was more sushimi options floating
author: Everybody S.

description: ABSOLUTELY love this place. Living in San Francisco there are so many Sushi restaurants to choose from and I have tried many. Nonetheless I always come back to Warakubune. Their service is friendly and the food is fresh . I love the fact that you can grab the food from the boats. I am a visual person so I have yet to memorize some of the names of the dishes so when they go around the boat I get to eat some that I have forgotten about.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Fun little space and good food...if you can get it.

We went for dinner on Friday night at 9pm and were seated within 5 minutes - good!  We were quickly brought hot tea and water (upon request), which was also much appreciated.

I really liked the sort of old fashioned, waterfront ryokan feel of the restaurant and the old-timey boats that circulate with the sushi on them are much nicer than the alternatives at uber-modern kaiten sushi options around the city.

The reason this only gets three stars, however, was the lack of food.  I know it was on the later side to have dinner, but if you're serving guests until 10, there should be food on those boats the entire night...

When we first sat down, about half of the boats were empty.  Most of the remaining sushi on them - all rolls - was never touched for the remainder of the evening.  I had two servings of spicy raw oysters (four oysters), one serving (two pieces) of BBQ eel sashimi, and one serving (two pieces) of a ginger albacore sashimi within the first 15 minutes of arriving - all from the boats.  However, those were all items that were initially circulating.  In the entire hour we were there, they only added four more plates to the boats.  The rest of the time, the chefs were either cleaning up for the night or pushing out orders that people had placed off of a menu.

For me, the appeal of coming to a place like this is having the chefs create whatever they want and then getting to see it all and decide what appeals to me.  If I wanted to just order sushi off of a menu, it wouldn't come to a kaiten sushi restaurant.  Yes, everything we did manage to get was really excellent, but I wasn't incredibly full upon leaving because there was hardly any food to choose from.

I imagine if you come earlier, you'd have a lot more selection - but I also imagine that you'd be fighting more people for it / waiting longer for a seat....a real Catch-22!
author: Tay H.

description:
Warakubuni is my all-time favorite sushi restaurant. Sometimes the wait times can last awhile as seating is limited but the wait is worth it.

I know sushi boat restaurants get a bad rap, but this place is different. The sushi is fresh and it changes quickly. And if you don't see anything you like floating by, you can order from the menu.

The special roll and the spicy white tuna are my favorites. 

They tend to be out of ebi (shrimp) and uni (sea urchin) frequently. 

This place is a bit pricy, but the quality is amazing, so it's worth it.

I can easily shown spend $80 on myself without flinching. It's definitely a wonderful luxury!

In the 6 years that I've been coming here, I've only experienced one of night and that is when the head sushi chef was on holiday. Other than that, it's 100% consistent.

I hold all other sushi restaurants to Warakubuni's standard. So far, only a few have even come close!
author: Caine H.

description: Better be quick with your chopstick(s)... these sushi boats move fast! Service is attentive and friendly. The food is good here. The oysters, the scallops and the rolls were decent. They probably use too much rice on the nigiri. Also some (just some) of the nigiri fish (tuna specifically) could be better quality (fresher?)
author: Jason P.

description:
I can't say enough good things about Warakabune. I like this place so much, I almost didn't want to say so on Yelp for fear of making my wait longer next time I go there. They are in the very walkable neighborhood of Castro / Upper Market. On that note, if you can avoid driving here, you're less likely to make yourself insane trying to find parking. 

Every time I've been there, I'm greeted with a smile. If your party is 4 or fewer, I highly recommend sitting at the sushi bar, as food comes out fast and often, and just about everything is good. Plus, it comes around on BOATS! Who does't like sushi delivered to you on clever watercraft? 

Know this, even if you're at the sushi bar: If you're a picky eater or just have a hunger for something specific, ask for it. Their sushi chefs are usually pretty cool about making custom rolls to order. Each time I've done that, the food has been very good as well. 

If your party is bigger than 4, you'll probably want to sit in the small dining room toward the back of the restaurant. There you will have access to all the same food you would have at the bar, but you'll be in a less crowded environment.

Also good to know: They serve ramen. The ramen I've had there is not the best in the city, so if that's what you're craving, you're probably better off going to a ramen-specific restaurant. But if your friends want sushi, and you just can't hang with that, their ramen will suffice in a pinch.
author: Brian K.

description: Oh no not coming regularly enough again. I'm losing mayor status. Love this place. Super friendly servers and sushi chefs.
author: Griselda Z.

description: Decided to come and eat here because we were in the area and were craving sushi.  I ordered sushi from the sushi belt and I was not impressed.  I had a spicy ahi roll and I did not think it tasted fresh.  Something was off.  I was surprised because I read good reviews on Yelp.  You can go elsewhere for better sushi.  The staff was welcoming and the service was average.
author: Mikayla M.

description: This place is solid for a sushi boat place. It is one of our go-to spots when we can't risk being disappointed. It is reasonably priced and will hit the spot if you are craving sushi. We never have to wait very long to be seated and the staff has always been friendly and attentive.
author: Jenna M.

description: If you want sushi, you better come here! It's very good! Instead of a belt, they use a boat! That's interesting! The sushi is also good! So if you are a sushi lover, you will definitely love this place( Not just that, you will come back FOREVER!)!
author: Simon H.

description: Meh. I've experienced better. :(  and the wasabi was so weak premixed in whipped form consistency weird
author: Vincent M.

description: Had a great dinner here.  Love the sushi boat just wish they had more of a selection. Also many of the sushi boat items seemed quite expensive not many lower option choices. .
author: Natalie K.

description:
In spite of my bloodline, I am not all that into sushi. I used to be a fiend for it in my youth, but as I get older, the prospect of letting raw fish swoosh through my gullet doesn't appear to generate as much pleasure to my palate. But every once in a while, I do get a motherland craving, and I had heard good things from sushi aficionados about Warakubune. I figured going there may generate good karma since it's located close to the dearly departed No Name Sushi which I used to frequent when I was struggling in my twenties. The place appears hermetically sealed since you can't see their operation from the outside.

Once you walk in, you are automatically greeted by a pre-recorded "Irasshaimase!" and the familiar sushi boat beckons you just like it does at Isobune. The boats were moving quickly in front of me, so I felt a need to do some stretching exercises to make sure I can grab a plate without causing a pile-up of raw fish in the canal. The waitresses buzz by with hot green tea and a hot towel. OK, I'm ready. I started slow with the $3.75 Saba (mackerel) which I haven't had in an eon or two (see photo). It was quite good, so to pace myself, I glanced over to see how quickly others' plates were piling up. The young slackers with the pot bellies next to me had quite a tower of stoneware started, and they didn't look like they were about to finish.

So I ordered one of their $5.50 house specials, the Unagi Teriyaki, which was a roll of barbecue sea eel doused in teriyaki sauce and topped with avocado and crab meat (see photo). Delicious if a bit on the decadent side. I thought I should have some Uni (sea urchin) to cleanse the palate, and for $3.95, it was nicely smooth and fresh (see photo). Then I went on a tear - the $3.95 Kani Salad (crab meat) satisfied my craving for a bit of crab salad in a roll (see photo), the bargain-price $2.95 Cuttlefish provided a nice chewy texture (see photo),  the $3.95 Maguro (tuna) was essential eating (see photo), and the $4.35 Oysters offered fresh slurpiness.

The one miss of the bunch was a $4.75 house special of an odd California roll topped with chopped tuna and accompanied by taro prepared like French fries (see photo). It was just weird and I should have known better since several of these creations kept circling in their barges several times without any prospect of a pick-up in the near-term. By the time I found myself feeling sated, I noticed my pile of plates looking embarrassingly tall, so I divided them in half in a hapless attempt to look like I have a bird-like appetite. To her credit, the waitress didn't slap her forehead in utter disbelief, but she may have thought I was that guy from Man Vs. Food.

FOOD - 4 stars...solid sushi for the most part with a few creative misfires
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...I was getting seasick
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...you can find your sushi groove here
author: Ed U.

description: For a sushi boat restaurant, this place rules.  I love how I can sit down and immediately start eating.  The chef is really nice too and will make you pretty much whatever you want.  Prices are little high but then again the sushi is pretty decent quality.  A fun place for a quick bite that's been in the hod forever.  Check it out!
author: Ryan M.

description:
I don't really write bad review until something really pisses me off. The food here is mediocrity at its finest, but the service here is horrible. The servers are really rude. Throwing utensils in front of us, dragging chairs around making loud noise, asking us to sit at the sushi bar while there are clearly empty tables.

Will never come back to this place.
author: Leona H.

description:
There are very few things that make me weak in the knees. 

1. Foie Gras (Farewell soon, my love)
2. Mr. Hendrick's 
3. CARBS

Nothing turns me on more than the smell of freshly baked bread wafting through the air (Yes, I'm that easy). It makes my heart beat faster and a sensation surges through my body like a wild fire. It drives me insane. It makes me salivate all over. 

Damn you, insulin storage hormones! 

Unfortunately, carbs hate me. Just looking at them makes my muffin pop explode out of my spanx so I can forget about eating them. 

Being a sushi purist, I don't like Chinese sushi (and I'm Chinese). *everyone throw stones at Cherylynn* Just like my men, I like my sushi authentic, plain, and raw...none of that mayo crap squirted all over which Warakubune Sushi has. So what brought me to Warakubune Sushi? 

THE LO-CARB SEAFOOD SALAD (Off-the-Menu - $24)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#ltUypmfV5EM4EnMzu28nmA
Swimming in a pool of bland ponzu dressing were chunks of sake, maguro, tai, hamachi, hotate, ebi, and tako intermingled with cucumbers, grape tomatoes, and avocado chunks. For $24, I expected a lot more in terms of quality. The fish tasted ALL THE SAME. Although firm and tender, none of the fish had a silky butteryness to it. The tako (octopus) was especially tough and rubbery. The cucumber chunks were dry as the Sahara desert like it had been pre-chopped the day before. More sesame seeds could have been used to give it more a flavor and texture dimension. 

Mr. NSS called me a high maintenance food snob because he thought it was good. Coming from a person that doesn't mind going to Jack in the Crack? PSHHH. *rolls eyes*

Warakubune Sushi is also a sushi boat restaurant and I initially thought I would cave if I saw handrolls and nigiris cruise by but my heart sank as I saw each boat roll by...

BOAT #1: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#Vtxb9EhHIftPWyUvMFus8w

BOAT #2: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#GrgRd829oLkPlf_CmqJQ7g

BOAT #3: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#q7h4i6-XhIy8MRmoMRMJBg

BOAT #4: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#UkeNAHQXSm0eobuzl9D3yA

BOAT: #5: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ#SsPe3tE9mfLmw-nPvmcHYQ

There's nothing sexy about CA Rolls, Cucumber Makis and Inari. I guess that was a blessing in disguise because I would have been ALL over them rolls...

OTHER NOTES:
*Service was friendly but very aloof
*Bento Boxes, Donburi, Ramen, Udon, and Soba are also available on the menu
*Order from the sushi chefs to have your sushi made-to-order (who knows how long those trays have been sitting there and who has coughed/sneezed into them from other ends of the table)
*Sushi boat prices: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ?select=Dc59fZZak_NpFwy7Gt0ENQ#Dc59fZZak_NpFwy7Gt0ENQ
*If you're a sushi snob, stick with places in Richmond (Tekka and Okina), Sunset (Koo and Kazu), and J-Town (Ino)
*Difficult street parking
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Meh. Nothing impressive here. Ordered take-out one night and portions are on the smaller side. Food was fine, but nothing memorable. We had rolls and salads. Definitely better options just down the street.
author: Kathy L.

description:
I like the concept of sushi boat because I can see the food, but I can also understand how it's not too appealing in that the food sits there for a while and you can't tell how long it's been sitting there if you're not diligently watching the food.  I've been here twice with the boyfriend and there are no complaints from me.

The fish seems fresh, I enjoy the concept, and it's very reasonably priced for a cute little date night.
author: Erica A.

description: This place is great! I love the seafood salad. Has all the fish you need plus more. Their service is very friendly! Will be returning.
author: nathan c.

description:
If you like...

...Bland, gloppy Chicken Katsu curry 
...The whole sushi boat thing
...Fairly fresh Hamachi and Tuna Nigiri and  
...California Rolls loaded with mayo

Then Warakubune Sushi is the place for you.  

(Not the place for me though.  Oh well.)
author: Amy C.

description: Gender neutral bathroom and sushi on boats. Fish was fantastic quality.  Fresh and delicate. Be prepared for QUICK service but real friendly.
author: Juke W.

description:
Solid 3-3.5 stars.

I really enjoy their spicy seafood salad and spicy white tuna.  Good sized portions for what you pay.
author: Leland H.

description: Great neighborhood sushi restaurant. Seafood is veeeeeery fresh and literally melts in your mouth. When we came in, there were many rolls on the boats. I am not a fan of crab, mayo or cooked sushi, which what was on the boats mostly. But I ordered things that I like and they were made to order very quickly. Their house specialty poke is a must. Had to have a few of them.
author: Anat N.

description:
Sushi boats are usually terrible, but this place was actually really good. I've been here three times now - each time the food was four-star good.  Some of the items are impressive. I ate a lot and I didn't eat anything I didn't enjoy; some of it was stellar. 

Unfortunately... 

They keep this place about fifteen degrees too warm.  There's no reason to keep it in the mid 80s. I don't care if it's cold outside - if it's too hot inside, it's too hot. Why make your customers uncomfortable when it is easily avoidable? 

The seats are WAAAAAY too close together for me. I don't like when my shoulders touch the  stranger next to me. Maybe if I were skinnier, I wouldn't hate this, but I find it worse than communal seating. 

Service is usually middling. 

I thought the prices were too high for what we were getting. I've paid just as much or less for identical items at higher-end sushi establishments.
author: Tim W.

description:
My sushi craving go to spot. By far the best one around the SF area that I've tried.

It is a bit small, but you're in SF and everything around here is cramped into a small place.lol

The tempura sushis are the BEST & always crispy!! Definitely fulfills my umami taste buds 

Been here a couple times already and never had to wait to get seated.
author: JG I.

description:
I'm going to have to round down with this place and say 3.5 
Why? 

Because on Sunday night after getting the bill I asked "$70?! That seems like a lot for what we ate..." to which the mister said "well, you WERE pretty hungry and you ate most of it...you ate a lot" And I said "yea I know but $70 worth?? Let me count this" 
So 13 plates and a soda ran me $70 which still to me seems on the overpriced end when the two of us have done more damage for less at another sushi boat place. Reason? This place prices their plates higher. I guess they can get away with it since it's the only sushi boat spot in this area. 

When you sit down, it's hard to see what's coming around. Reason for that is that the sushi boats are running above table level. So weird. 

The other thing I didn't like was that they were pretty slow to get sushi out. Many boats circled around empty for quite some time and then when they did refill them, it was boring basic stuff (seaweed salad, Inari, California roll). They didn't break out with the good nigiri until later. Had some surprisingly really really good salmon. So good I ordered another 2 and a special albacore nigiri that had ginger and scallion on it for the mister. We both really enjoyed it. Forced him to eat an order of the scallop nigiri even though he said he was full because it just looked so damn good. And ya know what? It was so sweet. Yum.

2 guys next to us were eating out of a massive bowl that was basically a cornucopia of sashimi. I asked myself what the heck is that and why isn't it in my face right now?? Eventually I worked the balls to just asked the guys what it was. They told us it was spicy seafood salad which actually wasn't spicy at all and then insisted we try some. Okay, I admit. I took sashimi from a stranger. It was a hodge podge of everything! Cucumbers, little sweet cherry tomatoes, salmon, maguro, scallop, octopus...  The quality was very good! I honestly didn't expect fish to be at this caliber at a sushi boat restaurant (now I'm not saying it's Maruya or Akikos but it's damn well decent). 

Next time if I am in the area and have a mean hankering for sashimi, I am going to skip the damn boats. Screw that child's play ok? It's a waste of money. I'm going to order that giant massive sashimi salad thing and conquer it. Just you wait.
author: Susy C.

description:
Still a solid source of quality fish, very good service, and great prices.

Dropped in last evening early to avoid the Sunday Night crowd, especially post Bay to Breakers. 

Floating past were all my favorites, like oysters and spicy tuna roll, oh and the most wonderful salmon, so flavor filled and melt in your mouth tender. So many choices went past, and more folks came in and before I knew it there were 10 empty plates in front of me...

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
SPICY WHITE TUNA is the best sushi I've ever eaten.. I'm drooling just sitting here thinking about it. It's chunks of white tuna, edges covered in sesame seeds and seared super quickly, and then topped with a little ginger and their special sauce and heaping full of thinly sliced green onions. The fish is so fresh and doesn't even taste fishy. I used to never eat raw fish at Japanese sushi restaurants, but for some reason, I had to try this, and now, I cant stop eating this! I mean, the price went up a little, but that's only because the price of fish at the fish market went up. Still the same good fresh fish!

Special Roll - shrimp tempura roll topped with avocado, crab meat and special sauces.. it is so delicious and a beautiful display!

Coming in, you can choose to sit at the sushi boats or the tables in the back. Sometimes their sushi boats are empty, but that's because they want to make the sushi fresh. I've been to some sushi restaurants that the sushi have been going around in circles for like 5 hours.. gross.. Totally not the case here! Don't even hesitate to ask the chefs to make it for you fresh!  I also like how their ginger is not the dyed pink stuff that is usually served. They constantly refill their tea for you and everything is clean, even the bathroom!

MY TO GO SUSHI PLACE IN SF
author: Carmen C.

description:
Hands down this is the best quality for the money in sushi in the area.  Other sushi restaurants are far more expensive, less friendly, and precious.  Warakubune has very fresh, delicious sushi (and I'm not even a big fan of raw fish).  It's fun to sit at the counter with the floating boats of food going by!  And service is impeccable, very quick and friendly. 

Try their "Special" shrimp and avocado roll...YUM!

We've gone here probably 50 times and it's always consistently good.  Get there early, though, as you'll have to wait 15-20 minutes after 6:30pm.
author: Jamey F.

description:
Is this a joke? Warm sushi. Maybe three different kinds of rolls. Hovering waitresses.  Hard mochi ice cream. 

This place was awful.  The only good part was the warm towels they give when you sit down.  

But the sushi was I'll prepared and warm.  I can already feel the food poisoning setting in.
author: Laura D.

description:
Decent spot to go for sushi if you are with friends. I haven't found the wait times to be very long, even if you do choose to dine from the sushi boat seating area. The sushi is decent, but it definitely does cater to less of a traditional taste. You can expect to find some of the more non-standard types of special rolls here, along with some classic favorites like tuna rolls and salmon nigiri. I did realize though that sometimes the sushi does float around for a while, and I question how fresh the fish is after spinning in the boats. Other than that, the food is pretty decent.

If you do not find what you are looking for, you can also always opt to order specific sushi dishes that you want from the sushi chef. Pricing is coded based on the type of plate you select, so nicer items will generally be more expensive. Service is also attentive enough, and generally pretty friendly as well. I would recommend coming here if you are in the mood for a light meal because it's easy to gauge how much you want to eat since you can just pull it off from the floating boats.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Pretty pricey for simple americanized sushi.

This place is just for the experience of revolving sushi. However, most of the rolls were pretty simple and pricey at that. $1.95-$4.35 a plate for only 2-3 pieces? If you do the math, if you wanted to get 8 pieces (like most sushi places), you would have to pay $4 x 4 orders (of 2 pieces) = $16 for that roll?! No thank you. I'd rather pay that money to go to Kabuto instead [http://www.yelp.com/biz/kabuto-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:K8af8vJ4ylwJ65rG8vGLZg]

If you must come here, order Special Roll [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/warakubune-sushi-san-francisco?select=ltUypmfV5EM4EnMzu28nmA#LeI18_0AF4aHIB_n9Gj1RA] and the Spicy White Tuna Roll.

Pic of the small little restaurant: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/warakubune-sushi-san-francisco?select=ltUypmfV5EM4EnMzu28nmA#2rs1rSrulqM40PMwm_gwgg

What makes revolving sushi fun is looking at the different kinds of sushi in each boat. But if a lot of the sushi in each boat are the same... what's the fun in that? =\ We still made it fun by watching the sushi chefs and trying to get the first one he takes out to get the freshest roll. "NO b*tch that's OURS!!" lol jk we didn't say that. 
Or did we..? =P

OVERALL: good experience for revolving sushi. a bit pricey for simple sushi.  Don't think I would come back.
author: Raquel Y.

description: Five stars for the food but one star for the service. The young man kept hovering over my party, walking behind us and looking and stopping and looking...both servers were rude and abrupt. We felt rushed and uncomfortable and watched. It was an awkward experience.
author: M L.

description: Decent Sushi Boat Restaurant with a moderate selection of sushi.
author: Clinton C.

description: The sushi boat concept is one that I truly love as you watch the sushi float by and select only the options you desire. I loved the design of this restaurant as the sushi chefs were in the middle of the sushi boat area so you could watch them prepare the sushi. At other establishments I have seen the boats just float in, but been unable to watch the food preparation which always makes me wonder what is going into the dish. At this restaurant we had the salmon roll, spicy tuna, and tuna roll. sashmi and miso soup. The miso soup was flavorful and the fish in the salmon roll tasted very fresh. I was not a huge fan of the tuna roll as it did not taste as fresh as the other fish. However, the spicy tuna did not have the same taste so I am not sure what the distinctive difference was. We came early, and until four to five groups were seated did not have a lot of variety in the food options. This changed as we stayed longer, but was a little annoying at first. Overall this place is a-ok in my book. While it might not be my first stop in San Francisco, it is still worth a visit now and again.
author: Dawn B.

description:
This place is by far my favorite sushi place in the city and peninsula.  I've been trying to search all over for a better tasting and better priced placed than here, and I have yet to find it.

If you've never tried the spicy seafood salad and love sashimi, you must try it at least once.  It serves 2-4 people.

The service is very friendly and quick and I am going to be so sad when I move and won't be able to come here as often anymore.  I live only 1 block from here and despite all the wonderful places I can walk to in the Mission and Castro, this is the one place I will miss the most.
author: Sabrina H.

description:
The food here is not bad. It's fast and simple. The sushi boat seems to be popular. The fish is really tender. I'm not a sauce fan but my boyfriend is so he love the dishes that came out. I on the other hand was just impressed at how fast the dishes came onto the boat. 

I would come back. The uni wasn't the best but it wasn't bad either.
author: Marlene T.

description: It's all about instant gratification here. Want a decent roll and want it now?  Just grab one off the sushi boat.  Not tons of variety, but a solid selection. They also have great udon soups.  Wasabi out of a tube is disappointing as is the overly attentive, bordering on annoying, staff.
author: Kamael S.

description:
It must mean something when you're sitting at a sushi conveyor belt next to an Anthony Bourdain-esque clone, thick book in hand, rocking a dark suit jacket with casual pants, salt and peppered hair, and clearly a friend of the owners.  

Given that the owners are NOT Japanese (they're my Cantonese homies), the sushi quality remains high for this type of joint.  I walked in at around 8:30pm on a Friday night and it looked like there wasn't much left on the belt expect for some fried sushi pieces and some spicy tuna maki adorned with yam fries.  No seriously, I kept seeing those two circle around and around that I couldn't forget them.

It doesn't matter because you can just order whatever nigiri you feel like eating.  The only downside to this is that you won't know what specialty dishes they have in their pocket... some which I was able to see later like the seared tuna (which is actually more raw) and then some octopus/zucchini dish that I couldn't snatch my hands on in time.  Conveyor belt is only for the quick of mind and fast reflexed.... otherwise expect yourself to be running for your dish.

Now the crowning moment was when I got the uni.  This is like the creme de la creme of nigiri for me and my dessert to a proper Japanese meal.  The sushi man said that they had only a little bit left, but possibly not enough to make two pieces.  But he scrounged it up and was able to give us two luscious pieces of glory.  It tasted fresh and buttery, just as it's supposed to.

Now don't get all snobby on me because this is a conveyor belt place so treat it as one.  Locals clearly love it here--all I saw were hugs to the owner and "see you next week"s.  Now that's my kind of place!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Ehh...this place was alrite. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, which was not what I expected. The tonkatsu pork was served on the side and the ramen tasted like it could've came out of a packet. I would advise to stick with the sushi, as those dishes seemed pretty decent but nothing too special.

Service was pretty dismal. Friends got their food 40 minutes before the ramen came out. Our waiters didn't really come to check up on us and they forgot some of our orders. Our party was fairly large though, so I'll give them some leeway for it. Don't think I'll be back.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Great value sashimi, relaxing environment and lovely staff made this the perfect spot to visit after an exhausting day of walking the streets of SF. 

This place was located really close to our apartment and we popped in around 5.30. It was easy to get a table, but by the time we left an hour later it was nearly full around the sushi-boat area so make sure you either make a booking or get in early!

I ordered a sashimi platter - I always get sashimi rather than sushi as sometimes I don't really enjoy the rice. For 12 pieces of sashimi it was around $16 I think - a good price for a delicious, fresh selection. My only gripe is that I don't know what the fish pieces were but I enjoyed them all, salmon is always my favourite. 

I also had my husband's miso soup (he got a set dinner meal) which was delicious and green tea was served and refilled quickly. Service was friendly and helpful - they didn't even mind when I asked how the sushi-train of boats worked (I couldn't see how they were being propelled and it was really bugging me! Apparently the water keeps them moving around, there must be a fan/jet in there somewhere).
author: Briony C.

description: Fun to sit at the bar and watch the boats go by! Tough to stop from overeating. Each dish was roughly $4-5 for 2-4 pieces, so overall was a pretty cheap date (about $50 total). Not the fanciest sushi you'll ever have but plenty good for the value.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I just love this place.

I hadn't been for a while and sure enough, Tiffany remembered me and welcomed me back.

Special requests are not a problem and I've not had a piece of fish I didn't like - I've been going here since 1995.  I hope they stay in the neighborhood and continue to prosper by delivering great service and fresh, delicious fish
author: C S.

description: Sushi here is just mediocre. I arrived around 6:30pm and the sushi boats were full. There were decent amount of options. I ordered the tempura and its was waaaay too much batter and the batter is not event right... A little disappointed. The sushi rolls were okay.
author: Fei G.

description:
Meh. Its alright if there is nowhere else to go. All of the sushi on the boats is a variation of a California roll. Nothing any different from that. A few pieces of sashimi here and there. There just wasn't enough variety for me. i also feel like it was overpriced. A little seaweed cost us $4? White tuna was pretty good though. 

Also, the service was...weird. It was a slower night and the waitress stood right next to us the entire meal and watched us. As if we were going to put raw sushi into my Michael Kors. No girl. She was just so abrasive too. 

Much better places in the city to eat some sushi. On a boat. Bye
author: Lana S.

description: The sushi is sub par even for a conveyor-boat style restaurant. Obviously don't expect high quality raw fish that has been cruising around a restaurant for who knows how long...but this food was especially poor quality. Even the wasabi and the ginger seemed old and used.
author: Mike S.

description:
Ship has sailed.

Front room has a sushi boat.

Back room has things like Tori udon with so much chicken and noodles it's two delicious and filling meals in one. Surprisingly light. Even more surprisingly $12.

With sushi in the logo had to try a roll as well. Salmon, cucumber and avocado was $4 for three rather generous and enjoyable pieces. 

Service was attentive but borderline perfunctory. Space lacked character. But despite the unmemorable atmosphere the food made it a memorable meal.

You won't miss the boat.
author: Jason B.

description:
Pros:
- Novelty of boat sushi
- Japanese welcome voice

Cons:
- Masago not fresh
- Very expensive for 2 pieces of maki (4 bucks).  Spent 30 bucks on 10 pieces and a seaweed salad.  Could have gotten twice that for same money at another place.
- Obscure choices, not quite authentic Japanese sushi.

There are too many other excellent sushi restaurants in SF.  I can't believe all 3+ star reviews here.
author: Anthony S.

description:
The boat sushi is good, for boat sushi. The spicy seafood salad is hardly spicy, but delicious.

Service is good enough. Seats can feel cramped. Consider getting a table in the back.

Get some drinks at Tacorgasmico down the street and eat here after.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Sushi boat places are so much fun!

Great place to take a date, a friend, or your parents...just be sure to make 'em eat something weird. 

Tip: It's gonna add up if you get the expensive plates, so you might wanna watch what you're grabbing.
author: Murphy O.

description: Glad this place is a few blocks from my house! The sushi is great. Sit at the bar and watch the boats go round. Grab what you want. You can also order specifically what you're looking for. The Spicy Albacore is simply amazing! Service is great. The only downside is it can get a little crowded and you may have to wait but I guess that comes with the territory. Hopefully my review doesn't attract too many new customers.
author: Eddie K.

description:
The best Sushi in San Francisco is right here!!! 

Truly amazing on many levels. They have the freshest, most tastiest Sake (Salmon) I have ever tasted - yes, it is that good. Another favorite of mine is the Butter FIsh - my god it's truly melts in your mouth. They have this amazing "special" roll that is unlike anything I have ever tasted. It comes wrapped in avocado and in a spicy orange sauce...it's to die for. There is another roll that comes with these really cool french fries - I think they are turnip fries - but the roll that comes with it has this amazing spicy red sauce on ti that you can dip the turnip fries in. Soooo damn good!! The staff is also on top of their game and there for your every need. I am going here tonight, I made myself hungry after writing this review.
author: Neil M.

description:
My favorite sushi spot in SF. Tiffany and Ben make the experience special every time and I've been a 1x every two week customer for over 3 years.  Clean restaurant, always freshly purchased fish and Ben's very open for creating custom options. Some personal favorites
- Spicy Scallops over half an avocado
- Spicy White Tuna Sashimi
- Special Shrimp Tempura Roll
- Unagi hand roll

- If you're an Uni fan and it's in stock, it's always delicious. 

Highly recommend sitting by the boat bar.
author: Paul S.

description:
We had a party of around 8 people. Although this is a pretty big party, it was pretty ridiculous that our food came out over 20 minutes apart. I mean normally people wait to eat together, but it was getting pretty ridiculous... So they just ate. But like it's pretty stupid to have people still eating while others are still eating. 

I ordered miso ramen. It was okay, not bad but not great. Ordered ika and the salmon special too. Pretty meh food for the service. Oh well.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I came here on a late Friday evening (around 8:30) and only had to wait for 2 minutes for two seats at the bar.  The waitress was sooo nice.. she was so sweet and reminded me of my friend's mom.  The service is also great - they refill your tea cup constantly even if you had only taken several sips.

The only downer was that they were out of halibut for the night (although the red snapper was a fine substitute) .. but everything else was fresh and the choices were unique, unlike the standard choices at other sushi boat restaurants.  There were quite a few options.  There was one dish that even came with fries.. of which kind I am not quite sure.  My boyfriend and I finished 13 plates.  We weren't full, but we decided we had had enough sushi for the night.  I didn't see the spicy seafood salad on the menu, but I'll be sure to order it next time.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Amazing if you can't be bothered to look at a menu and happy to try what comes to you on the sushi boat ride. You can also order a special request to the chef and he'll make it for you under your eyes. I couldn't get enough of the sushis, they were too good to stop I wanted to try them all. I'd recommend to share each plate with someone so you can try one of each without risking a food coma (comes by pair of 2, 4 or 6 for the smaller bites). Top it up with some cloudy unfiltered Nigori sake and you're in heaven. 
(Also super close to vibrant Castro for a good night out straight after.)
author: Olivia M.

description:
I got a really bad craving for sushi 2 days ago and HB Steph asked me if I had heard of the sushi place next to her, WITH BOATS. I actually HAD heard of this place before, from my best friend Jenna F., when we walked by it one night and she said, "This place is good, they serve sushi, IN BOATS."

So Friday night HB Steph and I arrived a little before 7pm to beat the 7pm rush (though the rain outside helped keep it a little slower than usual) and sure enough there was the sushi, IN BOATS. 

I expected the sushi to not really be that great- I get it, its gimmicky, BOATS, etc. but I immediately pulled some salmon nigiri and it was DELICIOUS. I was impressed with the quality of the fish! I also had several other rolls and nigiri pieces and was super impressed! It was kind of pricey, but the fish to rice ratio was also excellent!!! 

Walked paying 25. I'd definitely come back here. The sushi and the BOATS do not disappoint!
author: Emily D.

description: We tried this because of the great Yelp reviews but not sure what we're missing.  The fish wasn't fresh and it was pretty expensive for the quality.  It's also hard to find parking, even at 4pm on a Sunday so be ready to walk.  People working also tend to put their hands on the back of your chair when they aren't serving you and just hanging out.  Note - people were super nice and attentive but the chair touching annoyed my wife =).  Biggest disappointment was the grossness of the sushi.  Set your expectations really low and maybe it will be okay!
author: Ishi C.

description: Very high quality fish. My water never ran dry. Their ramen is also very delicious. I live in Seattle, but I come here every time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Stephen F.

description:
I have always had a thing for sushi being served on a boat that goes around and around. Not quite sure why. A lot of these types of places have closed in San Francisco and this was the only one I haven't been to. 

It's not necessarily that this place is bad, it's more of the fact that it's overpriced for what they are serving. It honestly looked like everything on the boats were a variation of a California Roll. Basic AND overpriced. 

When my friend and I first arrived around 7:30 on a Saturday night, we waited about 5 minutes for them to clean up the table that just left. Not too long of a wait, we got lucky. However, they need a better system in terms of remembering who came in first. Maybe a sign-up/ wait list would be helpful or should be utilized because the male server remembered we were there first and the female server tried to seat another couple who walked in minutes after us. 

If you are looking for authenticity, this is not the place. It is run by Chinese people, so it's your typical Chinese Japanese restaurant. I don't have a problem with it, I know what I'm getting myself into. I just couldn't really justify the crazy mark-up for the dishes just because we are in a particular neighborhood. 

Around 8pm it got super busy and there was a long wait. Also, you could tell there was a lot more people eating because a lot of the boats would be empty. The sushi chefs couldn't really keep up. 

Service here is pretty good though. They came by quite quickly to refill tea and my teacup was never empty. 

Counting the plates was a little weird. If you and your party are paying together, they line up all the different plates and stack the like ones together. I understand it's easier to count that way, but it's also messy. Some of those plates have sauces and the way they stack the plates on top of each other so quickly made the table so messy and dirty when we had to pay for our check. Is there possibly a cleaner method? 

Anyway, this place was fun to try, but I wouldn't really come back unless someone really wanted sushi boat and wanted to hang out in the nearby area. This might be the place for you if you enjoy California rolls though.
author: Rebecca T.

description: Fantastic experience and great service. The staff are unbelievably friendly and cooperative. I haven't had better sushi in all of my year. The facilities are absolutely stunning, and I cannot wait to return.
author: Zachary Y.

description: Legitimately the only good sushi boat restaurant left in SF/Daly City.  The fish here is fresh, and you can tell in the taste and texture of the food that goes on the boats here.  Sometimes they have this sashimi salad special - a heaping bowl of maguro, hamachi, white tuna, and a bunch of other fish in some kind of ponzu dressing with avocado cubes - and it is worth every penny of the twenty or so dollars it costs.  Whenever my family wants sushi, we make the drive down to Castro for Warakubune, even though parking here is a misery.
author: Tracey L.

description:
Warakubune might just be my favorite overall sushi place in San Francisco.  Now is it the best sushi I've ever had... No... but when I'm in SF and want sushi, I go to Warakubune 9 out of 10 times.  The fusion-y rolls are some of the best tasting and better deals I've encountered. Also, since it's sushi boat style with small orders you get the ability to try a lot of different kinds of sushi for a relatively inexpensive price (each roll comes on different kinds of small plates equates to a price).  Each plate typically comes with 2-4 pieces of sushi or a side dish like a seaweed salad.  Admittedly, sashimi isn't amazing so stick with the rolls (as a side note if you want amazing sashimi check out Tekka on Balboa!)

MY FAVS

Oyster Shooters
Unagi with avocado
White tuna toro
Shrimp tempura with avocado


SERVICE

Service is timely and good.  Best times to go are the main dinner hours as they keep a constant flow of different sushi and rolls coming quick.  If you want something special or something you haven't seen in a while just let one of the sushi chefs know!

OVERALL

A great sushi place to go any day of the week and an opportunity to have to try lots of different kinds of sushi without breaking the bank.  Highly recommended!
author: Rob P.

description:
Don't come here if you're expecting high quality fish! It is, after all, sushi served on conveyor belt boats! Do come here if you're just planning on a fun night out with some friends chatting and ogling what's floating by the bar in front of you next! All the dishes also really adds-up so it's not really that great in terms of value either. As a small Asian girl, I would say it will cost you at least $40 per person to feel full at this place.   

The biggest surprise for me here was the deep-fried seaweed-wrapped taro and shrimp. This strange combination is strangely addictive! Apparently this is a special that isn't served every day! They really should make this a regular item though because I would come back JUST to eat it.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Value sushi. Our total bill (for 2 w/ sake) was more around what I spend for myself for a solo dinner (w/o alcohol). 

Presentation on the plate is no-flare. However, the boats on the conveyor belt at the sushi bar are pretty entertaining.

Fish is good -- I've been told to go on Wednesdays because fish shipment comes in on Tuesdays.
author: Joanna K.

description:
To be completely honest, I am not a big fan of seafood. So I wouldn't really consider sushi as one of my favorite foods. But, since my girlfriend LOVES seafood (especially raw fish and sushi in particular), we decided to give this place a try. 

When I first walked in, I knew I was gonna like the service this restaurant provides. The sushi chef and waiters looked our way and greeted us with a smile once we were past the door. Other than that, throughout the evening, our waitress tended to our every need and had helpful suggestions on what we should order (I'm quite indecisive). It's always a plus when the service is excellent. 

Now let's talk about the food. We ordered a few items on the menu. Sashimi, oysters, octopus, and a few rolls. As I've stated, I'm not a big fan of seafood. But this restaurant might be a crucial factor that changes that opinion. The sashimi was absolutely delicious. It felt like the fish was melting in my mouth. The oysters were delightful as well. Although I don't eat shellfish often, these oysters are the best ones I've ever had. I actually enjoyed every single bite of food. The octopus was chewy and flavorful.
