My girlfriend also enjoyed everything. She's a huge sushi fanatic and has been to quite a number of sushi restaurants (in and out of the state). To rank this in her top 5 favorite sushi restaurants, is really making a statement. 

Overall, our experience at this restaurant was really enjoyable. The staff were friendly and nice. The food was mouth-watering. The ambiance of the place was comfortable and cozy. What more could you ask for? We will definitely be back!
author: Michael C.

description:
Sushi boats! C'mon, you know you like the boats, and you know that's part of the reason I'm going to go back here. Because it's fun.

But the sushi is also pretty good. If you get there when it's busy, you'll have no problem grabbing something delicious as soon as it appears. The nigiri is fresh, the rice is seasoned nicely, and the wasabi is well-apportioned.

As other reviewers have mentioned, this is not the place to get Americanized sushi. Avoid the asparagus tempura roll, or the mayo-covered thing which came with fries, because (1) why would you do that, and (2) those dishes look like they've had a long time to sit on the boat and quietly reflect their fate. This is a place for hamachi, sake, maguro, hirame, ikura, hotate, and maybe a spicy tuna or a California roll (if you must).

The atmosphere is lively and cozy. We didn't have to wait for a seat, but others did, so you might. (Timing is everything.) You will sit shoulder to shoulder with strangers, and pretend not to eavesdrop, and probably spill a bit of sake on yourself because there isn't a lot of room to pour. 

Once you're sated, the no-nonsense staff will be eager to tally up your bill and move you on, but you'll never feel rushed. You might note that there is, indeed, higher quality sushi somewhere in San Francisco, or that you spilled a bit of sake on your leg because someone bumped your elbow. But the sushi is still very good, the location is convenient, and it is way more fun to take your food from a tiny boat.
author: Alex L.

description: Very unsatisfactory experience. Judging by the absence of Japanese language on the menu and by the accents of the staff, they are not Japanese. Their serving style is not Japanese (gracious and pleasant) but Chinese (brusque to the point of rude). No refills were offered on water or tea. The sushi was fine but the tempura was disgusting - dense and crunchy like over-fried fish and chips, with only sweet potatoes and a single soggy broccoli - not at all light and delicate and varied in vegetables like true Japanese tempura. I should have sent it back.
author: Kenneth D.

description:
I have been here many times and these are the reasons that I keep coming back: 
1. Great, friendly staff
2. Very reasonable prices 
3. Very good sushi
4. The best option for quick dinner
My suggestion is that you shouldn't come here if you are more than 4 people.
author: Eirini P.

description:
This is for the table seating:

The service wasn't amazing - they initially forgot our menu and then took 20 minutes to give us a beer we'd asked for.

The nigiri was great. I ordered an 8 piece assortment. Thick slabs of fresh seafood - more volume to it than the pallet of rice underneath each piece. To me, the most important part of a sushi restaurant is the quality of its sushi, and Warakubune did not disappoint. Recommended.
author: Jade M.

description: I had sushi plenty of time but I never had the opportunity to eat sushi from a boat that goes around in a circle. The pricing is different according to whatever plate of sushi you picked. Some of the dishes that stood out were the oysters and the sashimi. I was craving oysters on our trip but I wasn't ready to wait in a long line for them. The oysters were actually pretty fresh and seasoned well. They are still raw but I like it that way with some squeezed lemon on them. We also ordered a sashimi plate (on their actual menu) and their fish was fresh and sliced pretty thick. If I was super hungry, I would have gone crazy and ate a lot more. Overall, the atmosphere and service were both nice. I definitely enjoyed this place and would come back in the future.
author: Thy T.

description: My boyfriend and I come here on the regular and always leave completely satisfied! They have an awesome sushi boat train where you sit sushi bar style and help yourself to any sushi plate floating by. Each plate has a pre determined price and at the end of your meal they count up your plates, simple as that! They also offer a full dinner menu including dinner plates, Ramen & Udon. We've had almost ever Ramen, all are delicious but the Spicy Ramen is our favorite. Ramen bowls are massive, great for sharing! One last point, the staff is awesome!
author: Sarah A.

description:
This is one of our regular spots to hit, so 5 stars. 

The sushi here is 4 stars good. Waaay better than just decent. It's fresh and creative which keeps you interested and entertained. Creative in a good way, not Barracuda-first-date-sushi-place- whoa-look-I-put-mango-in-a-sushi-roll-cause-I-don't-eat-nigiri-kinda-way. The nigiri (which can sometimes be a little heavy with wasabi) and sushi here are really delicious. All the usual nigiris are good here with walu or escolar being my favorite. They call it super white tuna, I've had it other places, and I like it here best. The one I like the least, the hotatei cause it has a wasabi bomb in it (I'm guessing to cover the fact that it may have been a frozen scallop at some point). 

Their creative rolls/plates are a nice way to change up your pallet, you might get a little salt overload though. Spicy white tuna, tataki, special roll, all hella good...all hella salty. 

I found out about this place probably 4 years ago, and have been coming back probably twice a month since then. That's because the service is great, the staff is nice and the food is genuinely good. It may not be the best or most authentic Japanese food you had (um duh bro, it's owned and operated by Chinese people, but so are many other Japanese places. Warakabune does it right. What can I say, some of my people really know how to imitate good Japanese food), but again IT TASTES GOOD and it's always entertaining to watch what the next sushi boat will bring. If you're sitting at the back tables or here during a slow time when the sushi boats aren't flowing with the good stuff or lack variety, you can always just order. 

And one last tip, that pretty much everyone who frequents here knows about...if you're really in the mood for fish and salt...get the spicy seafood salad..it's a combination of mixed sashimi, tako, cucumbers, and peppers in a spicy soy sauce...
author: Alan C.

description: Excellent sushi. Very reasonably priced. Would eat here again. I have been here three times now.
author: Chris A.

description:
Once the gimmick of sushi-boats wears off, you're left with food that has clearly been left out for far too long.  It was obvious the food wasn't going to be fresh when, after sitting down at a full table, not one of the three chefs prepared anything for the next fifteen minutes, choosing instead to let the (sometimes) crusted-over dishes continue to circulate untouched.

When the chefs finally started to add to the mix, they only added heavily sauced rolls, or pungent nigiri that had also been sitting out longer than one would hope.

For the record, they will add something tasty every now and then, but not enough to warrant the trip. Or the price.

If you're looking for a great sushi boat experience, I would recommend Isobune in J-town!
author: Nick B.

description:
Food on little boats?! This is ingenious!  

Generous portions, always fresh. Been coming her for years and the food is always great.
author: Paul Z.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE!!  Overpriced and low quality sushi. 

They removed my post and I'm re-posting and contacting yelp to let them know.  

I came here on a Sunday night with a friend because our regular spot Sushi Time was closed.  A hundred dollars (pre-tip) later, we left disgusted.   

The fish on the nigiri is cold and tasteless.  Extremely cold, like it was just recently thawed.  

The sauce they used on the rolls tastes like Chinese stir fry sauce from a jar or the fish is covered in spicy orange mayo.  They use way too much salt and siracha sauce. 
 
They even messed up the tempura.  How do you do that???  It was heavy on the batter and over-fried and tasted like they used old frying oil.

This place is the same quality sushi that you get at an all you can eat sushi buffet for $19.95.  

At Sushi Time, you can get ten times the quality of food for half the price.
author: Patricia L.

description:
I married my wife for many reasons, she shares many of the joys that I have. But she also shares some of my guilty pleasures. One of them being Sushi Boat places. I know I know, Sushi boat restaurants typically are never the highest quality place that you'll go to. It's raw fish, so it's best served right after it's made, not floating around on a little boat for every person in the restaurant to gawk at and breathe on before you snatch it up.

That all being said, I still love my Sushi boat restaurants. Like I said it's a guilty pleasure. It's like a game, hoping that the one plate you really want comes around. The issues of ordering to share are eliminated and you can just sit, talk, drink some sake and enjoy your meal. Once you're done you can sit back and admire your massive stack of plates.

Now that I'm done rambling, for Sushi boat restaurants Warakubune is probably the best quality of the ones in SF. The fish is pretty decent and the service is pretty good too. I actually like the location since it's close to where we are and ironically even though we typically cab it, for some reason we've ended up driving here several times and always seem to find parking within half a block. 

The different Nigiri of salmon, tuna and hamachi were all excellent and the rolls were actually tasty. To be honest much of the sushi was better than I've had at some regular Sushi joints. We also typically order Nigiri or hand rolls that you don't see on the boats which is totally fine. This is our go to spot for Sushi boats.
author: Hyung L.

description:
This place was weird.

The sashimi i ordered was fishy and not fresh. The tempura was ok but its pretty hard to fuck that stuff up. 

the food was supremely substandard.

the strangest part was the waitress who just hovered over me the whole time and literally asked me if everything was ok after each bite of food. 

oh and not that it really matters but the water in the moat that the boats run in looks like it has not been changed since 1996. its all murky and nasty.
author: Victoria G.

description: Family friendly, great vibes and atmosphere. The wife and I have been going here for years.  When you need sushi fast this is the place to go.  Music can be a bit much but the food is excellent.  We have brought the lil man when he was 8 months and it was not an issue.  Love these guys
author: Derik D.

description:
It's funny, I actually went through all the reviews on yelp for this place and discovered that 99% of non-Asians gave this place 4-5 stars and 90% of Asians gave 1-2 stars. 

We only decided to try this place because we saw that they have a 4 star rating, but we were sadly disappointed. The service however was very good. We didn't experience bad service like any of the other reviews talked about. I hate to leave such a low rating because the employees were pretty nice for the most part. 

But the food was overpriced and the sushi boats didn't have much variety. We ordered one roll (shrimp tempura) out of the 3 they had on their menu, a nabeyaki udon, and a salmon sashimi bowl. The salmon sashimi bowl came with salmon, rice, and cherry tomatoes. I repeat: cherry tomatoes. 

The bf and I knew right away that this place was catered to a certain demographic. And it wasn't us.. So lesson learned...
author: Lily Z.

description:
I made a reservation here for my friend's birthday because I have always loved this restaurant (SUSHI BOATS!!!!). After calling two hours beforehand to see if I could move the reservation back a half-hour to 8:30, I was yelled at and told that "NO, PEOPLE WILL BE WAITING", so I told the woman it was fine and we would keep the original time. We arrived to find our reservation had been cancelled (with no explanation or apology) and we had to wait 45 minutes to be seated, ironically at about the same time when I had asked our reservation to be adjusted to.

We didn't receive menus at the table for another 15 minutes, no water, nothing. 

I am always especially polite and accommodating to waitstaff, and this was the first time that I felt a service person had a personal vendetta against me. 

I had organized the dinner so I was trying to be sure things went smoothly, and I was snapped at by one of the waitresses at every turn...
-for asking about our edamame (which hadn't arrived after our sushi had already come) 
-for not knowing the difference between two types of tuna rolls (and the waitress ended up bringing the wrong one even after I clarified which one I wanted and then staring me down) 
-for ordering a salmon nigiri by saying "we'd like another salmon nigiri" when we hadn't ordered one to begin with
-for inquiring about an extra miso soup charge on our bill

I almost cried trying to interface with the waitress at the end of the meal, it was completely infuriating. 

Even though the salmon here is completely delicious, the experience last weekend was ridiculous enough that I will definitely never be returning.
author: Helen H.

description:
This is the hidden gem for sushi in SF. 

If you prefer sushi restaurants with a menu filled with large pictures of foo-foo speciality rolls... then this place isn't for you.  Warakubune has the freshest, top quality fish, yet it's priced very reasonable.  I've been here well over a dozen times and my favorite dishes are:

white toro tuna
spicy white tuna
special roll (shrimp tempura roll w/ avocado & special sauce)
butterfish
sake nigiri
white tuna tataki
seaweed salad
author: Matt S.

description: This is a good spot to go if you want a quick sushi meal because of the boats. However, all the rolls and sushi that rotate on the belt are all very Americanized - think california rolls, dragon rolls, rainbow rolls, and stuff with cream cheese. The quality is decent, but if you're looking for an authentic sushi experience, try somewhere else.
author: Amy Y.

description: I used to love this place, now I'm saddened by some the changes.  The food is still great and the place was never super cheap, but now they are serving smaller portions of fish (on sushi) and I got an order of scallops that looked like it was one scallop cut in half and placed on two pieces of rice.   It was half the size of what it used to be.  It's just unfortunate.  Definitely not coming back as often as I used to.
author: R X.

description: Good prices. The hamachi cheek on the specials menu is very very delicious and is a must have. A personal favorite of mine is the hamachi nigiri from the sushi boats.
author: Carolina L.

description:
Best sushi boat in the Bay Area. Sushi is always fresh, staff is super friendly and the sushi chefs always seem happy to serve you. 

My friends and I love coming here, but because it's the Castro, parking is always a challenge. The restaurant is small, so be prepared to wait as well.
author: Matt L.

description:
Update: I added one star after my last visit because the sushi chefs were keeping the boats filled for a change. It's a hit and miss option for me now. So 3 stars instead of 2 now,

3 years ago I would give this place 5 stars. But since then every time I try Warakubune  the sushi boat selection is smaller and lamer. Half the boats were empty tonight early on a Friday evening like you might see at closing time. Very sad these ghost boats -like pirates had pillaged them.  I go to a sushi boat place for the fun of choosing from a variety of sushi coming out of the chef station. Warakubune: not fun anymore. Now they encourage you to order off the menu - like they are giving up on the boats.  Although Warakabune waitstaff is really nice, next time I will go to Isobune for the real sushi boat experience. Although both joints use the same low grade cheaper pink ginger when real sushi bars use the undyed version. Step up the ginger sushi places - we know better. And Warakabune please improve. I want to like you again.
author: Marga G.

description:
Live scallop....$5.95 tender. Wish I could've had more!
Aji nigiri...$3.95 sooo good and fresh! 

Even their items on the boats are good. We got here at 5pm so the boats were more empty. However, by 6 pm more stuff showed up. Delicious Japanese pickled veggie maki ...yum!  

Tempura appetizer was good...although they should lighten up the batter. Under $6.  (About 8 pieces of tempura)

My sister's spicy seafood salad was deliciously savory but it had a bit too much sauce. Tons of sashimi!! $18.50!

Service = friendly

Bathroom = nice and clean

Prices = reasonable

Parking = street. Deal!  (Or take the J, it's in between two J stops)

I'll be back for more....

Note: I think they're Chinese owned...or maybe just happen to have plenty of Chinese staff (plenty of Cantonese being thrown around)
author: Fannie S.

description: Their sushi is simple and simply amazing. The fish is fresh and the cuts are thick. For boat sushi, this is one of the best you'll find especially in this area/neighborhood. My friends and I frequent this place, sometimes once a week and have gotten to know the super friendly staff. If you're looking for fancy mayonnaise or fried rolls, this is not your place!!
author: Tasha L.

description:
This review is over due.. Been coming for the past year or two or whenever I'm in the area...

Great sushi and a nice selection on the menu.
Why its not a five star review? The service kinda sucks...
I'm having a hard time understanding the waiters and also they are always in a hurry and you get the feeling lie you really need to know what you're going to ask them for or they just going to be mad and leave. I was ordering a few things for our group and in the middle the waiter/waitress (I don't remember) just left... (?!) Usually, waiters need to ask "is that all?" to make sure.. but I didn't get that.. I got an "ok" and a very fast waiter that disappeared..

Another down point is the kitchen. I have been there a few times with a group and someone from the group always prefers to order some sort of teriyaki dish or an udon soup... well that takes FOREVER! All the other people will be all done eating and the person with the teriyaki dish is still hungry! I'm talking like 30-40 minute wait! I have no idea why it takes so long but it happens every time! And I was raised with the table manners that until everyone gets their dishes/ arrives. You don't start eating. So it makes the experience very uncomfortable... When there are such nice little plates of sushi floating in front of your eyes and you just got to wait for those teriyaki people... :) 

You gotta fix it man! people are starving!
author: Ketie A.

description:
Let me first get this out of the way- sushi on little boats... moving on. 

BEWARE: authentic sushi! 
We stumbled on this place with some friends from out of town who were looking for "americanized sushi". They didnt love this place. Warakubune is for authentic sushi lovers. There are other options (teriyaki chicken, etc) but they are pretty uninspiring. 

The service is .. eratic. I felt sorry for our waitress who was literally running throught the restraunt. she was waitress and hostess. 

Now for a compliment: The prices here are great. The quality of the sushi is good. 

Not sure I will go back because I love a giant deep friend roll with cream cheese and spicy mayo.. Im a sushi fraud.
author: Sydney S.

description: The uni was very fresh and delicious. The sushi boats could slow down a bit though. Overall, good neighborhood joint. I would come back.
author: Emily C.

description: We went in, sat down and there looked to be no fresh sushi on the boats. Granted it was later in the evening. Service was also lacking. We actually ended up leaving when no one came to give us a plate. The place was crowded, so something must be great, it wasn't for me.
author: Jaye T.

description:
I'm surprised this place is 4 stars. 

The tables were sticky.  The cooks were slow.  The dishes came out completely disjointly for our whole table.  The servers constantly mixed up dishes and checks.

Perhaps all three servers that were on our table were new, so I can give them the benefit of the doubt.  However, if that were true, I can't give the same benefit to the manager who assigned all 3 newbies to our one table.. :(
author: Laundry F.

description:
Loved this place!  The quality of all the fish we tried was wonderful, and their seaweed salad was great.  Good gyoza, too.  We were bummed that we were too full to keep eating when the salmon nigiri and rolls started coming around on the boats -- it looked so good!  We will definitely be back for some old favorites and to try some new rolls.  The staff was nice and attentive (your tea mug will never be empty).

Tip:  if you get there before 6:30, order off the menu instead of waiting for rolls to come out.
author: Julia W.

description:
I really give them one and half stars because the waitstaff was very nice, and the sushi boats look like a whole lot of fun (didn't get to experience the boats).

The sushi is good.  Not amazing, omg-to-die-for, but good quality and great for the price.

Where it all goes wrong?  The chicken teriyaki.  It was one of the most disgusting dishes I've ever had.  Thinly stripped, the chicken had air bubbles.  AIR BUBBLES in chicken!  How is that even possible?  I have no idea.

The teriyaki sauce tasted like salt.  No flavor, no color, no good.

It worries me that a restaurant that can produce good sushi can produce such disgusting chicken teriyaki.  It makes me wonder if those fancy fishes as sushi are really that...
author: Preeti M.

description:
Are you a fan of spending money?  And not getting anything that you couldn't get at Safeway?  Then Warakubune Sushi might be right for you.  Where else can you spend $30 a person and leave nearly as hungry as when you came?  My favorite part of the experience was watching the same items go round on the boats as we were waiting, as we were eating, and as we were leaving.  

I enjoy getting something for my money, the quality was middling, so I won't be back.
author: Matt B.

description: I try and come here at least once a week. I love the sushi here and I've never really been a sushi person. The boats make it kind of entertaining too. Good for a date or going by yourself. You can order what you want or just wait for something interesting to float by. Service has always been friendly and they remember you.
author: Angelina P.

description:
Avoid.
Strip mall sushi for tiny boat enthusiasts.

Most things have sticky sweet slather or weirdo pinkish mayo schmaltz.
Shake n Bake breading on the Spider Roll? Really?

I heartily disagree with any characterization that this is good sushi let alone Japanese food.

For the $84 spent - jeez - 
Go gonzo at Sushi Time!
Or the superb silk tofu at Eiji.
Or hop on J-Church over the hill to spectacular Saru.
Or Ichi Ichi Ichi Ichi Ichi Ichi Ichi.
author: Anthony A.

description: This restaurant has the worst tempura in the world. Look at the brown colour tempura. You should never see a tempura like this s**t in a restaurant. Its flavour was just so disgusting! The flour is not even tempura flour. It was like a stone! You cannot even bite it unless you have a mouth of good tooth. As an Asian, I'm pretty sure that they are using wrong and cheap flour to make tempura. Although their sushi (SOME of them) is good, the tempura tells us they are not a good Japanese restaurant. All employees there are speaking Cantonese. Maybe the Cantonese chef does not even know how to make a tempura. So they do it in a Cantonese way which makes the tempura taste like some Cantonese deep fried dim sum. But It's also not a good dim sum at all. It was like a kind of deep fried flour sticks as hard as stone. Just so bad! After we talked this issue to the owner of the restaurant. Then the owner just left us and got us our check. There is no compensation at all and we didn't get any "sorry" or even a bubble gum! Bad food worse service. Unbelievable! Actually this is my second time visit to this restaurant. But I won't go there again. People, do not order ANY OTHER food except sushi there cuz nobody there know how to "cook" a Japanese cuisine in this restaurant!
author: Felix W.

description: Really quiet on Sunday night. Nice to go to a sushi boat place you're not afraid to get sick at. And, also nice to eat a big hunk of toro and not pay up the wazoo. Tea refills were plentiful. You really need to order with the sushi chef. We sat next to a regular and got the lay of the land down. Wish they had more rolls and a side salad option.
author: Andrew K.

description:
If you've got sensitive teeth, STAY AWAY! The fish is cold as ice here! 

Freshest sushi boat around with good mix of raw fish and rolls. I like it here enough but ouch, my teeth. The plates on the green sheet are hard to read. You would think they would have a little sign at each sushi boat spot instead. I can barely differentiate between plates. 

It's not that flavorful (nigiri or otherwise) but whatever, it's sushi boat.

C'monnn.
author: Margaret S.

description:
[M]ona: 3.5 Stars
[W]ayne: 3.5 Stars
Average: 3.5 Stars

+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ Big Portions
+ Decent Prices
+ Open Late

- Little Variety
- Hard to find parking

[W] So this sushi boat spot was located in the Castro district. Mona wanted to try this spot out since we always go to Sakana Bune in the Richmond District. When we first walked in, the restaurant look pretty busy. I'm not sure if this was only one of the few Japaneses spots here but people were definitely taking advantage of it. If I can recall, each plate ranged from $1.95 to $4.45 or so. I think that this place didn't have enough variety as I would have liked it to be. Especially for the price we were paying the 3 cooked could have put out more food and at a quicker pace too.

Throughout the whole time we were there, there were a lot of empty "boats". Me and Mona kept waiting for more food to come out the entire time we were there. One thing that kind of bugged me was that the boats were going around a moat that was pretty much eye level. It was a little annoying to me because I'm just use to the boats being below eye level so you can see what is going around instead of sitting a little closer just to reach for the food. The only thing is if you LOVE California rolls http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ?select=Roa_5kKxObeQAYNkZAJ_tA, then this is the place to be because it seemed like that was the only thing that was coming out.

We were tired of seeing the same rolls come out so I just had to ask for a menu and ordered separately. We ended up getting the California Hand Roll http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ?select=vzi6Xyg6_9tO1aHGcbybxQ as well as the Kani Salad Roll (crab salad) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ?select=-xlG78iL80Pv2ae_XMF5xQ. There WERE some good rolls from the boats. I enjoyed the Tamago http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OZAZSQnvAGeETvoKRSEbuQ?select=ghvZ5Q4L1gtRDx3usFnNzA which tasted a lot fresher that the ones at Sakana Bune. The Kani Salad Roll was tasty as well. The other thing about this place is that they make their rolls very "tall". Meaning they pack a LOT of rice. I guess that makes sense because nobody wants to pay almost $4 for a plate and not get a lot of food.

Anyways, parking here was a little more difficult this time. We had to circle around a couple of times and ended up a block away right in from of the Mission Delores Church/Missionary. Overall for the price we paid, I would suggest going to Isobune in the Japantown mall instead. I think they have a lot better selection and their food tastes better as well.
author: Mona C.

description:
I havnt been to a sushi boat restaurant in a long time but lately my girlfriend has been hankering for some. So, she investigated some places and found this one. Now when we first tried to go the place was closed so we had to return another night. 

We went on a Saturday night and the sushi looked like it was going fast and being made just as fast. Semi-worried I ordered tempura thinking that it would be an easy out if the sushi wasnt good. Well it looks like I was the loser in that situation because I soon realized that the sushi was AMAZING. Spicy tuna? I burned my tongue on it, it was so spicy.... and that's just what I like.

The atmosphere was mellow, the bar in which you sit at gives you an opportunity to talk to you neighbors about their sushi choices as well as egg them on the take the sushi they want. 

There was one piece of sushi though... that haunted me the entire time I was there. It was two pieces of Nigiri with succulent crab legs. Every time it would pass I craned my neck to follow the pieces but thought that it just wouldnt be that great. Well people started to leave and so the sushi options got slimmer and slimmer and finally I gave into my primal urges and grabbed the sushi. Thinking that it may have been dry or gross since it had been going around the on boats for so long... i hesitantly bit into the crab. I was delighted to find some of the sweetest juiciest crab I've encounter, and did not expect at a sushi place.

Overall good experience. Shitty salad dressing, but that wouldnt mess up its stars.
author: Amy M.

description: Fun place. It's tiny but really relaxing just staring at the boats of sushi going by. I honestly wouldn't mind going alone (better with a date though).
author: Matt D.

description:
I have literally just come from this place and Oh My God!!!!!!! I have never had food so fresh and amazing in my life. I had spicy tuna roll which was actually spicy. I had a tempura prawn and avocado roll which was one of the most tasty things i have ever eaten. Had a scallop sushi also. 

If you are in San Francisco or even near it.. make your way to 307 church street and pull up a chair!
author: Julie G.

description:
Just got home from dinner at Warakubune and it was total disaster. Wanted to try this place for some time now. So we decied to try it tonight beucase today is my daughter's 5th birthday and she requested "sushi boat". 

We were a party of 5. As soon as we walked in there were 4 avaliable seats at the sushi bar/boat bar. So the waiter added another chair. Meanwhile there was a purse sitting on an empty chair that belongs to a woman sitting next to it but she was done eating and is paying. No biggy, we are pretty patient. 5 minutes goes by and the woman is still seated and her purse is still on the empty chair, so I decided I ask the waiter to please let the woman know that my husband will be sitting there and if she can please move her purse. As the waiter was approaching the woman, the man (owner/sushi maker) behind the sushi boats stopped him and said "don't listen to her" in cantonese. He must not know that I speak cantonese and knew what he was saying. After I heard what he said it really pissed me off. I wanted to leave then and there but my kids got to the sushi already. My husband decided to ask another waitress and she was able to ask the woman to move her purse.

 I had to ignore what I had just heard from the owner and just sit and eat because  I didn't want to ruin my little girl's birthday dinner.  I daughter wanted a spider roll so we ordered her one. At the end of dinner spider roll was nowhere to be found and turns out the waitress forgot to put in the order. Ok fine we'll just cancel it.

Dinner was done and now time for cake! I specifically "boxed" 5 candles along with the cake. They brought out the cake along with 4 candles on it. If they looked at the cake it said "Happy 5th birthday Melanie"! How and why didn't they put 5the candle? Ok 4 candles... fine. We started singing happy birthday and so did the waitress. But here's the craziest part the waitress sang "happy birthday to Camrin, happy birthday to you" Um.....my daughter is named Melanie not Camrin...wth...? 

My husband paid the bill not sure how much tips he gave them but if it was up to me they would have got NOTHING and we are fellow restaurant owners.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Small, compact, crowded, uncomfortable... I just didn't like it. If I had more room to eat and move my arms, I think I would have enjoyed my time better here at Warakubune.

My co-workers at Barracuda love this place, but it was just a-okay for me. They offer a sushi boat service with limited items that come around. It's stocked fast and full, so you'll always get what you want. And if it's not on the Sushi Boat, you can definitely order it from any service staff. 

Must try:
Fried Shrimp Balls
Special Roll
Seared Albacore Tune with Spicy Mayo
Ama Ebi (the heads were puny though)

Stay away:
Tako, anything tako. Their octopus is just chewy as can be.
Sake (not salmon, but the alcohol); it's not that great

They have Nigori! Treat yourself to some!

Oh, if you want edamame, make sure they know. We ordered some, but never got it.
author: Mike N.

description:
Definitely my favorite sushi place I have been to in SF.  Very reasonably priced, always fresh/high quality fish and a nice variety.  It's great sitting at the moat with the sushi dishes piled on top of the little boats as they pass by. Parking is the worst part of the experience since you are in the heart of the Castro, but don't let that stop you.  

I'm good for at least 1 visit a month!

Here are my favorite dishes.
- Tataki
- Albacore
- Saba
- Spicy White Tuna

If you don't recognize them on the boats as they pass by, just ask the Sushi Chef and they will prepare it for you.
author: Cameron F.

description:
The sushi here is OK, but there are a lot of better options  in the city. Probably pretty good for a sushi boat, but keep in mind, if you're going to eat at a sushi boat place, it's probably not the best. The price is a bit on the higher end compared to the quality.

Don't get the ramen either. While it wasn't bad, it wasn't very good either.  The broth and flavors were bland in comparison to other ramen broths, and this was more chicken boullon based as opposed to pork bone/dashi based in flavor
author: Marc T.

description: Great service!! The food was amazing. I suggest the tempura, tempura shrimp sushi roll, and the ramen.
author: Julia D.

description:
The service was ok and the sushi was good but not great. The waiters either don't understand you or choose to ignore your requests. For instance, I ordered edamame as an appetizer. It was not brought out until after my meal even though I asked twice for this. Both times I was told "okay".

The selection of rolls limited, as in there are maybe 5 different rolls on the menu. It is also too expensive for what you get in food, service, and atmosphere.
author: Eric S.

description:
Warakubune used to be one of my favorite sushi restaurants even though parking is a b****. However our last time here proved otherwise.

What sucks is when you raved about a restaurant to a friend, they show up and the service is a complete disappointment.

- Prices increased a fair amount.

I was eager to try the spicy sashimi salad but noticed it was increased to $24.95. How did it increase $10?!

Spicy White Tuna increased by $4. Presentation was less appetizing. It looked like the tuna were all pushed to the one side and sauce was not spicy at all.


- Service? How did they receive 4 stars with the service we received?

The waiter (tall, skinny, Chinese guy with glasses) needs to speak louder. All of us had trouble hearing him and asked him to repeat things again and again.

My friend ordered the 10 piece assorted sashimi. They ran out of two type of sashimi (salmon and something else) and the sushi chef would not substitute. First time I heard of this. What happened to keeping the customers happy? 

After being denied the 10 piece sashimi, my friend tried to ordered other sushi but they basically ran out of everything. Half of the menu was off limits. Again - what happened to keeping the customer happy? How can you not be prepared for the weekend?

Apparently asking the waiter to tell the sushi chef to make nigiri without wasabi was too much trouble. When the waiter came back and told us the sushi chef denied the request, my friend sent him back to tell the chef that she CANNOT eat wasabi, he acted like it was too much trouble. 

Our group had the check split. My friend, who ordered from the sushi boat area, had an extra item added. Be sure to go over your bill and make sure they calculated it correctly.

After the huge increase in price and huge disappointment in service, I'm not sure if I'll come back here again - not even my most favorite dish - Spicy White Tuna.
author: Joanna W.

description: The beeeest sushi, I live in Daly City and I will in this place at least 2 times a month, my favorite sushi is shimp special, the owner is always very polite.
author: Marcia M.

description: The service here has gone down hill. Called tonight at a quarter till asking if I could pick up, and I was told they were closed. I could literally walk outside and order and can see they are open. Besides this point, which I will give them the benefit of the doubt, they keep raising prices. $30 for spicy seafood salad? It used to be $20. I won't be back and am a longtime neighbor.
author: Andrew M.

description:
If you ever feel like you want to hunt your food, you should probably come here. Yes, there are boats that float around the sushi bar, and yes you can grab whatever you want. But what happens if you, like me, are seated on the far end of the sushi bar and everyone else takes what you want before it comes around?? Basically it goes like this. "Oh what is he making in there? It looks so good" "I want that when it comes around." 20 minutes later it still hasn't gotten to you so you pick one of the unappealing plates that has been circling the moat for hours. And you know what? It still tastes good. but what tastes even better is the good stuff, so try and sit near the sushi door where they put the food on the boats. Then you won't feel so much like a vulture.

On another note, be careful how many plates you grab here, the price racks up quickly and it is pretty much impossible to check the bill to be sure it is correct.

All that being said, I love this place and the whole experience. I am pretty darn excited that it is 20 feet from my boyfriend's door!
author: Caitlin H.

description:
It was late and my friend and I were just looking for any spot still open to get some grub. Thankfully this sushi joint was still open around his area. Upon entering this place, we had no idea it was a sushi boat style restaurant. There were about 6 couples waiting ahead of us in line, so we decided to put on our name on the dry erase board! and checkout another sushi restaurant in the area that was also open. We eventually ended up coming back here. The dry erase board should be a dead give away for divey food ahead!

The waiter had no clue who was next in line because there was really no order to the dry erase board, and the waiter was not managing it anyway. But thankfully people abide by the honor system here and knew who was ahead of who in line. Eventually, my friend and I were seated on the right hand side away from the door in the sushi boat arena. I have to say, that this could possibly be the worst place to be sat. You will always get the last dibs on all the stuff that is created, so try to be seated on the left side, the side closest to the door. 

If you've never done sushi boat before, it's not hard, you just pull sushi off of a boat tray. haha. the sushi pieces are on smaller trays that are marked by a design and correspond to a price. my friend really does not like sushi boats for one big reason, these pieces of sushi are floating around for some time so they are not fresh, and you don't know if someone from across the way has picked it up, sneezed on it, and then decided oh no wait i don't want it and then puts it back. It could and probably does happen!

I had about 7 trays of sushi, but they were not exactly what I wanted. There were some very good pieces of Salmon nigiri. The pieces were very thick. Also of note, the Wasabi that they use here, is extra potent so be careful! For the 7 trays it came out to 23 dollars. I was full and content so i thought it was very reasonable, but I have had better sushi boat experiences.... that were in Japan!
author: Michael C.

description:
My past experiences with sushi boat places in San Francisco have been meh sushi that doesn't hold up very long and are way overpriced. However, Warakubune seems to be a nice exception! 
We decided to get there when they opened, owing to the reviews that mention how crowed it can get later. (Like clock work, around 7 or so, it was starting to get crowed) The waiters were hyper attentive, bordering on the edge of ridiculous, which I never thought I'd complain about! 

Selection: 
Pretty solid! In the beginning, the sushi chefs started making the cheaper plates of california rolls (~$1.95) and then moved on to more expensive ones, like the super delicious but also super stomach-filling roll with shrimp tempura and avocado on top (I think it was a $3.95-4 plate). They also made sushi on request, but we stuck to the floating boats. Between the two of us each having about ten plates in total, one large beer and a small cold sake, it came to ~$50 with tip. Not bad for a sushi bar in a nicer spot like the castro. 

Ultimately, it's all about strategy if you want to get the rolls you want, because by the time it started filling up, we couldn't get our hands on any newer rolls. Which was fine, because it gave us time to enjoy some sake and listen to their techno soundtrack. 

My only complaint is that I wish the waiters wouldn't stand right behind me waiting for my tea cup to be empty. But, like I said, if I have to complain about that, it was a pretty solid time!
author: Dena R.

description:
We've been there 5+ times, so this is the summary of our experience.

Positives:
- It's cheap
- Boats with sushi plates float in front of you
- Would be fast if you just eat from the pre-made boats

Negatives:
- Indifferent service
- Incompetent service
- Attitude
- Cleanliness so so
- Bathroom fixtures broken
- Things off the menu (not on the boats) are slow
- sushi chef grumpy and you have to sit in front of him for your visit...

on our last trip, I asked for water 3 times from two different service people. The spider roll was at least 15 minutes in arriving, but was good. The bill took too long and in general, the service personnel just weren't available much even though the place was half empty (that's why they got a $1.75 tip).

The quality of the sushi is low.  It falls apart easily which speaks to the chef, and the fish is dry-ish, which speaks to the freshness.

I would never go to this place again, except my 6 year old loves those damn boats!  I need to find another sushi place with boats :-(
author: John A.

description: I love this place. I have been to many other sushi restaurants but none compare. I live far from here but make the drive just to fill my sushi cravings.
author: SOPHIA C.

description:
Place was okaay.
Sashimi (15 piece) was okay.  The salmon was pretty fresh, as were SOME of the white fishes.  The others weren't the freshest, and some were cut into weird smallish shapes.  For example the tuna and another white fish was cut into small cubes that counted as 3 pieces, but any other place that would be 1.5-2 pieces at most.  Wtf.  Basically, not as many pieces as you might think.  Also served with a couple cherry tomatoes (wtf? okay sure)

Yakitori was a bit mediocre.  At least the chicken wasn't dry.  The teriyakiish sauce was way sweet for me.

Friend got the pork katsu curry and said it was okaay as well.

Tea seemed to be very diluted genmaicha.

Waiter put those towelettes down for us to use, but when another girl came to take our order she removed them immediately without asking (wtf?? they weren't even opened yet).  I mean, I like to use them before I eat or at least while I'm waiting for food, not when I'm deciding what to order.  That was weird.

Overall probably good if you like the whole sushi boat thing.  We just sat in the back.  Probably not worth the price.
author: Xue H.

description: Best Revolving Sushi experience in SF! You have to do the revolving sushi or you won't have the experience. Wait can get hard and parking can be difficult but its worth it. The slices are huge and the price makes sense for it.  YOU MUST GO HERE FOR SUSHI if you want the best Revolving boat water conveyance of your SF trip! ahha....
author: Geoffrey O.

description:
Wow, I am reading the reviews here and either I got totally different food and service than some or my standards are low.  I think it may be neither and some people just don't have a clue what they are eating.

Service was great, price was great, quality of the fish was great, and we had no issues with items staying out too long and even witnessed the chef grab a few items and throw them away.  Saw the chef make and put out several fresh items including a scallop nigiri which was amaze balls.  Easily the best single piece of sushi I have had in a while.

Is it as good as the best places in the city? NO.  Is it as good as Yume in Alameda, definitely no.  Was it excellent for the price?  YES.  Did I enjoy the food?  YES.

We had a group of around 12 and even though we took up half of the restaurant they were able to seat us pretty quickly.  2 other groups of people were leaving as we were coming in.  We had been out drinking and really pigged out and the bill came to just a bit over $300.  I have spent that with one other person on sushi before.

The waiter was extremely accommodating.  One of the people in our party asked for a specific roll and the chef made it for him.  The waitress, Sandy, was extremely nice and brought everything we asked, Sake, gyoza, edemame, etc and served us quickly and efficiently.

I had the following I can remember Philadelphia roll (OK), Spicy Tuna Roll (Pretty Good), scallop nigiri (excellent, perfect balance of sweetness and the kick from the wasabi with some lemon), Dragon Roll (probably the best dragon I have had, really freshly fried shrimp, sweet and spicy, yum), a couple of the maki rolls with salmon and tuna, maguro nigiri, fried rice inari and one or two others.  We also had 4 orders of gyoza, 2 orders of edemame, and 4 bottles of sake for the table and most people ate as much or more than I did.  Personally I think for a sushi boat place that gave reasonable food at a good price it was excellent.

You have to rate places based off of what they do.  You can't compare Farolito to the French Laundry.  Both are great at what they do, but if you rate a burrito off of the merits of french high cuisine you have a screw loose.
author: Chris L.

description:
Nothing remarkable, but a pretty solid sushi place. Good fish-to-rice ratio.

And the spicy unagi wrap was good.

As with any sushi boat place, just be wary of the plates that you've seen float around a few times.

Service was a little haphazard.

Oh, and their "draft" beer wasn't draft beer. It was just bottled Sapporo beer "imported" from Canada.
author: Glendon M.

description:
I have been a patron here for almost 8 years and Tiffany and Henry always greet me and my friends by our names and always knows exactly what we want... awesome service although it gets quite packed on the weekends... DEFINITELY worth the wait...

For you virgins out there, try their Special Roll...

And for you sushi fanatics like me... order the Spicy Seafood Salad or the Butterfish if they have it... come on Wednesday if you don't like crowds...
author: Nathan D.

description:
I was skeptical when my friend wanted to eat at a sushi boat place. In my past experience, sushi boat places tend to have unfresh fish, unexciting rolls and the most basic of nigiri. But Warakubune was a pleasant surprise. The fish was fresh and they had some interesting things I have never seen at a sushi place before... conch, taro fries, and some interesting-looking rolls. Here are some of the things we had:

Oysters - delicious and fresh
Seaweed salad - yummy and good way to satiate your appetite while waiting for your custom ordered rolls
Spider Roll - good but the one they made for us was poorly constructed (it was made too fat so the nori roll didn't quite overlap enough to stay together)
Nigiri - all the pieces we had featured super fresh, pristine-looking pieces of fish. 

I would definitely come here again but next time I think I'm going to make sure we have a snack first. Since the wait for some of the things we custom ordered took awhile.
author: Dani D.

description:
I've been twice now and look forward to more.  I don't usually fancy sushi - really have to find myself in the mood - but my boyfriend loves it.  Warakubune seems to be the perfect marriage of our tastes, with tasty, affordable sushi and delicious alternatives.  I've gotten a chicken dish and the spicy soup (I wanted the spicy ramen but they were out when I went).  The chicken dish was fine, nothing great, but that spicy soup is one of the tastiest dishes I've ever eaten.  I get cravings for that stuff.  I highly recommend you try it, or drag your friends along who, like me, aren't huge on sushi but like other Japanese foods.

I will say that I wanted to try their California rolls, which are bargain priced and made with real crab.  I usually don't like California rolls too much, but the allure of real crab at for the price was irresistible, and I was handsomely rewarded.  This was easily the best a California roll has tasted to me, made much the better by the low low cost.  Sushi aficionados may disagree with my assessment, but for my tastes, the California roll at Warakubune is a must-add item.

My one gripe with the place is that the service is a little weak.  I've never been totally ignored or forgotten like some people seem to have been, but there could definitely have been more attention paid.  That said, the staff was also able to seat me quickly when I went both times, each time in a group of no less than six.  They had no qualms about pulling some tables together to find us a place, and I really appreciate that.  The rest of the service felt a little sparse, but not enough to truly put a damper on the rest of the experience.

The decor is lovely and exciting, and they've got sushi boats - how fun!  I've never tried the sushi boat experience, and may have too much of a craving for the soup to ever truly give in to it, but I look forward to sitting at the bar and snatching some sushi as it sails by the next time I visit.
author: Blake D.

description:
I really really REALLY wanted to love this place.  Before our recent weekend trip to SF, I researched "the best" sushi places and we settled on Warakubune.  I have to admit, we were a little disappointed.

First, I need to say, the fish was good enough.  It was fresh, and cold, and the portions were generous.  But, for sushi, it was also a little messy.  The chefs seemed to be in a huge hurry, just slamming the food out fast-food style and getting it onto the boats.  The prices also seemed all over the place.  There are 4-5 color-coded plates (priced from $1.95 to $3.95) but we never saw a $1.95 plate go around and the $3.95 plates were quite common.  We did enjoy the much recommended asparagus roll, but everything else was just...meh.

Maybe I'm a little spoiled living in the Pacific Northwest, with amazing sushi practically at my doorstep.  To me, Warakubune was ok, but the fish was not amazing and the presentation was harried.  It also bugged me that they didn't seem to be keeping a close eye on the length of time their raw dishes were sitting on the boats.  For example, there were raw oysters on the boats when we arrived, and the same oysters were still going around the moat when we left nearly an hour later.  Ewwwww.

In all we spent a little over $30 not including drinks.  I'm still looking for SF's best sushi, if anybody has any ideas for my next trip!
author: Jennifer J.

description: When I went to college in SF my friends and I fell in love with this place and its food and friendly staff. We'd seriously frequent the restaurant 1-2 times a week (sometimes ditching class for sushi instead)! Now it's been 10 years since we discovered this gem and we still make an annual trip up north and make sure we stop in for our favorite sushi joint ever. Our favorites include the Special roll, salmon sushi, spicy white tuna,  fried shrimp balls w spicy mustard, the spicy octopus cucumber salad, and I even like their California rolls too! They are generous in portions and the sushi is soooooo fresh and cold and melts in your mouth!
author: Jessica S.

description:
This review is for dining at the boat sushi area of Warakubune.

I have been here several times and I keep coming back because I really get a kick out of snatching little dishes off of the moving little boats. It makes dinner a  bit more interesting.

When you dine around the boats you can also order off of the menu to round out your meal. I would recommend Warakubune for a date or other paired outing. It can difficult to be seated for a group that is larger and having a conversation with anyone but the person next to you is kind of impossible.

This really isn't the place for a sushi purist.   Sushi on the boats are often covered with a spicy or creamy sauce. If you like crunchy rolls with tempura or avocado you will be happy here. There are several vegetarian roll options on the menu and on the boats along with seaweed salad and inari.

I would rate service as pretty poor because it is difficult to get a waiter's attention and they weren't refilling green tea or refreshing ginger and wasabi promptly.

I think the sushi is a little over priced for the quality of rolls you are getting but is pretty average for a casual sushi dinner in San Francisco. It is kind of hard to tell how much your bill will be because you eat things spur of the moment but the place mat key can help you guesstimate your bill.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
Got here on a Sunday night and it was pretty packed. 
My friends were here already so i didn't have to wait.

Overall the sushi is just ok but the servers are on top of their game and not overly annoying trying to upsell you.

And the music they play here was awesome reminded me of 1015 in 2010

I probably wouldn't be back here unless I was in the neighborhood but definitely a good experience.
author: DOM d.

description:
This is the best sushi place in San Francisco!  The salmon is so fresh you'd think you just stole it from a bear.  The food is always fresh and served promptly.  The wait staff is very good and the Sushi chef is spectacular.  I have been to Ozumo and other sushi places that charge way too much and for what Warakubune serves up better!

Highly, highly recommend this restaurant.  Come early, parking can be troublesome.
author: Jerry H.

description: I am so happy my friend recommended this place.  This is the best sushi restaurant in SF!  Sushi is always fresh and the staff is very friendly and always asking if we are happy or not.  I've been here several times now, and they embarrassingly remember me and know exactly what I want to order.  Parking is a little difficult in the area but not too bad.  You can easily head to PIE right across the street after or Bi-rite for dessert.  The wait can be long but worth it!
author: Alister L.

description: I love this place! My family and I have been coming and coming back to this place since they opened 18 years ago! It's wonderful to come sit at the bar and take your pick from the sushi boats, or to experience more of an intimate setting at a table behind the screen. Always check on the specials as this place has much to offer- and don't forget you're never limited to what's on the boats when you sit at the bar- ask for a menu and enjoy!!
author: Alicia J.

description:
***Good***
Great sushi, top quality, solid diversity. This is likely the best sushi boat in town. 

***Bad***
Tiny place, expect a wait. 

***Recommendation***
Do the boat! Also, someone got this giant bowl with tons of fish in it; looked delish. Go during off-hours.
author: Nick K.

description:
You walk in and see the sushi bar - an oval shaped donut with seats around it and a sushi chef in the middle making magic.  Take a seat to begin your sushi-eating experience.   Floating in front of you in water are actual boats with small rectangular plates of sushi.  Something catch your eye? Take it. The chef keeps making rolls and placing them out on the float; you keep grabbing what looks appetizing - and the cycle continues. It's too easy. 

Favorites included the spicy white tuna roll encrusted with sesame seeds and with ginger and green onions on top.  They have a delicious oyster plate that comes with sriracha, lemon, and green onions.  Also, their hot sake was full of flavor and they provide complimentary green tea - not particularly nutty but still tasty, hot, and aplenty.

When you start to slow down and are no longer eating because you're hungry but instead grabbing a 14th plate because it just looks so good and you don't want to watch it go by, it's a sign you should flag down a waiter.  They'll count the number of plates in front of you to determine how much to charge.  Each dish costs somewhere between $2 and $4.5.  The two of us spent $60 before tip and that included a small and large sake.  We left very full. 

Potential con of the experience: it can be hard to know what you are eating.  The dishes aren't labeled and you'll find yourself choosing food based on appearance.  If you're picky, it will take guesswork and an ability to recognize different types of fish to know what you are getting - but I actually enjoyed the element of surprise and was never disappointed by any of our choices. 

Overall, this was a wonderful first sushi boat experience.  While the fish quality was not as good as Sushi Zone down the street (beating Sushi Zone would not have been an easy feat), Warakubune's offerings were delicious and the atmosphere warm and lively;  I definitely look forward to returning.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Whenever I am in San Francisco I come here for dinner.  Sitting at the bar, grabbing delicious sushi as it floats by really is the best.  Inexpensive but very fresh and flavorful.

If there's something that you want but people take it before it gets to you, just ask the sushi chef and they'll make on for you.

There are enough great votes for this place that you should know you should go.
author: MIke P.

description: They barely had any sushi on the boats or much variety. I was pretty disappointed. I think I sat there for 30 minutes just waiting for more sushi. More than half the boats were empty the whole time. I'd suggest hiring more sushi chefs.
author: Diana B.

description:
This place def. deserves a 5 star rating based on the quality of their fish alone. I've never understood the term of "melts in your mouth" when it comes to sushi until now. (: The fish was so smooth that I barely had to chew! 

The restaurant also deserves a five star rating. Inside the restaurant it has a long huge oval surrounded of sushi boats floating down the stream, the tables, and our chairs. If you look around there are different kinds of huge fishies hanging on the wall haha. I thought it was cheesy but cute. (; 

We first walked in and there was these drapes that covered the entrance so I got a bit confused, lol and when you open the door there is this Japanese little girl recording  that greets you. After we passed all of  that, they gave us seats right away! The paper mats had the prices listed for each of the trays so it was easy to tell how much everything was.

I like how everyone of the workers were able to help out or take our orders, including the chef! If I wanted to order a roll, I sear I asked like 4 diff. people and I still got my food fast! If I needed more napkins, tea, water, or to see the menu, there was a waiter just nearby so I give them a 5 stars for service. : )

I love the variety that they have here. Lots of salmon, lots of hamachi, and lots of saucy type of rolls. ..mMmMM! All my fav. type of sushis! This place has become my new sushi boat spot to go to, but it is a bit pricey. =X 

1.95-4.95 trays i think?
author: April D.

description: Honestly, don't arrive at 5:30 when the restaurant opens. The sushi boats will be running, but the interesting and creative plates come out as the evening progresses. This sushi bar also becomes busier as the evening progresses, so be prepared to wait. This is a small restaurant and the seating allows enough personal space. The raw tuna is real tuna and fresh.  The sushi is rolled tight, but not firm.  They offer a variety of interesting sushi to choose from.  The wait staff is attentive and offer many cups of tea. The wasabi and pickled ginger comes you in your own dish, which is a lot cleaner and sanitary.  The crispy pork Katsu dinner is generous and filling.  The salad greens are a good compliment along with the plain white, fluffy rice.  If you want top quality sushi made by a master chef, this sushi bar ranks high.  The sushi transported little boats also add an interesting conversation to the mix.
author: K C.

description:
The sushi was Divine!!!!!!
We had Uni, Saba, unagi, albacore (white tuna), tuna belly, tobiko, and green tea!
We love how fresh every fish was and how neatly it was prepared.
Hot green tea was excellent!!
We love the service and how nice the waiters were!
We arrived at 5:35 right when they opened and the boats only served California rolls  but when more people came cooler sushi would come.
author: Jane D.

description:
I have a dangerous shellfish allergy that is only ironically paired with my love of fish. When I go to serve yourself kind of places, I'm a little embarrassed when I have to ask "does this have shellfish in it?" 50 hundred times; I'm especially nervous when the person I'm asking doesn't confidently show that they know what I've asked (or disappointed if they only hear the word "fish" and I'm forever excluded from all other eats from the ocean. So, I'm always happy, excited and relieved when someone on the wait staff is able and willing to help me out in the "what seafood i can partake in and what could kill me" game. this was such a place and besides this one specific particular i have, they were genuinely sweet and attentive.

i had a couple of varieties of sushi off the boats: plum, salmon nigiri, tuna nigiri, some kind of spicy seared tuna dish and salmon maki. the tuna plates were my favorites. my date also tried some crab sushi and i heard that was pretty good.

the space is small, but the service is quick. it's on a train line, so parking is non existing.... but it's on a train line. i will definitely be back for more - i hear there are many kinds of sushi if you stay long enough and see the food rotate (which we sort of did as we were leaving).
author: Kariz M.

description:
Warakubune delivers the golden promise for all avid sushi goers who wish to stretch a dollar. WIth that being said, for those who might accidentally get "too excited" should choose another restaurant due to the following reasons:

1. inexpensive GOOD quality sushi
2. extensive variety of traditional and fusion-y sushi
3. cheap alcohol
4. great service

Yes, it all sound too good to be true but as I mentioned before, there is a catch. Stay away if your the type with tendencies to max out your credit card at those annual sales in your local department stores. Warakubune is sneaky since everyday is equivalent to a sales day.
author: emily g.

description:
Never would've guessed. Its like a hole in the wall place. 

I freakin' love the ambiance of the place. The idea of just sitting around a table where a boat floats with your food on it...welcome to grab anything. They charge you by the color of your plates but its pretty self explanatory since every table sitting as instructions. Staff was quiet attentative as well. 

Better get their early tho... they have a long wait. We got there at 5:30 and we were good. Around 6:30-7 it started to get super packed.
author: Nathalie N.

description: Wonderful sushi. Fresh and delicious. Try the hamachi, maguro and salmon. They also have some specials and things which are not on the menu. Ask. Loses a star for servers who completely ignore you unless you yell at them as they are running past you.
author: Jason B.

description:
Oh my gosh....I don't usually write bad reviews because I feel bad, but my experience here was just so ridiculous. First I'll start with the good: the food is decent. I have no complaints about the food; I ordered the katsu dinner, and it was good. Nothing special, but nothing terrible either.

The thing that made this dinner so unpleasant was the service. We didn't order anything too complicated....so I have no idea why the server got so much wrong. My friend wanted the spicy udon, but somehow got regular udon with tempura on the side. My sister ordered a spicy tuna handroll, which they COMPLETELY forgot about until we reminded them at the end of the dinner, and then they said we never ordered it. All throughout the dinner, the servers NEVER came over to refill our tea OR water, so we were parched the entire dinner. Then, when the bill came, we realized that they charged us for miso soup that we didn't order....they just brought us the miso soup and we thought it came with our entrees, so we drank it, not realizing it cost extra. 

And it wasn't just our table; they kept making mistakes at the table next to us too. During the hour or hour and a half we were eating there, I noticed that they brought the next table food they didn't order, forgot 2 orders, and never refilled their tea or water either. 

By the end of the dinner, the service was so terrible that it was starting to become comical how much they were messing up. Needless to say, I am not going back.
author: Kortney E.

description:
Like any revolving boat place, theres normally little service since you just sit and pull whatever you see floating past. Each differing colored plate comes with its own price...  your bill can add up quick with all that food just placed before your eyes, but ultimately its a pretty good deal for all that nomming! 

However, for a revolving sushi boats joint, this place is great! Warakubune is probably the best revolving boat sushi joint I've come across, and a more than decent sushi establishment. The service is great; your water/tea is alway full and they always check up on you. The sushi is actually of GREAT QUALITY. They have everything from creative fusion rolls to your authentic nigiri/sashimi, plus theres also udon and ramen too. Definitely a great place to go to to get your sushi fix, or even to take a fun date. Its kinda small and has a very intimate feel. They've got a few sit-down tables too if you're not into the whole revolving sushi boats thing.
author: Lana N.

description: The fish is fresh enough for sushi, but they don't have a lot of variety. We sat there for an hour and waiting for sushi to be put in the boat. Eventually, we only picked 8 plates of sushi that interested us to eat. Service is attentive.
author: J L.

description:
I have eaten here probably a dozen or more times. The boats are cool, the wait staff always around -- at least by the sushi bar. I have never eaten at the tables. I have no idea what other reviewers are complaining about. The service is fine. 

The sushi always has generous portions of fish. It is attractively priced and fresh. This is not ultimate gourmet pure Japanese traditional sushi, this is more California sushi, but given that, the food is well done, and very reasonable. 

The fellow patrons at the bar tend to be very friendly and I have on many occasions struck up a conversation with them. As far as I am concerned, it is the best sushi in the area, with the exception of maybe Sushi Zone which I think is just amazing.
author: Will G.

description:
If you've never had a sushi boat experience, your face will light up as you walk into Warakubune . A trough with cute floating sushi boats separate the diners from the two chefs confined inside the oblong-shaped bar, rolling out nigiri sushi and maki rolls onto the boats. As you wait to be seated at the bar of this somewhat popular establishment, you'll start eyeing the sushi atop the boats and possibly drool a little.  Let's face it, any food on tiny little boats that go round and round is nothing short than adorable.

The excitement builds up, but as soon as you're seated at the bar you'll discover how lackluster the selections are. Tofu products, maimed cuts and who knows what under some drippy sauce are what you can expect to get at Warakabune. Sure you can special order from the menu, but that would defeat the mission of sushi boating. It's amazing how cute little boats dress up Warakabune's mediocre sushi, kind of like what a great pair of jeans would do to one's otherwise flabby ass.

Warakabune is not for the sushi purists. It is however, cheap. Yelp further and you'll find a much better budget sushi just around the block.
author: Rina W.

description:
omg. for the price. NOT WORTH IT AT ALL. i guess someone did mention that it IS easy to spend a lot (and very quickly, i might add) especially since the portions r sooooo small.... -_- but i mean. its a freakkknnnnn sushi boat place. they have a paper at each place setting that tells u the prices (in black and white) The plates that they have floating are different colors. so u cant tell WTF is what. which really sucks. (this means u have no idea wtf ur buying, and theres almost no way of gaging how much ur spending unless u ask every time u pick something up. STUPID)

let me say this, nothing was BAD. (nothing was amazing either though.)

all in all, i dont mind going to a real sushi spot and spending a hundred bux, i mean, its sushi, what do u expect. but believe me, i did NOT expect to come here and spend a hundred bux for 2 ppl. 

i was under the impression that this was the cheaper alternative to doing sushi, but i guess i was wrong. i wouldnt say dont everrrrrr go here. but shit. go here if ur in the area and price is no issue. :)
author: Lisa N.

description: I love this place for it's spicy albacore. I grab that plate off the moat like there's no tomorrow. I come here every so often and enjoy how fresh the sushi is. Unfortunately, that one star is gone because the last time we were there, we were seated next to a couple that would not stop making out. That's great you're in love, and maybe I'm just not a PDA person, but some things don't need to be done (and overdone) in public. Maybe I should have asked my server to tell them to stop, but maybe management could have figured that out themselves when everyone else in the restaurant looked irritated. It's cramped up enough as is. Help me keep my food down, please.
author: Ang L.

description:
People have been telling me to come here for a bit. So I finally did. Ok so I saw the boat and was like woah this is not good. Get out now. But I gave it a chance. Honestly it's nothing special. I mean it's decently priced, and the portions are generous. The stuff on the boat just moves around for a while so I would recommend ordering from the menu. I didn't know this menu existed though at first since people just sort of whirled around me for while asking for water, drinks and then they just sort of rotated around the room. The chefs didn't seem to talkative but yeah they will give you a menu if you ask.

Since I am not much of a roll person, I ended up ordering the sashimi plate and was a little disappointed. Nothing really had any taste. There were big cuts, but everything tasted the same. Like yellowtail I love and I am sort of used to it having a tougher texture around the ends and really good flavor. I didn't get any of these qualities from the yellowtail I was served. The only thing that had much taste to it was the spicy white tuna.

Next time I come I would rather sit in the back where there is a little more seating space. And it also looks like they have ramen, so that is definitely on the agenda then too.
author: Greg G.

description: I see how they do this.  You unassumingly grab a plate of sushi as it floats by all cute and stuff.   You eat it...it tastes great...so you grab another.  After you do this a few times, your stack of plates grow bigger and bigger...and they you pay.  OMG how did I do this?!   $77!!  (ok, I ate a lot...)  but it was SO good!
author: Matt V.

description:
Maybe we went on an off night? Maybe we ordered/ selected wrong?

Didn't feel the variety on the boats was that great.  Ordered the curry roll off the menu which was good, although nothing too special. 

$4.25 for a small seaweed salad off the boat!

Overpriced and over rated.


Too many other  good places.  Keep looking
author: Bruce P.

description:
As I sit here drinking a beer, waiting for my friend to come by, ready to hop in the shower....
I'm updating this review....
BEFORE we head out to Warakubune.
Why? 
I KNOW its gonna be great!
I know I'm gonna see Tiffany.  I know I'm gonna see Henry.  I know I'm gonna see Ben.  They always provide exceptional service.
The fish is always consistently good.
Every time they are "out" of ikura, uni, shake... Chef Ben always manages to find some for us.  
The ikura and uni here are EXCEPTIONAL.
Of my 200 reviews, I've been to this spot more consistently than any other in my list...
To me, that means something.
See you guys soon....!
Kampai~!
author: Barry A.

description: My absolute all-time favorite sushi place ever. Delicious, fun, and cheaper than most.
author: Kate H.

description:
Anytime I feel like taking a cruise, I motorboat over to Warakubune to travel down my favorite tobiko river. 

Although there are tables in the back and the idea of being sat immediately versus waiting for a spot along the Ishikari is tempting, hold out as long as your grumbling stomach can handle. Put your name on the white board and take a seat. If you want to sit at a table and eat sushi, walk over to Sushi Zone.

When I'm hungry, I want to eat. I don't want idle chatter. I don't want waiting formalities: greetings, drink orders, "do you need some more time?," bread baskets with only two small pieces, appetizers and finally a meal. I want instant gratification and Warakubune does it so well. 

Some very tasty selections. Anything with the spicy red sauce is definitely spicy. The sweet egg on rice and wrapped in seaweed is delectable. Many of the rolls are good and there are some creative choices worth trying. Most come in pairs or triads, so grab a dish and try something you've never eaten before. 

Although sushi boat places can be dangerous for your wallet (oh, we grabbed 25 dishes? I didn't even notice), my bill for two people has never been more than $30-40 and I always leave quite full. Well, for at least an hour. By that time I'm home and at a hand's reach of my jar of peanut butter and endless bag of animal cookies.
author: Jared S.

description:
I'm a sucker for food that gets paraded in front of me, particularly if it's purty. Not making any claim that I know what I'm talking about, but the sushi is tasty here. Try to sit near where the two sushi chefs put down the rolls so you can snatch up anything tasty immediately. Sitting on the ends of the boat parade is bizarre since you only get the briefest moment to see and then to snatch. See, snatch, repeat.

Favorites: The "special" roll, the warm taro/shrimp roll, the salmon nigiri, the raw oysters, unagi handroll

Not so hot was the fact that we realized the California roll with a sprinkle of tobiko was two bucks more than the nude one. In general, slightly pricey, so keep an eye out for the dish colors.
author: Kevin L.

description:
If this was a review for only the quality of their fish - it'd be 5 stars. Incredibly fresh & literally melts in your mouth.
However, this is Yelp. And we all love to bitch. The way they choose to run this spot confuses me. We got there a couple minutes after it had opened. Nothing was put out yet, which is fine. So we wait...and waited...got some seaweed salad...and waited. Finally the waitress came over and demanded we order something since the chef wasn't going to put anything out since it wasn't crowded. What are we? Chop liver?
Reluctantly we ordered - what is the point of a sushi boat if you can't take the plates off and see all the fun stuff they got floating around!? 
By the time a couple more people had sat, they kept putting out the same three rolls. It just wasn't the experience I was looking for. Too bad because everything we had was so good! Go to Isobune in Japantown - so much variety and the boats stay full.
author: S. M.

description: The fish quality is A+++++! You never know what you get at a sushi boat place sometimes but at Warakabune you know you are getting the BEST! The tuna and salmon were delicious and so were the oysters! Beware: Oyster plates are about $5-10 EACH and you only get a couple of them. Also, towards the end there were about 7 boats that all had what LOOKED like salmon maki rolls but it was actually....wait for it... CARROTS. That cost about $6 for a plate or Sushi Carrots and it was not good at all. Next time, I'll stick my head closer to the boats and make SURE its not carrot sushi i'm getting. Warakabune... you tricksters.
author: Angela P.

description:
What a great find! Its hard to find a sushi boat place that's good.. Well we found one... I've lived in this hood for 6 yrs and I can't believe I've just discovered Warakubune.. The fish was incredibly fresh.. The assortment was abundant. The service is fantastic.. 

Try the octopus salad - delicious! The hamachi - so fresh... everything else - perfect.. 

This is my new fav!
author: Monica S.

description:
Some of my friends went the week before and said it was pretty good for a sushi boat place. So I decided to give this a try with Tracy and Weak Sauce Steven. It was already full at the bar area so there was a little wait but not so long. Got seated and waited for Steven to come. Tracy and I were starving and I literally wanted to grab everything in front of my eyes but I wanted to wait til Steven got here. Finally came and we started eating..

Plates ranged from$1.75-$3.65
There were plenty to choose from but it all looked the same and at times, there would be almost nothing going around and we would just sit there and wait. 

Some dishes I tried were the
Sake Maki (Salmon R oll) 
Hamachi Maki (Yellowtail roll)
Salmon Special (salmon, avocado, cucumber roll)
Spicy tuna over California roll with taro fries!
Sake (Salmon over rice)
Dragon Roll
Spicy Scallop Roll

Most of them were pretty fresh, especially the salmon ones. The spicy tuna over cali roll with taro fries is a must try. Really yummy but really spicy. Spicy Scallop roll is also a must try but you have to order that since I never saw it on the boats. Dragon roll was good since the shrimp tempura was freshly fried so many people were eying for that and snatch it when they can.
