As for me, I like getting the tail ends of it so when Steven decides to grab one for himself, I noticed it didn't have a tail on it and screamed to him to grab the one I was eying instead since it had a tail! So funny! People thought I was crazy!

Definitely a good spot to have a eating contest if you got the $$. I thought it was pretty pricey. 7 plates plus 3 order of small plates to go was $43 with tips.
author: Juliane N.

description: Melt in your mouth sushi. My fiance grew up down the street and whenever we visit SF we always go here. He's been coming here all of his life and I now love it too. The employees are so wonderful and friendly, and the service is impeccable. The tuna tataki is unreal and one of my favorite dishes ever. Love Warakubune!
author: Caroline D.

description:
Props to a great recommendation from several stellar yelpers...a group of us swung by Warakubune for some serious sushi consumption, post-Sangria overload. 

What a gem. Seriously, I know in the Midwest we are a little behind on the sushi front, so this place seriously rocked in my humble opinion. A little river with sushi boats floating around the sushi chefs? Brilliant. You can just grab whatever you want without waiting? Even better. 

Seriously, I want to open a sushi place in Chicago with a river and sushi boats JUST because this place was so sweet. 

Sigh, sushi full...the best full one can get. Great service, miso soup was great, everything was fast, courteous and fresh. Our discerning group was ultimately pleased, and a good time was had by all.
author: Colleen C.

description:
I love this place. It's best to come at around 6/7pm when it's busy for dinnertime because that's when they put out a better variety of sushi.
The pieces of sushi are always a good size and the rolls are always, always delicious. The plates are usually $3-$6, I think you can get a generic california roll for about $1.65, but those are gross. I usually spend about $20-$25 bucks, but it's so delicious and worth it.
One of my favorite things about this place is the endless hot green tea.
author: Lori C.

description:
I certainly couldn't get through a week in San Francisco without getting my sushi fix so I was extremely excited to set foot in Warakubune. Even having a full stomach from a wine and cheese party earlier in the night was going to stop me from some good sushi! 

When we first walked in I was in awe. The sushi bar has actual sushi boats going round and round...and you just grab sushi off the boats.  Oh wow! I quickly learned from my dinner companions that this is common for sushi restaurants in SF.  Why, oh why have they not brought this concept to Chicago?

Unfortunately, they didn't have room for my party of 10 around the sushi bar, but we quickly scored a large table in the back.  I was a little disappointed not to be sitting where I could grab sushi off the boats, but our waitress assured us that we could push our way through the people sitting at the sushi bar (sorry to all those peeps) and help ourselves- I love this place!

I quickly made my way through 4 small plates of sushi, a miso soup, and some edaname. It wasn't the best sushi I've had on the West Coast (I prefer Ryoko here in SF), but it still put a smile on my face.
author: Andrea R.

description:
The first time I went there I wasn't crazy about it but I decided to give it another chance since it's only a couple of blocks from where I live. It was much better this time around and I liked most everything I ordered: california roll, rock n' roll, spicy tuna. The only thing I was not crazy about was the shrimp gyoza.

The place is small and cute with a nice ambiance.
author: K C.

description:
Processed chicken used for the Teriyaki Chicken Donburi. Gross.

Two stars just because the service was good.
author: Greg K.

description:
The best deal in the house in the phenomenal sushimi salad.  Huge hunks of assorted  fresh fish in a bowl of yummy soy/sesame dressing and avacado slices.  Great deal at $20 and totally Atkins, South Beach diet friendly.  My advise is to split the salad and  grab a few boats as they float to carry you through your Sunday night.  Top off with a mongo sized Sapporo and you have yourself an affordable raw meal.  

As with everywhere else in this chilly city, I won't be taking off my jacket, but its worth it to go for a cruise at a Warakubune.
author: Nicole R.

description: This is my favorite sushi spot of all time. I almost don't want to review it because I don't want people rushing there and taking my seat, but I have to give credit to the chefs and wait staff. They make this place sooo flipping good, I'm there at least once a week to get my fix.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I walked to warakubune and I was hot because I was walking pretty far and fast.  then I opened the door to this place and it was really hot inside.  Ok, no air conditioning, that's for sure.  A little gnat or something kept buzzing at my nose and that was annoying, but you know, when there are a lot of fish around, like fish guts in the trash, then it is bound to happen.  

So this place has sushi boats.  A lot of California rolls.  A bad sign that the customers don't really like real nigiri sushi or raw fish for that matter.  So i got the sushi dinner special.  Some of the fish was really delicious.  The rice sucked, it didn't seem like proper sushi rice and when I dipped it into the soy sauce they just fell apart.  Also there was not enough rice being used.  Is rice really that expensive?  

The ebi I had was really lame and looked like it had been through hell, it was really chewy and rubbery, didn't seem fresh at all.  So I decided I would try their amaebi (raw ebi) nigiri sushi.  It was just fine, not the best I have had, but yummy.  Not as sweet or as large as some amaebi I have had at other restaurants.  

The chef asked me if I wanted the head of the shrimps fried so I said yes.  It took awhile but it was totally worth the wait.  They even brought me a little bowl of tempura dipping sauce to dip the shrimp heads in.  No way, I have never seen a place do that before, but I thought it was an awesome touch!  The heads of the amaebi were delicious, like shrimp flavored Pringles, lol.  

So in a nutshell, as far as sushi boat places go I prefer Isobune in SF's Japantown for a sushi boat type of place.  Sorry Warakubune.  I would go back there someday, but I even prefer Miyabi also on Church St. over this place.  

Staff was friendly, decor was fine (I like this fish on the wall).  They filled my water and tea promptly and I appreciate that a lot.   

One couple came in right before me and I think they were upset they didn't get menus or they didn't like the looks of what was on the sushi boat and they left without eating anything.  Then later six people came in to eat but not enough seats, so they had to wait.  Then a couple came in after them and they decided the place wasn't worth the wait and left.  Then after that a lot more people came in...busy place for a Wednesday night.  

So yeah, that's my review, it about says it all.  Prices were medium/low for s suhi place.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Fresh and delicious, and a fun way to introduce someone new to sushi.  Wait staff is very attentive and seats you quickly.  Only complaint is they serve more rolls than regular sushi.
author: Sam F.

description: Two stars for .....um, not bad service, but NO service!  I couldn't believe it.  We were seated right away and within a few minutes they brought us hot tea and water.  Not one single employee checked back on our table for at least 20 minutes.  My friend finally got up and grabbed a tray and went up to the sushi boat counter and grabbed us some food off of the sushi boat.  That is how we fed ourselves on our visit here.  We would have sat at the sushi bar, but it was full.  The sushi was pretty fresh and tasty - but the service???  What service.  Very disappointed.  We left with full stomachs (just two of us), only drank water & tea and did not leave a tip as it was not deserved.  The bill was only $31.  Oh yeah, and we had to get up and find someone to bring us the check so we could leave.  Unbelievable.
author: Julie H.

description:
I've only been to Warakubune Sushi a few times, and still can't pronounce it properly, but every time has been as good or better than the time before.

The boat style of receiving sushi is fantastic for those who want to try different sushi rolls without having to invest an entire dinner in an expensive piece of fish. Instead, try three pieces at a time.

One of the best parts of Warakubune is the layout. You sit in a large oval, boats carrying sushi rolls travel counter clockwise in front of you. Two sushi chefs stand in the middle making their selection of rolls or just about any roll a customer requests.

What I love about the layout is the community it builds. I love sushi but I am by no means an expert at what is what, but at Warakubune, it is inevitable that someone on my left or right is. Every time I have visited I have been given tips on the best rolls to pick up and even had a few customers make orders for me. You won't get that at a regular sushi restaurant.

I challenge you to go to Warakubune and not see a regular. The fact that regulars even exist showcase the restaurants quality fish, talents and customer service. 

So far I haven't had anything but wonderful experiences at Warakubune. The sushi is delicious, the chefs friendly, the staff is quick to refill a glass or pick up an order of miso soup or vegetable tempura. They know their regulars and sell the biggest bottles of Sapporo I've ever seen.

Sounds like an all around winner to me!
author: Justin S.

description:
Crap sushi. Crap rice bowls. Crap sake. 

It just goes to show that people will eat anything as long as it start with the words Sushi. 

The best part for me was watching the sushi boat sail around in circles. I was memorized by it for like an hour. Actually now that I think about it that's probably the best part of this place, since the food is sub par to McDonalds and their 1 brand of sake tastes like bleach.

If you want sushi there are tons of places in the city, so why go here and leave with a stomach ache? Seriously...
author: Erik B.

description: The price went up but the food is still good! Ive been here for years and the food is always fresh. I mostly sit at tables to beat the wait. Everything is made to order and must try the seafood salad if u like raw stuff!!!
author: Yvonnr L.

description:
On the whole the sushi was solid. What really sold me were the special rolls. There was one with shrimp, avocado, special topping and then I think eel sauce - delicious!

The people who work there are also really nice.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I can confidently say that this is the best sushi boat restaurant in San Francisco.  I can also confidently say that you will (very easily) drop $40 dollars on just yourself.  ...Oh wait, that was me.  

Ouch.  I ate $40 bucks?  Ouch.  

But it was really really almost worth it.  The unagi is amazing.  The special house roll is amazing.  The seaweed salad is amazing.  The california rolls?  Amazing.  

AND THE CHICKEN WING.  It permeates my dreams.  

The sad part about this place though is that it's pretty common for the boats to be empty - either because it's busy or for some horrible reason unknown to me.  Menu ordering is common (lame!)  

To see my full restaurant review:  http://roofbythesea.blogspot.com/
author: Rachelle P.

description:
5-stars, because Yelp designates 5-stars: "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" . . . in this case . . . as good as it gets for sushi on boats (whether it's boats, train, or conveyor belt . . . I associate those means for serving ~ 'mediocre' at best; think 'Isobune', and you're there, but this place rocks).

NEVER in a million years would have thought the quality, service, AND price would match in a sushi restaurant, serving on a chain of boats, but this place comes close to rivaling Ebisu in the Sunset.
author: Peter B.

description:
We came here early after reading all abt the wait at this place. We showed up at 7pm and snagged up the last two seats. Boy, was it full and crowded at the sushi boat counters. We noticed some tables in the back room but it was empty, I guess you can order from their menu but if you want sushi boat, it's just not fun sitting in the "back room."

We had salmon nigiri (we snapped it before it was even placed on the boats as soon as the chef finished slicing the fish), crab sushi, salmon sushi and a few other plates. Bf felt like some vegetable udon, it came with a nice broth and was tasty. We eyed our neighbor's dish which was this plate filled with lots of fish and sauce. He pointed to the Daily Specials Board and it was called the spicy seafood salad. We ordered a plate ($14), it was worthwhile since it had so many different slices of fish (salmon, tuna, octopus, hamachi, etc) but the sauce was a teeny bit sour and it wasn't at all spicy but worth a try. 
We'll definitely be back, the caterpillar roll looked good!! Our meal came up to abt $50 incl tips but our neighbor's bill (party of 2 with sake) was $80! It's pretty pricey for Isobune sushi but they told us that their sake was realllly good.
author: Yan M.

description:
Five stars for fish quality, four stars for service.

When we arrived there were about ten people waiting for the sushi bar, so we chose the tables and were sat immediately.  The servers seemed extremely busy, and although they were nice it was hard to grab their attention to ask questions about the slightly confusing menu.

After receiving our drinks the bus boy mentioned that we were allowed to get up and grab food off the boats if we wanted.  perfect!!  It's a little awkward having to reach around other diners to get to the boats, but if you time it right when someone has just left and the the staff is cleaning the area it's no problem.   

We ordered the spicy unagi off the specials menu which was amazing, and got the rest of the food from the boats.  The oysters are great as well.  Actually all of the fish is delicious and fresh, and there seemed to be a good variety floating around on the boats.  Prices are good too!
author: Austin F.

description:
After many times of trying to come here and being told that the wait was going to be an hour, i finally got lucky and was seated right away.  This is a sushi boat restaurant meaning that sushi goes around in little boats around the table. 

Sushi here was good for the price. I don't think they have much variety on their sushi menu, but they can always make things that isn't on the menu, if you know what you want. For those that don't like sushi they also have reasonably priced udon, donburi, and bento boxes.

If you plan on eating here, try to get here early or expect a wait.
author: Cedric F.

description:
MY FAVORITE SUSHI IN SF! Extra points for friendly service at this family run gem. The sushi is super fresh and thoughtfully prepared.  If you don't see what you want on the floating boats of instant gratification, just ask for a special order and it comes out quickly.

Super healthy and delicious is the SPICY SEAFOOD SALAD! A huge bowl of raw fish chunks, avocado, cucumber & jalapeno all swimming in a savory soy based sauce. Well worth the $19.95 because it's enough for a meal.

Other unique favorites: Santa Barbara Uni, Seared Ahi Tuna in Special Sauce, Spicy Unagi Handroll, Tempura Asparagus Roll and Ama Ebi, Scallop & Mackerel Nigiri all rock my world.

Sushi heaven! Bravo!
author: Dawn D.

description:
Five of us went out to dinner last night (Sunday) and decided to try this place. We were all starving, having toured the city all day.  The front part of the place has a sushi boat eating area, but we opted for a table instead. The guy sat us down, dropped down menus and then briskly walked away.  There was hardly enough room for the 5 of us at this table so we used the adjacent table for the 2-person overlap. One of the servers seemed to have a problem with this seating arrangement and asked us why we could not sit together at just the one table. Really?!  Since there was no possible way to do this w/o sitting on one another's lap, he suggested we move to another table that was slightly bigger.  Okay, so this was our first warning sign to head for the hills.

On the way to the restroom to wash up, I noticed that the bathrooms were located way too close to the dining area--I guess this is alright since this joint was so small and the fact that real estate is sky-high in S.F.  Since both doors were locked, a member of our group asked a worker if we needed a key and he said something like "I don't think so" and simply walked away (we all should have done the same at this point).

Okay, so there are 5 of us, but we only had 2 menus? Go figure. So, we finally got somebody's attention to please have some more menus, which they did bring, but only 1 more. Luckily, we all like each another enough to sit close to peek over at each other's menu.  If we knew we'd sit this close perhaps we should have kept the first table after all. 

Room temp water/Diluted green tea/ Even waterier wasabi
We all drank water, which came to us lukewarm and seemingly straight out of the tap, but we noticed that others seated at the sushi boat area had ice in their water glasses. Though a very generously sized tea pot was set in the middle of our table, but we were all taken aback from the very diluted-down tea.  Each person received a little dish for soy sauce that had wasabi and ginger on top, but sadly, most of the wasabi was reduced to a runny-green puddle...should I continue?  Sure, why not.
Now is when things go from bad to worse.

"A Sticky situation" 
Alright, you think we should have ran out the front door screaming when we noticed that everything was "adhering" (including our arms) to the table. I'm not kidding! The soy sauce, menus, and almost everything else were seriously crazy-glued to the table.  It was so bad that more than one of us had to use a napkin to fashion a "mock" placemat. 
Not too many choices on the menu, especially the sushi.  My impression is that this place caters to their sushi boats and not so much the table diners?
Now for the miso soup, which was not hot, but rather warm and pretty sub-par. My mom (who is Japanese) says that you can always tell the quality of a good Japanese restaurant based on their miso soup.  Well, lo and behold, this soup just plain sucked! ALWAYS listen to mom and you'll save yourself a lot of distress!
Our orders finally arrive...and yeah, their service is also not very prompt here and lackluster at best.  Each dinner entrée came with salad that was wilted and don't get me started on their funky salad dressing! It was just not good and way too sweet. Three out of five of us had the tonkatsu chicken/pork with curry.  It was not awful except that the curry sauce was placed on top of the tonkatsu and the pieces were already soggy before reaching our table.  One member of our group had a bowl of pork donburi, which he seemed to enjoy.  Another person had chicken teriyaki, which she said wasn't very tasty.  We also ordered a few 3-piece sushi including avo-maki, Ca. roll and the salmon special.  I'll admit, nobody really disliked what they had for the sushi. 

I must admit that the service stepped up when it came to our water glasses being filled, which was very often, BUT the person's water-pouring technique was really poor and many times, water was splashed out onto the table or onto us.  Oh well!  Thank goodness the water wasn't ice cold.

Bottom line is save yourself the trouble and look into eating elsewhere or perhaps give the sushi boats a try...Do whatever floats your boat. (sorry I couldn't resist!)
author: Mel C.

description: Yuck. Sushi wasn't . Rice had no flavor. Cuts of fish for sushi were blocky and barbaric like I was the sushi chef. Hubby liked the eel. Zero artistry. Even the cheap sushi places in  have pride in their offerings. Tea was good. Servers were nice. Food was surprisingly bad considering how packed they were. People seemed to like it. Unfortunately, I'll still be searching for a good sushi place in the .
author: Mona M.

description:
This is a great sushi boat place! Sometimes when you're so hungry you can't even wait to scarf something down, ready to eat food as soon as you sit down is a godsend.

Their ingredients are fresh. Their prices are great. The staff is friendly and they have tea ninjas (your tea cup is always full and you wonder how it happened). They have lots of yummy creative sushi varieties going around. My favorite is the spicy tuna cubes covered in special sauce, thinly sliced green onion and cherry a tomato. The chef was sooo nice, he let us have something we were eyeing for free cause they were closing. It's a nice quiet relaxing place to have good eats. We're going back soon cause my fiance announced it was his new favorite sushi joint. Five stars cause I can't think of a thing to complain about.
author: Roxanne Q.

description:
I usually turn my nose up at sushi boat restaurants, but this one was out of the norm. Everything was exceptionally fresh and the rolls were fairly inventive. We even tried the live scallop which for $5.95 wasn't too steep at all. There were a few options that were outstanding - the hamachi topped with ginger,scallions, and ponzu sauce, the snow crab nigiri, and the octopus salad. Yums! 
Price is reasonable but a word of warning - if you go hungry you are going to be in deep with the dinero. I found it hard to keep my paws off every dish that swung by and the plates kept piling up. For $50 bucks (no drinks) two people can dine to the brink of food coma.
The wait wasn't bad - about 10 mins on a Friday night for the best sushi in the neighborhood.
author: Stacy T.

description:
I am giving this four stars because of how fun it was to try and grab the sushi off of the boats as they float by, also, they were willing to make specific rolls and put them on the boat if you asked for them.

The wait for a spot at the bar was very long and the quality of the sushi was not the very best i have had, but I loved it and I will be going back.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Sushi rolls = Sashimi was surprisingly not too shabbs for a sushi boat :)
2.) Chicken Teriyaki - ehh.. not very good
3.) Oyster - Oyster shooters yum


SERVICE:
Just grab from the sushi boat. But a server does come around to ask for drink orders, and for specialty rolls you can ask the sushi guys behind the boats. They refilled our teas plenty of times, so that was good.


ATMOSPHERE:
This place is small, and literally just features and surrounds a sushi boat course. haha. Darn things were quick, kinda requires coordination and decisiveness to snatch up the little plates.
author: Angela L.

description: Very fun sushi spot in the Castro area! If you never experienced sushi conveyor boats, it is a must try!! Fish quality if amazing and they have tons of variety! Don't be scared if you never been, it's like a self served place, pick a plate off the boat you want and eat! They will give you your check based on the patterns on the plates you grabbed. Just be careful if you only ordered the expensive stuff, you could spend a fortune here! If you don't see what you want, you can ask them to make it for you!! Only thing you might want to know is they are not Japanese, they speak Chinese, hence the 4 star rating, but go check it out! You'd have a blast!
author: Sappho C.

description: Sushi boat style (conveyor belt). Pleasantly surprised since my only other boat experience was at Gatten Sushi in LA which was terrible.  Pieces of fresh nigiri floated by, lots of vegetarian options. Reasonably priced. They have both table seating as well as seats around the belt.
author: Alias A.

description:
I've been here four times in the past two months and it's delicious. Everything i've gotten was good. 

Rolls: I've gotten two of the expensive rolls on the boats, not too sure what they're called because I couldn't find it in the menu (I think the guys create their own) But they were both SO YUMMY. Especially the one with the spicy mayo sauce.

Salmon Nigiri = heaven. They give such huge pieces of salmon! Something that many sushi places skimp on. 

Waiters were fast. The only thing I don't care for is the tea, but that's just me. My roommate loves it.

I recommend this place to everyone I meet who wants sushi!
author: Camille D.

description: Just was meh. Not too much variety and the sushi looked like it had been sitting out for a while. Needed to ask for a standard menu but the wait staff was really nice! Most likely not going back
author: Jake L.

description: We showed up at 8 and sat there until 10 waiting for fresh sushi to show up on the boat. Never happened. Got one round of food after ordering off the menu. Soooo, after a night of mediocre service I looked down and saw a crusty toothpick lodged in my tea cup, that was not mine. Gross! Pointed it out to our waitress who took it away and did nothing.
author: H.S. G.

description:
A foodie coworker had recommended this place over a year ago and since it's walking distance from the boy's apartment, we headed over here for my first sushi-boat experience in years. 

Some of the fish used on nigiri tasted spongy which I thought was odd although I'll attribute that experience to not having clue as to what I was picking up from passing boats. The salmon/sake nigiri wasn't bad and it seems they do a pretty decent job with the rolls. 

Great value for sushi, the bill was well under $50 with a drink or two included. It didnt' show up when I was there but next time time I'll make a point to seek out the unagi.
author: Ida C.

description: Went there for the sushi boat.  A bit overpriced for a sushi boat and for the quality you get.  Not sure I'll be returning.
author: Michael M.

description:
I truly am lucky, this place is right around the corner from my apartment. Every time my partner and I go in we are greeted with a friendly smile by the cute lady who I believe runs the place with her husband the sushi chef. It's nice to have a place that knows who you are and appreciates your business.

I have two standards items I must have every time I go. The dragon roll is a tempura shrimp roll placed on top of a spicy aioli and sweet teriyaki glaze, then it is topped with avocado and fresh crab meat; the roll is an absolute delight. The other must have is the spicy white tuna. It's lightly dressed with a tangy soy vinegar, topped with scallions, and garnished with a baby tomato. This tuna is so tender and delicious it transports me to a place of pure bliss. Yes I love it that much.

They have the boats in the moat that float by with a lot of assorted items.  I have tried most but after having the two gems I mentioned above, everything else is pretty much a quick way to kill off the hunger until my favorites arrive. My partner and I order them each time we go in and we both can never get enough. I wish money were no object because honestly I would go there all the time.
author: Izzy Z.

description: Phenomenal service, food and times. This place has the most amazing staff and owners, and I can't believe the diverse menu they offer.
author: Eoin L.

description:
I used to really like this place, but now it seems just OK.

The seating along the sushi boat is much more crowded than I remember it being, and the sushi doesn't seem like much of a value anymore.

Of course, like most sushi places, there's also no attempt to provide serve fish that comes from sustainable sources, and there are fairly limited vegetable/vegan options on the menu (e.g., vegetable ramen is in chicken broth).

Service is prompt and friendly.
author: Jane D.

description: finally tried the off menu seafood salad, it is impressive but expensive as all hell, but worth it. Give it a try
author: Lauren V.

description:
surprisingly decent nigiri from a boat! who would have thunk?

so many places get it wrong, you forget good food can be found anywhere. a recent visit to asia reminded me of this. 

it seems that we forget that food is supposed to taste good. its not a mass produced commodity that gimmicks and marketing campaigns are supposed to sell. 

warakubune really is good nigiri from sushi boats. id say one of the better places in the city. its fairly priced for what you get. there are some "jive ass" rolls, but they are made well and taste good. it is what it is. simple and good.

parking can be difficult in this area so plan ahead.

we got there right before the 7pm rush so we got seated at the LAST free spots.... quickly after, lines lines lines.
author: Euge L.

description:
Get the spicy seafood salad! 

I've been here several times and they've all been meh. It's just the same ol' borin' average sushi, going round and round, round and round in boats. Sigh. My boyfriend likes this place, I like him, he likes sushi, I don't care either way about sushi, so we come here. 

I figured that with 4 stars, there must be some secret thing yelpers know that I don't. It's the spicy seafood salad, part of the specials posted on the wall. Expensive ($18.50 as of last night, yikes!) but worth it. Basically a bunch of sashmi, at least 5 different varieties, served in a large shallow bowl with grape tomatoes, avocado (yum!) and zucchini chopped in. It's swimming in sauce, which tastes good, but sometimes overwhelms the fish. I ordered it as is to try it this time; I plan to order it with sauce on the side next time.

Spiciness level: I consider myself a moderate consumer of spicy and couldn't taste it at all. I preferred it that way. There are jalapenos in the bottom of the bowl if you want a real kick.  A doesn't eat spicy foods and thought the spiciness was noticeable. 

Sushi is average. Keep in mind that as I'm not a huge fan of sushi, I tend to consider it all average. Service is very good. As commented, they are prompt about filling your tea and water. When we came here right when they opened at 5pm, there were no sushi on the boats yet, but we enjoyed having the restaurant to ourselves. There's a whiteboard to sign up for seats when they're busy, and they can get pretty crowded. Seating is around the boats or in the back room.
author: Yan E.

description:
I could almost go five stars on this place, but I reserve five stars for unparalleled perfection.

I was dubious the first time visiting Warakubune, having had bad experiences at all other sushi boat places. But I am now a regular customer and find this place to be the best sushi for the price in this area. (Koo in the Sunset is my fave in the city, but I also really like Sushi Time over on Market).

The fish is super fresh, they use (exclusively?) real crab, and their signature tempura rolls are delicious. AND BONUS: I love their oysters-- served with plenty of lemon and a little smoky spicy sauce they are fresh and briny and ever so good.

I recommend the butter fish here, the mackerel, and the oysters especially.

Two of us usally spend $50-60 including sake or beer, so the price is RIGHT!
author: Jenny H.

description:
Ate here for the second time Wednesday night for a good friend's birthday dinner.  This is your typical Japanese sushi boat layout with table seating in the back.

The food quality and color is amazing here.  I am a bit disappointed at the variety available on the boats however.  We sat down at about 7:30 and finished about 8:45.  It wasn't until we were about to leave that the really good and interesting sushi started to appear in the boats.

Now you might think, okay, go there later then to catch the cool catch.  Wrong!  This place gets PACKED and it seems so every night regardless of the time or the day of the week.

They have some spectacular dishes off the menu that you just have to try.
author: Mike E.

description:
The first time I have ever experienced munching on sushi via boat style.

That isn't the reason though that I gave this place 5 stars, I gave it five stars since the sushi that was taking a cruise into my stomach was some of the most delicious sushi that I have eaten ever!  Just be ready to shell out a little more cash then a regular sushi spot.

This place makes sushi that has sweet potato fries on it, with taro in it as well.  This place definitely delivers the goods!  The roll that is filled with nothing but crab in it is one of the best rolls at this joint among many others.

If the sushi cruise is this good I wonder what the rest of menu is like.  I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu.
author: Mark L.

description:
I am pretty sure I went to a different place than the people that have given this place 4 and 5 stars. 

The worst service ever. I sat down and asked what beer they had on draft (since it was the menu) and the guy had no idea what I was talking about. It wasn't a language barrier thing. They just don't have draft beer and I guess no inclination to change the menu. It was just plain dumb.

The fish was precut and had been sitting in the fridge only to be placed on poorly cooked rice. If thats 5 star nigiri, than clearly most white folk are morons. 

The "sushi" that was circling on the boats was old. I am talking crusty old. People had given up on taking the garbage on there and were trying to order from the sushi "chef" (just because you don a kimono and make hand rolls does not make you qualified to stand behind the bar, dummy).

I have gotten better sushi at Safeway; better service too.
author: Christopher C.

description:
Round and round the boats go!  Sushi boat bar anyone?  

My friends love love this place.  I have to say it was pretty good.  Vast array of Sushi options, Crab legs, specialty sushi rolls........A merry-go-round of sushi boats! .......Ugh these boats make me dizzy!  

My friends come here for the Sushi Boats, but I would have to recommend the ramen and the broiled Hamachi.  Those two were amazing.  I would totally come back to have those again.  

So it's your choice, sit at the bar, or there are tables in the back, and you can order your sushi and have it made fresh at the bar.  The idea of old sushi sitting on a boat isn't my thang, especially if you can have them make you the same thing FRESH! 

Arigato Go zaimas!

Happy Sushi Boating!
author: Sandy C.

description:
Yelp once again has NOT failed to please my pallet!

After having some great melt in your mouth Sushi at a $$$$$$$ place in Las Vegas, I was on a mission this week to find a good restaurant that had served comparable dishes at cheaper prices and I must say this comes close although it was my first shot this week to find a place. 

I decided to do it differently this time and go with the recommendations under the review highlights:  

1. sashimi spicy white tuna 
2. spicy seafood salad
3. special roll with shrimp tempura/avocado/special sauce

I was definitely pleased by all the recommendations!!! First off, since it was our first time we did not know how or what to order.  I flat out said, "Yeah we'll have the sashimi spicy white tuna"  the waiter asked which one and I was stumped but he helped out and said do you want the one with the mayonnaise sauce, green onions and tomato?  My boyfriend said..."yeah yeah we'll try that" not knowing if it was the right one.  Holy!! I usually don't take chances like that but wow that Spicy white tuna was melt-in-my-mouth good!!!!!!

With the seafood salad, I again did not know and just ordered the "seafood salad" and he had these questions describing it and my boyfriend again said "yeah that's it, we'll have that too." Scooooore!  It was chunks of raw fish and octopus in a vinegary sauce with cucumbers, avocados, tomatoes and sesame seeds....to die for! For $18.95 I thought it was money well spent!

The easiest to order was the special roll and that was really really good but I think it was the sauce and the avocado together with the roll that made it tastes reallly good.

My advice is to not sit at the bar where the sushi boats are, I like made to order things and you'd probably end up spending less than what you might rack up on that boat!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
This restaurant is the standard by which all other places can only aspire to become.  This is a sushi boat restaurant on Church street (@15th) and at first glance you would think it was overpriced or horrible.  I know, it's a boat bar but believe me, not only is good but the best!

As you walk in the door you see beautiful savory fish that when tasted melts in your mouth.  The staff is very accommodating and for sushi fans you can even pre-order specialty items in advance.

Some of their regular item must haves that might be called the same elsewhere but different and better at Warakubune are : white tuna sashimi, albacore takaki, fatty albacore, crab nigiri, salmon nigiri, salmon skin roll, unagi hand roll or nigiri, house special roll, scallops and mussels. 

The staff are very attentive and willing to take special orders. Most importantly Bengi, the head sushi chef and manager is very careful in his preparation.  It's like watching an artist at work.  Although most items go immediately I have seen him throw out sushi on the rare occasion it sat for a several minutes.  

The ambiance is nice and inviting.  There is even a small back area for to accommodate larger groups or if you want a quite moment.  Many of the people are regulars and are greeted as such. Finally for all this the price point is not more expensive then anywhere else.
author: Stacy T.

description: Incredibly fresh fish, cheerful servers, bumpin' music, sushi boats. It's an all around fantastic experience. Because it's predominantly communal dining, I usually end up chatting with my neighbors. Thus far, everyone I've chatted with has been a regular. Which means they love Warka as much as I do! Once you start, you can't stop. I won't eat sushi anywhere else.  #WarakuAddict
author: Karen M.

description:
OMG. my fav place for sushi boats is Isobune in Japantown but since I moved to noe valley it's so far to go there. 
Warakubune satisfies my needs for sushi boats. It's kinda cheaper than Isobune but a little bit better! They have live scallop, uni, and ankimo! 

And omg. I love the the spicy scallop! soooo good! they even use real crabs for their kani roll. 

What's interesting is that they use freshwater uni, so it's a little bit bitter. But for all you white people who likes to order the basic rolls plus hella fusion stuff, you're gonna love this place. 

For me who loves traditional nigiri, it's not bad at all! LOVE LOVE LOVE
author: Miss C.

description:
OK again, this is what I get for just skimming reviews as I completely missed that this was sushi boat (I know, how is that even possible?). Imagine my surprise when we walked in (and of course, my immediate judgement) and saw the whole set up. 

Sushi was OK but probably would have been a better selection on a busier evening. A lot of the sushi looked like it'd be sitting there for awhile and as the restaurant began to empty, they continued to sit there. Many of the fell apart as I tried to eat them and weren't held together really well. The food that was brought out from the kitchen (oysters, seafood salad, seaweed salad) were all extremely solid and good. Some rolls/plates were good: fried asparagus roll, the tuna chunks someone else mentioned, the salmon nigiri. Of course I often hesitated and missed out on the good stuff and they were limited so they were never to be seen again, wah. Bring out the good stuff!

The ramen was so-so but I love ramen so maybe I am biased. Boo though it was pretty good but I found the meat to be tough, the broth to be just OK (spicy, though) and the noodles far too soft. I am a hardass about noodles though.

I feel like I am being somewhat generous by giving 3 stars. I did enjoy the pop and rap that was playing though. And the service was friendly and helpful though they didn't give us a real menu and we had to steal one from this other lady.
author: Salina Z.

description: I went to this restaurant with a friend for the first time and was greeted by a nice staff.  They seemed to hustle when getting us tea, ginger, wasabi, and drinks.  We were ushered to the sushi boat bar which was cool but I'm not a fan of this style of sushi service.  After waiting for a bit and grabbing a few nibbles off the boat that looked decent, I finally asked if they served sashimi and nigiri.  To my surprise they actually have a menu that was not offered to us when we arrived.  Just seems like poor service not to offer a menu to your customer and assume they've been to your establishment before.  For that i give them 2 for poor service and ok sushi.
author: Magenta M.

description: Another place to take the kid relatives....like Isobune in Japan Town....itsa fun thing. For what it is.... the boat thing delivering "sushi" in front of you. This is a much more friendly place than Isobune and I think the quality of the floating food is higher than Isobune. Great variety of nigiri & rolls and other concoctions. I do however prefer the traditional approach of a sushi restaurant (and TOP quality fish), omakasi or based on my whim, but this type of joint fills a niche that is appreciated by many... and so it goes with many 5 star reports.
author: Matsuo U.

description: My first time trying this place and it will be my last. Nothing I ordered tasted right. The Albacore, the Unagi, the California Roll... not even the wasabi was the right consistency or flavor. I went here based on reviews. I guess most people have never had good sushi before.
author: Cathy N.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place in the entire city. I've never sat in the back or really ordered anything except miso from their regular menu, but whenever my boyfriend and I get that sushi craving we come here. 

Three big reasons I love this place:

1. Their fish is outstandingly fresh. This is the only place I go to get mackerel nigiri (saba nigiri), but practically every nigiri here has that melt in your mouth quality that I just love. (I would also recommend their special hamachi sashimi with their house sauce and sesame seeds and a grape tomato and chives. SOOO GOOD) 

2. Their service is awesome and their staff is super friendly. I've come in a few times and gotten free sake from the sushi chef. 

3. The prices are pretty reasonable. For the quality sushi you're getting the prices are not bad. If I remember correctly their cheapest item on the  is around 2.50 and their most expensive is 3.95?  Give or take a few "black plate" items which are a bit more pricey, but few and far between. 

I take all my friends here, and have nothing but love for Warakubune. Arigatogozaimasu!
author: Cake S.

description: Love this place!  Staff is amazing and takes caste of good customers. Fish is fresh and well prepared. Fresh all the time. Can't say enough about it really. Gotta come in and try!
author: Lynda M.

description: My favorite sushi place in the bay!... The sushi is fresh and the flavors are outta this world! There is always a variety of sushi, with incredible flavors! This is my go to sushi spot in the city. Its run by the nicest, most amazing couple, creating a warm, welcoming environment. Plus, the waiters are incredibly attentive! The food and service will definitely keep me coming back! I wish I could give this place more stars!!!
author: Lauren V.

description:
Love the sushi here...made fresh, great flavor, some ive never had at other places...i love the special, tempura with a spice sauce and avocado..yummm...i can eat 5 of those plates, the spicy tuna is a must, and one i had never had that i really like is the sushi roll with sweet fried potato...what a delight...the sashimi is very fresh and its just a great place to go with friends, have some Saporo or sake.

only thing is parking is a pain in the butt but well worth it!
author: lori c.

description:
This place is horrid! If you don't know what real sushi/sashimi is, then this place is for you. 
I went last night (2/6/2010) and the service was just bad. They weren't even all that busy. They literally try to cram as much people around the sushi boat. We settled on the tables which was a bad idea. It's freakin literally next to the damn bathroom. We can effing hear people flushing over all the talk of normal people. The guy that was waiting us had a thick ass chinese accent, and had broken english. The bus boy kept hitting my friends chair since he was in the way of the back kitchen next to the bathroom; let alone him screaming at the "CHEFS" in the back. 

Aside from the service, I ordered a few things and said it in japanese (it was also written on the menu) he had to pause and keep asking to see the menu and make us point to what we wanted. The food was horrible. The portions were meek, just stuffed with rice and it's very VERY high priced. Their so called "spicy" dishes is just either drizzeled with wasabi and/or suracha (the vietnamese rooster sauce). Overall terrible place. Terrible people. 

 My friends and I ended up going across to street to eat @ sparky's. If I could give negative stars I wish I could!

Oh and the good part (yes I am being sarcastic), we spent $40 on just the 3 of us.

If I were you, i'd ditch this place and go some place else.

Minor note, what you see in the picture were ripped off of a Japanese food site, it's nothing compared to what you will get.
author: Dave Y.

description:
Compared to other sushi boat restaurants...........this is definitely 5 stars.  The food itself is probably 4 if you compared it to a more full service sit down establishment.

I am utterly surprised on how great the sushi was.  Everything was fresh, service was awesome, and the food was reasonable.  Genevieve and Phillip have told me about this restaurant for the longest time and this was bookmarked since 
god knows when...........this place didn't disappoint.

White tuna
spicy tuna
uni
salmon
hamachi
Shrimp tempura roll with unagi and crab salad

Nothing really disappointed me. Everything was great!!! Will definitely come back here.
author: jason g.

description:
Excellent location
Cleaner than most
Well-priced quality sushi
Pleasant, attentive staff
Welcoming environment
author: Right S.

description:
This restaurant is one of the things I miss most about living in SF.  Within about a 5 block radius of my old house were approximately 10 good sushi restaurants.  This place was the best.  It was in a close tie with another neighborhood sushi restaurant which lost it's best sushi chef (of course he was Korean, why do you ask?), so there's not even a contest now.  

An old friend and I ate here often, and when we did, we could barely waddle out the door at the end of our meal, leaving in our wake stacks and stacks (and stacks) of trays from the sushi boats.  In fact, when he brought his Japan-born-and-raised sister-in-law, she declared that it was the best she's ever had.
Every time but one, I sat at the counter with the sushi boats.  Not only is it fun, but you get instant gratification, and who doesn't love instant gratification?  

If what you want isn't coming by on the boats, (it just might be because I'm sitting upstream from you and I wanted it more!) you can order directly from the chef or even from a waiter/waitress.  Trust me and sit at the sushi boats counter.  You'll enjoy it, and you might be intrigued enough by something you see to try a new item.

Do have that one food item by which you initially judge a new restaurant?  For me it's Kung Pao Chicken for a Chinese restaurant, a Reuben for a deli, Tom Ka Gai for Thai and for sushi, it's unagi.

This restaurant serves the unagi by which all other unagi is to be judged.
I've never found better unagi anywhere.  I've found some which comes close enough to pass muster on the restaurant, and allow me to continue eating there, but this is the ultimate. (Pardon me while I drool a bit).  The eel is fresh, firm, perfectly cut, grilled to perfection, with just the right amount of their exquisite sauce brushed onto it and served up hot.  It's firm, yet melts in your mouth almost before your lips touch it.  Their anago is almost as good. 

My second favorite dish here, the other one for which I will swim upstream past your chair to get to it before you can?  Their tempura asparagus roll.  I'm not kidding, it's amazingly good.  Start with fresh asparagus, coat it in tempura batter, deep fry it lightly, but keep it crisp, put it in a rice and nori roll and slather the unagi sauce all over it and you have a wonderfully flavored vegetable roll.

Their spicy tuna is not the mangled, chopped sesame oil filled gooey mess that you get in some places.  It's the whole pieces of fresh tuna with a good spicy sauce (I believe they use the Vietnamese chili garlic sauce known as "Sriracha Chili Sauce").

All of their other dishes are wonderful.  I ate there often and can't remember ever having any portion of a bad meal or service.  

Yes everyone raves about the Spicy White Tuna and it is wonderful (and expensive), but I always came here for the simple sushi, and no one does it better.
author: Bill T.

description: Average sushi. The chef will make you anything fresh that is not floating by on the boats. The music is fun, poppy and dancey. It's a great place to get a quick healthy meal and feel cool while doing it.
author: Mark S.

description:
Great little sushi place.  When I came here, my friends and I were starving, so we opted to skip the wait for the packed sushi boats and sit in the small, but empty seating area in the back.  I was kind of sad to miss out on the sushi boat experiences of trying new items, but sitting in the back afforded us all to sit and talk with each other in our own cozy corner.  

After looking at all the yelp reviews, we had to get the spicy seafood salad.  We ordered it as an appetizer to share among our group.  The seafood chunks were huge and fresh, you could tell that they weren't just giving you scraps.  I personally think it looks more beautiful than it tastes - the sauce lends a kind of citrusy taste to the dish, that I wish hadn't been there.  Actually, had it been without the sauce, so I could just dip it in soy sauce and wasabi, I think I would have enjoyed it even more.  But a huge dish with avocados, cucumber, grape tomatoes, and an assortment of fresh seafood ranging from yellowtail, to tuna, to salmon, to octopus....I'm not going to complain.

As for the sushi, everything was fresh and the cuts of fish on the nigiri and sashimi are huge!  I had the spicy tuna roll, hamachi, hotate, and unagi nigiri.  The spicy tuna roll, definitely had a kick to it, but was very tasty.  The hotate nigiri was a large slice of scallop, very tender, but still not as buttery as I would have liked, but good nevertheless.  Hamachi, you can never go wrong with.  But definitely get the unagi - it was warm, huge, tender, and dripping with sauce (that's what she said).
author: AJ P.

description: Tiffany is the best.  The service is impeccable.  Prices are reasonable and they are always happy to see us.  Sushi is great.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
author: Aquableu C.

description:
I accidentally found this place while searching for conveyor belt sushi, which my partner had never tried. We were in SF for a weekend, and as there is a huge dearth of decent sushi in Phoenix, I wanted to make sure I hit up good sushi in SF, especially for my partner, who eats fish (I don't).

The place itself is fabulous -- easy to find, and I didn't realize it, but instead of a conveyor belt, they had little sushi boats that floated around the sushi bar in water...working rudders and all. It was pretty fantastic.

I ordered miso to go with my meal -- I wish they'd had a more complete menu even in front of the boats, so I could have ordered apps and more veggie friendly rolls. Also, the items on the boats weren't labeled, making it difficult for those of us (in a group of 5) with dietary restrictions (such as being non-fish eating) to figure out what was what. I had to ask more than once.

That said, the food was GOOD. They was a good options of veggie maki, as well as Inari (mmm), and the fish eaters all praised the various rolls.  One person had some sashimi that she said melted in her mouth.  When the boats were full, it was awesome...however, about half the time, there was a lull, and only the same 3 items that had been going around for an hour (seriously, at some point, take them off!) were available. I wound up ordering some avocado rolls to break up the boredom.

I had a ton of food. Like stuffed.  $15 (including miso and the hot tea). My partner had a similar amount, but with fish/crab/etc. $18.  Definitely affordable, and delicious. I just wish it was easier to a) figure out what things were and b) always have options.

While this isn't an all the time place, it's fun, affordable, and we'll be going back on our next visit.
author: Shanna K.

description:
I love this place!  The first time I went was with a true regular and they greeted us very warmly and full of smiles, soon followed by endless amounts of complimentary hot sake.  I was immediately hooked.  Now he and I still return time after time to the same smiles and great food and energy.  It's such a nice place to just relax and celebrate the end of the week.  "Otsukare sama!"
(but it's actually Chinese-owned, not Japanese lol)
author: West P.

description:
I just read tons of reviews applauding the freshness of the sushi.  I came here early on a Friday night because Sushi Zone was closed for renovations (I was utterly disappointed).  My bf and I were so early there were no sushi on boats yet and we had to order off the menu.  We got the spicy white tuna special and it was delicious.  Everything else was normal and tasted decently fresh to me. 

HOWEVER, at the end of the night I felt really sick and threw up multiple times.  My bf felt fine, but I'm pretty sure it was something I ate at Warakubune.  Don't let my one experience taint your expectations of this place, but just be wary, don't say you weren't warned.  

*The katsu is ultra salty and the meat isn't that great
**The music was horrendous at the beginning of the night, it was killer-headache-rave- music
author: Skye W.

description:
Something about the novelty of sushi arriving by boat makes it taste that much better to me. 
It also means I can try more things. However, variety of what is on the boats is key, always come at a peak time. We showed up around 8pm and the selection was good when we first arrived but was waning when we left.
Plates range from $1.95 - $3.95. Sushi quality is 3-4 stars. Plus 1 star for boats.

Plus another star for our company at the sushi bar. We were seated next to a party of 5 decked out in costume (it was the day before Halloween but that isn't a requirement to wear a costume in this city) who had obviously been partaking in some spirits. Obviously regulars at Warakubune, they were hilarious. If you're reading this, thanks for making our meal!
author: Audrey N.

description:
I've now visited Warakubune twice, and finally feel like I can say something about it.  And it's this:

Good.

Not great, not bad, but good.  Simple and easy enough where a solo diner can quickly get a sushi fix without feeling awkward sitting by himself in a full-serve restaurant, just like in Japan.  The selection of the sushi boats can vary, from what I've experienced.  Going close to prime time is probably better, because then they're making all the good stuff.

But be forewarned: the plates pile up quickly!  I've finally gotten into the habit of having a plate of inari before having anything else, so there's a good chunk of rice sitting in my belly before I start grasping at all the little pieces of nigiri that come floating around.

The fish itself is decent, not the highest quality, but certainly not bad.  The tuna and salmon to me have always been a little eh, but tonight I was able to get what I think is mackerel, which turned out to be pretty awesome.

Now there's a room in the back for those who don't want to sit at the boats, but then again, what's the fun in that?  But I suppose if you come with more than just one or two dining companions, that may be the preferred way to do it.

So...get your butt over.  Or don't...because I don't want to wait in line behind you.
author: Mark C.

description:
A girlfriend and I came here the other night when we fancied some good old sushi. we were early, around 6:30 pm. It was a good time to get a seat but there was nothing great on the sushi boats yet.
So we ordered. But as our orders came in, the boats kept rolling by with more and more awesome stuff. The fish is great quality and the prices are really good. 
I'll definitely go here again. 
And the front door speaks to you :)
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Priceless as it was seeing our neighbors' faces as my friend (a sushi-boat landlubber) yanked a piece of sushi off a passing plate with her chopsticks---an experience you just can't have at a standard sushi joint---Warakabune taught me sushi is more than just fish and rice.  

Sushi to me is about the drawn out ritual of small things and different flavors---some sake here, edamame there---savored over the course of the meal, and time to enjoy the people across the table.  

The sushi boat experience (tho Warakabune's fish is above average and the service is beyond efficient) is more about the novelty and challenge of snagging mass-made sushi as it zips past your section of moat.  "Quick, grab the dragon roll---NO, the DRAGON roll---awcrap, there it goes!"

If that sounds exciting, you really need a quick sushi fix, and the plastic pack at Safeway just isn't cutting it---yay!---you've found your spot.  I prefer my sushi sans moats and boats.
author: Dana S.

description:
Stellar sushi! 
 I usually avoid the sushi boat places as gimmicky and touristy, but this is the exception. Great, fresh fish, good tight rolls and the chef will make you little plates if you ask him to. He is front and center, captain of the sushi boat! 
 I have been here several times and have been lucky to not wait for a seat. Even though the last time the waitress spilled a cold beer into my lap I still love this place!
author: Emily L.

description:
Atmosphere: Fun
Food: Average
Price: Reasonable
Service: Wait servers are slow

We love this place for the entertainment factor sushi is good not great, love the neighborhood. Could use a facelift and a good cleaning!

Rick
author: Rick F.

description: Hands down my favorite sushi restaurant in SF.  You must order the spicy white tuna with sesame seeds, the white toro tuna, the seared ahi, and the avocado filled with spicy scallops.  The fish is so fresh, the service is excellent (if you don't see it coming around on the boats, just put in an order for whatever you want more of), and you can get your food quickly (ie right when you sit down if you want).  I can't wait to go back!
author: Amanda C.

description:
This sushi place rocks! They always have the freshest sushi and great service. My coworkers and I like to come here after work, since we are only a couple blocks away (Colorbox Salon-come get your haircut and then go eat sushi!!)
Some sushi boat restaurants scare me because, well let's face it, how do you know how long that sushi has been floating around on the little boats?? Not Warakubune though! They have sushi chefs working behind the boats, so only the freshest fish right off the boat! heh heh...
Be sure to get the "special", with spicy white tuna and cherry tomatoes. It's to die for!
We like to call this place "Sushi Dream Boat"! 
Highly recommended!
author: Adrienne A.

description:
OK, I have something to confess.  I didn't mean to do it, but I cheated.  A girl just needs something a little different once in a while.  I went to sushi somewhere other than my usual haunt.  (Gasp!)

This is a cute little place with the sushi boats.  We got there around 6:30, so we were seated easily, but there was a line later.  Service was friendly and the prices were good.  (I had 3 rolls, 1 nigiri, and two small cold sakes and with a 20% tip it was $30.)  I thought the sushi was OK, but not special.  I'm thinking that maybe I should have had more of the nigiri and skipped the rolls.

Overall, I wasn't disappointed that I cheated....and I'll do it again!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
love, love, love Floaty-Boat Sushi.  I've been coming here since the day it opened... the owners are so warm and friendly.  I love this plate that has three chunks of tuna, rolled in sesame seeds, with spicy mayo sauce drizzled on top, then sprinkled in scallions.  DAMN.
And also, the last item on the main menu-- the spicy Udon soup.  so gratifying.  
If you don't like it there, please go away so I don't have to wait in line!!!!
author: Madelena M.

description:
Everyone loves moving foods.  It's like I'm playing Oregon Trail with sushi.  The portions are generous for the quality of fish that you get.  The sushi chef will usually make whatever you'd like and takes pride in his food.  He overheard when I said "hmm this spicy ramen isn't that spicy..." and yelled at his staff to get me a new bowl.  We were ordering Uni and he said "hmm I don't think this week's Uni is very good," tries it and throws it away "no, no good, no uni for you, next week maybe better."

The oysters are good.

They carry walu / butterfish.

The white tuna toro is good too.
author: evan t.

description:
We went early on Friday night to avoid a wait. We were immediately seated and the waiter was taking our order. 

The boat sushi was mostly maki. But as the night progressed, more interesting and delicious sushi floated along. 

We decided to try the spicy white tuna special. It was SO GOOD we ended up getting a second order!

We also tried the curry fish roll which tastes just like katsu curry, YUM!

My friend loved her uni!

I can't wait to try it again!
author: Gina L.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  It's a bit small so definitely call in for a reservation if you have a big group.  The majority of the customers sit at the sushi bar where the chefs are in the center and they're constantly making rolls/sashimi dishes.  

They charge you by the plate.  I love their spicy tuna and all of their sashimi dishes.  Their SPECIAL ROLL is delicious and everything is pretty much made fresh (eel, softshell crab, etc).  Their eel is very tasty as well.  

Get there early for rush hours!
author: Phuong H.

description: The food is delicious and really reasonably priced for a sushi place. You can grab the little boats so you are able to taste a lot of different options as opposed to ordering only 1 or 2 rolls somewhere else. Besides the fact that it is pretty damn fun having to snatch the little plates off the boats. It makes the whole dining experience more unique. I definitely recommend.
author: Brittany N.

description:
When I go on dates with American men, and I say my favorite food is sushi. They always tell me that they know a really good place and they want to take me there. I know I should have forseen  the floating boat coming!!!!

Last Saturday was another one
Although I had a great time, I have to say I ate very little not because I was not hungry nor I wanted to play feminine card.

This is not sushi. Its something else...

I came home and made myself ochazuke.
author: Mika G.

description: The worst service I've had in a very long time! Felt like I was sitting at a family table with a bunch of folks u didn't know and had to hear all sorts of bothersome conversations and music being played. The waiters were not attentive and apparently no one in charge to talk to. When I finally got my food, after the first order being delivered to another party that showed up 15 mins after me, it was the greatest roll ive had in a long time - just not do sure it was worth the wait or environment. My first time here, and I WON'T be coming back.
author: John Paul S.

description:
Maybe there is life after Isobune. 

For a number of years, Ive been searching for a good sushi boat restaurant. I used to frequent Isobune in Burlingame about 20 years ago when it served fresh sushi in a great environment. I found something that comes close to that in Warakubune Sushi. 

I went to Warakunbune on a Saturday evening. We arrived early around 5:30 and surprisingly it wasn't very crowded. There was only two other parties, about 6 people. To my surprise, there wasn't any sushi on the boats yet. If your a sushi rookie, this might have presented a problem since you would have had to order directly from the sushi chef. Though during the course of our stay, sushi was added to the boats. By the time we left, the boats were mostly full. 

Of course, the sushi boat experience is good for those who might be intimidated to sit and order at a traditional sushi bar. The sushi was pretty traditional Nigiri-type rolls; so if you're looking for some exotic combination roll, you won't find it on the menu. (though like any sushi bar, you can probably order it). 

Sushi Freshness: 7.5 (1-Won't eat; 5 - what you would find at Safeway; 10 - to die for). The sushi was fresh. 

Sushi Creativity: 5 (1- Typical nigri rolls; 5 - typical nigri rolls plus some unique ones; 10 - Many different rolls). On the boats its mostly nigri-type rolls. 

Service: 9 - No wait for seating at 5:30! Promptly filled my tea cup and water glass (maybe to the point of annoyance. But that's better than dying of thirst with no one to be found!) One plus is that when I finished my ginger (you know the one that comes in a small dish with Wasabi) they gave me more ginger without asking! I havent had that happen except when I'm sitting at a sushi bar. 

Cleanliness: 9 - Overall the restaurant seemed clean. I didn't use the restroom to judge those. 

Overall: Great restaurant. 

i would defiantly come back here. I would recommend Warakubune for people who want to try sushi and maybe are a bit intimidated about sitting at a sushi bar and not knowing what to order. I would have like to have seen more variety in their rolls but otherwise I discovered there is life after Isobune.
author: Mark K.

description:
Not going to lie, really wanted to hate this place before trying it. I KNOW I KNOW, I'm SOOOO mean, but seriously, what sushi boat place serves fresh sushi?! I actually love this place. Tell you why later.

This Cantonese-run sushi joint wasn't hard to find - PARKING was hard to find. Took forever to finally find a spot a few blocks away. When we entered, we sat at the sushi bar - best place to sit since the boats are what you come there for.

Selection, I would say, isn't as big - they have the basics that you'd find at all sushi places: maguro, hamachi, sake and others. When we got there, there were no boats floating around - at ALL. Minus one star. We waited and waited but no new boats came around, only the red/green tobiko came around several times - don't know how long those stayed there but they were still there when we left.

We ended up ordering straight from our server who was very sweet and pleasant. Our tea cups were instantly filled once they even appeared to be empty. The sushi came out pretty quickly, straight from the chef. They were huge, cold and pretty fresh pieces, though the rice didn't stick together and tasted bland - not a very good sign.

Besides the preparation of the rice, the nigiri tasted pretty good and pretty fresh too. Apparently they also had oysters too that night but ran out that same night. The bf had this tuna/mayo/ponzu/spicy sauce salad thing, which looked really scary to eat but was soo good, he had 3 orders! Prices were fair and probably pretty good considering the size of the sushi.

Four stars overall because the female server said I was pretty. She totally won me over. And that is why I love this place so much lol :)

PS. Our server told us that many people double park then come to eat - tip if you're feeling adventurous!
author: T L.

description:
Me and my girlfriend went here last night.  It's not bad or anything (I actually really liked the Unagi), but for the price, it's simply not a good value.

I really wanted to go because they have a conveyor belt.  Conveyor belt is awesome, and the floating boats are cool.  However, you'll end up blowing way too much money for what you get.  There are some cheap plates, but they pretty much just have California rolls - anything else and you're paying up.  We spent $60 without drinks and for that money, the sushi should be a lot more bomb than this place.
author: Max B.

description: This place sucks. I was expecting a lot out of this place since there's not many revolving sushi restaurants in the city, but it didn't even taste that "AMAZING".....far from it.....and it's expensive. I knew that from the get go, but if it was actually good I wouldn't have cared. It's HELLA SMALL too.
author: Diane L.

description:
I've lived in SF for twenty years, and as far as sushi goes, this is the one place I consistently come back to. Last week I ate at a sushi place a few blocks away that everyone fawns over, and comparing that with the sushi I'm eating here right now, this place wins hands-down and is also much less expensive. And as opposed to an hour-long wait for a table, I walked in, sat down and started eating immediately. 

The Saba nigiri is the best I've ever had, no exaggeration, and the unagi is excellent. Often they will have uncommon items like bonito and red baby octopus. My only complaint is that they're closed Monday and Tuesday but everyone deserves a weekend.
author: PF D.

description:
I have been eating at Warakabune for four years.  The fish is always very fresh, and everything is always tasty.  I love sitting at the boats, and the sushi chefs even recognize me when I come in and within moments my favorite roll is circulating (I always order the salmon special).

Prices are great, service is excellent, and I never leave unsatisfied.
author: Michelle R.

description: The sushi here is fresh and there is a lot of variety.  Good service too.
author: Karen L.

description:
Dear warakubune,
Why have you gotten so many good reviews?

So the first time i went here was last year, i was sitting in the park drinking Sake as always during day time, I was taking some pictures on myself with Iphone and had a brief conversation with a creep.

Then all of a sudden I got drunk, like really drunk and I realized I need food, NOW, and now you ask me"why would you go for sashimi when you are drunk" Well because I just don't make sense at all most of the time, so if I confuse you, just let it go.

So I bought the sashimi combo, until this day even though hubbie says i was hammered I claim  that the fish was bad.

A couple of days ago we ended up there again, i ordered the sashimi combo again, and again the fish was poor, dry, fishy and uhh, even hubbie thought so.
So no thank you, no more dry sashimi.

HOWEVER if you order the spicy white tuna and the scallop it is actually quite tasty.
A tip, never ever order sashimi here, order nigiri or ask for specials that are off the menu!
author: cecilia k.

description:
I went here for dinner tonight.  The place was busy but the wait wasn't to bad. Took about 15 mins for two seats to open up at the sushi bar... where i suggest you sit. You can sit and chat as the sushi goes by on boats. When you see something you like grab it and enjoy!! This really gets you to try new sushi options instead of ordering your usual california roll.... which was excellent here by the way! So was the dragon roll. 
The seats are close together at the bar. Unlike other places I didn't feel cramped and couldn't over hear others conversations. The set up was nice for such a small area.   After everything my meal was only about $16. Pretty cheap for the amount of sushi I consumed. 
This place is great and I will definitely come back.
author: Wes P.

description:
cubed sashimi - F
waited 30 min for the check - F
difficult to get anything during the meal. waiters/waitresses barely make eye contact - F
author: Mi M.

description:
Warakubune Sushi is NOT a regular Sushi restaurant. 
It is a Kaiten Sushi (Sushi Boat) restaurant. 

Kaiten Sushi in Japan is very casual and cheap eats like fast food. 
Each plate costs about $1 or $2, maybe $3 at most. Gari (ginger) and Green Tea station is in front of you and free! 
So you don't expect topnotch quality and service from this kind of restaurant when you decide to eat at Kaiten Sushi to begin with. 

Knowing that I was going to Kaiten Sushi in SF, my strategy was to stay away from Nigiri Sushi and just to stay with Maki mono (Rolls) so that I would not be disappointed at the restaurant. 

It worked! I enjoyed the Rolls.  In fact, the California rolls were pretty good!  My boyfriend had a few plates of Nigiri. They were not tasty as I guessed. 

Warakubune is met for my expectation? 
Definitely not for Sushi restaurant but maybe for Kaiten Sushi restaurant. 
What makes me sad is that I know for the fact that we could have gotten sushi twice as good and paid 1/2  the price in Japan. We had no free access to Gari / Green Tea station. 

Though it is Kaiten Sushi place, the restaurant has a full menu from soup to main. There are additional tables in the back of the room. You can ask for a regular menu and order dishes from the menu even if you sit at the Sushi boat area. The waiters are around. 

Last note
I found the Sushi Boat ran much faster than Japanese one.  I felt sick and dizzy when I was busy looking at it to choose the plates.
author: Emma K.

description: This place was surprisingly good, both in food and service. Friend wanted to go to a "conveyor belt" sushi bar and this was the most highly rated one in the bay area. The food here was good and the service was fantastic. After a few sushi off the boat, I opted to order from the menu. The menu is pretty limited, but our order of age tofu and sake sashimi were both very good. Our waitress was also very friendly and helpful. I had no idea how much tea I had since she always kept the cup full!
author: Jess L.

description:
I finally ate here after much fanfare and praise heard from friends.

I only have one question for myself:  WHAT THE #$%@ WAS I DOING BY NOT EATING HERE BEFORE?!?!

Maybe it's just because I'm new to sushi boat, but this place is awesome.  You sit down and *BAM!*, it's go time.  No waiting for waitstaff to bring your drinks while you wait to order.  Watch all the delicious stuff float by, tuna, salmon, oysters.  Grab it while you can, other people are hungry too.  Hell, part of the fun is sitting here for a few minutes and seeing what will show up on the boats (tempura asparagus and shrimp balls, anyone?).  

The fish is fresh and pieces are pretty large.  I had some of the salmon nigiri and I swear I might have just ordered the whole damn fish.  Despite the seemingly unspecific mass production, the rolls are quality.  I even enjoyed experimenting and grabbing some of the random shiz that flew by and luckily I wasn't disappointed.  The prices are excellent, the stuff is easily a dollar or two cheaper than most places.  As a result I didn't feel so bad throwing down on 12 of those little plates.

The bad parts are obviously, if you are lusting after a particular fish and they aren't serving it, well... I guess you can order it?  I don't know I was pretty happy with the selection that got thrown out.  There was also a bit of a lull in the sushi production, so for awhile the same stuff kept going around while we hungrily awaited new and more enticing options.  This is a rather minor complaint, just order some beer and relax.
author: Steven R.

description: One of my favorite places to get sushi in the city.  It is a sushi boat establishment, but the nigiri is fresh and they are generous with their cuts of fish.  Their rolls are fine as well, but their strengths is in the nigiri.
author: dublin a.

description: I was really excited about this place and have tried to come by a few times, always a bit too early. When we finally got here at the right time, there was a long list at the door. The sushi boat experience was fun, but the sushi was mostly covered in sauce. If you like Americanized sushi (I used to!), this is a great place for you. I can't say I had any standout sushi and I really wish they had cold sake rather than only the hot kinds... but the experience is really fun and it's nice to chat with the other patrons at the bar.
author: Sylvia L.

description: I was always slightly afraid of sushi boat places, fun as they can be, but this is my go to place for sit down sushi.  Local, great service, reasonable pricing, and fish is always fresh.
author: B B.

description: Made an account just to leave a review, especially since I hear a lot of people like this place. Had an unsatisfactory experience. Came with three other people, one got his food after waiting 15 minutes and finished it before the other two got theirs and finished within 20 minutes. THEN got mine which was not as spectacular as I would hoped for after waiting 30-40 minutes. Maybe because it's Saturday night, but still, its such a small place and not fully packed. Maybe I'll try it once more, but so far not impressed.
author: Lance O.

description:
Cute place, good service, but food is just okay.

Yummy things:
Special salmon roll
Gyoza
Unagi (reallly good)

Not so yummy things:
Tempura
Spider roll

It seems that anything that is deep fried is over-fried and really greasy. Kind of unappetizing and overly crunchy.  The crab mix in the california roll had way too much mayo in it. I know it's pretty standard to use mayo in the mix, but you shouldn't really be able to taste, and it definitely shouldn't be overpowering.

The quality of the fish used in the sushi was pretty good (but not outsanding). 

The only thing that stood out to me was the unagi.  It was dellllicious.  I wanted to order about 6 orders of it, but I restrained myself.
author: Jenn S.

description:
I'd been resisting this place for a while because I figured the that sushi served in floating boats would have to be bad....WRONG! Finally gave it a try a couple of weeks ago and the experience was fun and the sushi fresh and tasty. The key to eating well here is to stick to the nigiri sushi and watch what goes around the boats--avoid the stuff that's been circling for a while. The good stuff goes fast so you have to be on the ball. 

Top recs: the white tuna topped with ginger and scallions--totally melts in your mouth. The salmon was also buttery. I also loved the fried veggie croquettes that come piping hot and filled with purple yams and such. Delicious.
author: Macheeks ..

description:
Sushi. In boats. Yeah. Not so much.

Well this is what I would have continued to think had it not been for 2 very wise friends of mine last night who took me to this here heaven in your mouth via boats sushi place. Oh my god. Can we please just talk about the albacore toro. I mean, there are no words. Seriously, unless you consider, "mmmm," "oh my guhh," "holy shi..." words, then yeah, there are no words to describe how amazing this sushi is. Wow.

What's even better about this place is once you discover the goods and I mean the really good goods, then it is a fun game of greed, gluttony and I win!! You see, there are no manners in boat floating sushi. Sure, you are probably supposed to share, but eff that, mama didn't raise no fool. I see buttery dissolve on your tongue toro for $3.95 being put out and you better believe I'm grabbing three plates for me and my crew. No shame in that game.
