We continued to eat and eat and eat some more and made friends at the boat bar with these two that swore this is the best sushi in SF. Honestly, I may very well believe them after last night. Oh and for this scarf-fest, filling sushi meal with cold sake...$25 a person. HELL YES!!!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Much thanks to Genevieve Y., I am a fan of Warakubune!  I don't think I would have known about this place on my own, since it's located on the quieter end of Church Street, whereas the other end is full of crowds lolling around the ever-popular Chow.

It's true that this sushi boat restaurant is owned by Cantonese people, but I have no qualms with that (power to my people!).  What's important is that their fish is extremely fresh, the sashimi pieces are generous, the prices are great, and the service is exceptional (my tea cup was constantly filled).  

Plates range from about $2-4.  We weren't too interested in the lower priced plates, and it seemed like most everyone wasn't either.  The sushi chefs were really good with throwing out plates that had been sitting on the river for a while.  We loved everything we had: salmon, scallops, spicy albacore, hamachi, spicy tuna, and specialty rolls.  You can ask for specific items from the sushi chefs and they'll make them upon request, and the rest will be divided amongst the sushi boats.  With 9 plates (specialty rolls included) and a large bottle of sake, our tab was about $44.

I'm not sure if it was the effect of drinking sake on an empty stomach or my proneness to getting dizzy easily, but eyeing sushi plates on the river was making me a bit light-headed (hmmmmm...).  But one thing's for sure: I'm definitely coming back!
author: Diane L.

description:
really great miso soup

the rolls were OK, and there wasn't enough variety coming around the sushi boats
author: Captain B.

description:
I've only been to a few sushi boat restaurants in San Francisco..

Fune-Ya
Sakura-Bune
Isobune

And they jus werent really any good. I mean they can make you full and are pretty light on the wallet. etc etc etc. Basically what you would expect from these type of "sushi" places. Anyways, last night after work my lady and I decided to grab some sushi and I remembered reading about this place. So what the heck lets give it a shot.

When walking in, there is a little machine that greets you with a "Iraishaimasei!" The main chef in front looks our way and greets us with a nod. One of the servers, this tall gentleman with glasses greets us and despite the small line of anxious hungry custoemrs, he tells us we dont need to write our names on the board. I guess he pretty much kept it in his head about who was in line.

So after a good 10min wait or so we got seated..and thats where the feast began. The sushi boat itself is not very big, not like fune ya where they have this huge bar with many boats. Thats a good thing cause it keeps the selection simple and the majority of the items kept getting picked up so you know everything was freshly made.

Salmon was great, Ive never had such good salmon at a sushi boat
Hamachi was buttery and wonderful, same thing.
Negi-hama was very good just enough of the hamachi and green onion
This one handroll, which had unagi and crab..it was spicy..not a little spicy but pretty spicy. Dont get me wrong though, also very good.
Unagi was very good, I dont know why other places have such crappy tasting unagi.
They had like a tuna tataki? a mixture of thigns on it. Quite tastey also.
They had this roll topped with a lil spicy tuna and taro fries, interesting but very good.
We saw this fried ball thing and didnt know waht it was, turned out to be fried shrimp siumai hahahahaha, thought that was funny that was good too but of course, since its fried hahaha.
Had some others, cant really remember but it doesnt matter. It was all very very good. And topped it off with a big bottle of Sapporo~

We also had the tamago to end it all with, I have to say their tamago was good but it could of been better...but they do make their own tamago so that actually says a lot about this place. A lot of places out there use packaged tamago. You see I'm quite picky when it comes to tamago, I'm a tamago guy....And since I've already been subjected to Tani's heavenly tamago, my standards on tamago are very high hahahaha

Overall this place is by far the best sushi boat joint in San Francisco. I wont go to any other sushi boat. Their service was quick and polite and nice. That tall gentleman with glasses even came by and asked how everything was. Look now, remember I'm talking about sushi boat, I'm not comparing this place to Koo and all those other places. Its effing sushi boat. Dont compare two different things, its like apples and oranges. 

For a sushi boat joint this is my top pick!! Puts a smile on my face this big   ^_________________^
author: phillip w.

description:
Kaiten-zushi is always a crap shoot, but it's nice when you roll a seven.

Yesterday, after spending several hours doing gardening, the roommate and I were starving for food and protein. Add in an out of town guest who has celiac disease, and therefore has problems with soy sauce (luckily he had has gluten free bottle with him) and a boyfriend who abhors seafood (wtf), and it sounds like sushi is a weird idea. but the seafood-o-phobe picked the place... so you'd reckon there is something for him to eat.

Being a sunday night at almost 8:30PM it was busy but not packed - we had to wait a scant 5 minutes to fit our part of four at the bar. It's a relatively small place, and the boat line is not very long, so most of the food doesn't spend much time spinning before it is gulped down. The fish was all very fresh and tasty. Stand out items were the unagi (which we had to special order - but worth it), and the albacore. 

Is this awesome sushi? No. Is it very good sushi? Yes! And it's relatively cheap, and when there is not a long line, a quick meal. The staff is very nice, too.
author: neil c.

description:
Ultimate Instant Gratification.

I can always be swayed when I can actively participate/interact in any way with my meals.  Warakabune gives me, a slight control freak with unpredictable expectations, a chance to take the lead in my own dinner destiny....freakin sweet.

Walk in, sit down, eat food.  Choose this, dis that, try this, pass that ooooh how I love choices.  The plates are yes small, but pretty cheap.  The upside is that you can try a lot of different sushi, the downside is that when you're done and you stack all your little plates with your partner in crime you feel like fat asses!

On that note, it's sooooo worth it.  I love the act of grabbing the plates off of the circulating boats of pleasure.  Who ever thought of this is a damn genius.  Although the fish quality is not superior, it's right for the price, and the quickness with which you are served.  Cheers to my favorite new place in the Castro.
author: Rachel P.

description:
I still love this place...and now more so because they had a special kobe beef sushi I got to try.

One thin slice of kobe beef over rice...it was delicious and melts in your mouth - yum..
author: Jade B.

description:
I showed up here drunk.

I hadn't intended to, but...well.  There you have it. I was drunk.

I was on a bad date.

It started with him taking me to the top of Twin Peaks with a bottle of wine. 

Nice touch, but he basically killed it by proceeding to talk about his ex for 2 hours.

Yeah, so I drank while he talked.

I don't remember if I suggested Warakubune or if he did.  Must have been me, because I know how awesome it is to sit down and start eating RIGHT AWAY.

That's the magic of sushi boat.  You sit and you grab and you stuff yourself silly.  

Or that's how it goes when you're drunk at sushi boat.  

The great thing about Warakubune is that the fish isn't questionable.  I don't have to stress out over raw fish diseases.

At the restaurant, he continued to talk.  I continued to eat.  That's the thing with talkers, you can always eat faster and eat more then them.  They're too busy talking about their ex girlfriends. 

Oh well, more for me then!

I ate and ate and stacked the plates so high you could play a game of jenga.

Thank you Warakubune, for making a bad date...not so bad.
author: Jen I.

description: My family and I have been customers for many years and we always compare other sushi restaurants to this one.  The sushi is always fresh and the service is attentive. Have not had a single bad experience.   It's not surprising they have a loyal following given the high quality and freshness of the sushi. No need for garnishes, trendy decor or extras when you get high quality sushi.  We are gratified by each meal here more than Blowfish or many other sushi places we've been to.  The only other place we frequent is Ozumo in downtown SF when we're willing to splurge a little.  Good value is highly important to me.
author: Chris D.

description:
Once again a stickler on Sushi. Yes, i'm a sushi snob, and I believe this place is your average Kaitenzushi. 

Food: Not bad sushi, it's average. But the fun of this is goin there and picking your favorite dishes off the floating boats. I believe there could have been a larger selection of sushi. No one fish in particular stood out... although poor pink fish though (dont remember what fish it was, but it was pink) no one seemed to like it though, it kept going around n around n around...oh how lonely! 

Service: Not bad service. Average, and nothing to complain about. And they were friendly enough. 

Environment: Well it's sushi boat, so if you come with a group of people, esp on a Friday night, you'll have to wait a little for chairs to open up next to each other. The wait wasn't horrendous when I went with four people. Otherwise, you can sit at the tables in the back and you can still get the sushi...just have to walk up to the bar. 

I wouldn't mind coming back if I want some instant gratification of sushi. Just remember its Church & 16th so parking is difficult.
author: Catherine O.

description:
For starters, I had a hell of a time remembering what the name of this place was so I could Yelp it. The name is great though, even if I can't remember it.

A friend took me here for the first time and it was quite a welcome refuge from the cold SF night.  The boats are always fun. Who doesn't love boats that float around and serve you delectable treats?

With my 1st home improvement job under my belt, I wonder if I can build one of those bad boys in my apartment...

Good selection of eats, yummy green tea and beer beer beer.
I could easily eat here, hit Bi-Rite, and go home happy.
What a lovely city this is!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Juliane, Steven, and I came here for dinner tonight.

We walked in around 6:40pm and the sushi bar was FULL! We waited for a good 20 minutes and our seats by the sushi bar finally opened up for the 3 of us. If you get the chance to come by here you should really try the salmon, its really fresh! I also tried octopus for the very first time tonight! It wasn't as good as I thought it would be but it was worth a try. I really liked their unagi roll since it was still hot when I ate it. 

This place is pretty small for a sushi place but the rolls are pretty damn good. It's a little pricey since I only had around 7 dishes including bf's to-go food it was $38 total including tip. I'll suggest to come here only if you're willing to splurge for good sushi.
author: Tracy A.

description:
My goodness, I can't believe I have been on Yelp 2 years now and still haven't reviewed my favourite Sushi place.

When I first landed here fresh off of UA 955 from London some four years ago my friends took me here as a way of welcome and as an introduction to some of their favourite haunts.  

Four years on this place is still consistently great and everytime I go there I'm welcomed back like an old friend.

You've no doubt read the reviews suggesting that you forego the menu and order some of their 'secret menu' items and I can say that it is great  advice.  A word of warning though, if you are a sushi purist and find the American contribution to the cuisine distasteful I might suggest you look elsewhere as their strengths lay elsewhere.  For those that like a roll or two then may I suggest you grab a table in the back and tell Tiffany that I sent you...

Ordering is easy, say yes to Sake.  I like the warm stuff myself and then get yourself the following:

1. Spicy White Tuna

Little chunks of yellow fin tuna served with baby cherry tomatoes and a great spicy mayo like dressing.  Now with fish this fresh and tasty I would usually say let go of the sauce and eat it naked but the dressing they use here is well matched to the fish.  The freshness of the tuna means that it stands out against the delicately spiced sauce and once the tuna melts away your taste buds will be rewarded with a little sweet heat that cleans everything down for the next mouthful.

2. Tempura Special Roll

Ok so it is tempura fried shrimp, wrapped in sushi rice, then avocado and doused in some more of the delicious spicy sauce from above.  I don't think anything else needs to be said other than make sure you get an end piece before anyone else does.

3. Asparagus Special Roll

Tempura fried asparagus wrapped in sushi rice then some nori.  Sounds simple but the freshness of the veggies and the saltiness of the nori makes a match made in heaven.

4. Tatake

Crazy good marinated fatty tuna, sliced deftly and laid over a well cooked ball of rice.  I sometimes like to get this as a sashimi piece but whichever way you slice it the freshness can't be beat.

So here is the best bit, I can't remember the last time I paid over $25 a head for anything less than a very full belly!  

Warakabune rocks.
author: Tony S.

description:
I've been frequenting this place for years....
They always remember me, and exactly what i want.....
Yes the white tuna with little sliced onions&ginger sauce melts in your mouth....(i could eat them all night....)
The tempura rolls....screaming unreal.....
Yes there are boats going around the bar.....but don't let that turn you off...if u want something u don't see ASK FOR IT...
Every person i've ever taken here, has loved it...
and so do i...just wish they were open mondays and tuesdays....
author: jonathan b.

description:
They have some special menu items that were quite good 

- yam & taro roll -- It's not on menu, but MUST try!! 
- spicy hamachi sashimi - pretty good 
- curry fish roll - interesting, not sure had curry sushi roll before

The house special roll ( tempura shrimp with Avocado & crab) was average
author: Coco L.

description:
I'm very wary of sushi boat places.  I usually write them off as a tourist gimmick.  But I'm reasonable.  I'll only really do that if the fish sucks too.  So I was pleasantly suprised with Warakabune.  Fish was fresh. And they had a yummy tempura roll with avocado on top.  

No wait for a Saturday night at 9pm, but enough people to still be lively.  You don't ever want to go to an empty sushi place.  That means zero turnaround.  But for boat places especially, the rolls go round and round so many times that you know the rice is going to be all hard and the fish is going to be all rubbery.  But the turnaround is good at Warakabune.  Everything felt like it was fresh coming off the boat.
author: Audrey T.

description:
The kitschy electronic japanese greeting when you walk in the door is cute.  And the interior is fairly well decorated.  And the prices are fairly reasonable.  And the fish is relatively fresh.  And the portions are generous.  And the wait staff is attentive and nice.

Why the two stars, you may ask?  Well, this is one of those boat places.  The little boats float around and around.  At most other places, the boats carry delicious fresh sushi.  At Warakabune, the half-empty boats carry crusted-over rolls that have clearly been floating around and around for hours.  And it's not like the place is empty...it was a Saturday night, and 2/3's of the seats around the boat bar were filled with hungry people.

To add insult to injury, the boats themselves were filthy.  Now, I'm no clean freak, but the few grains of rice, sesame seeds, and a couple of smears of sauce on the boat are just nasty in a Japanese restaurant.  Everything is supposed to be clean, neat, and fresh...and this place fails that.  What's worse, is the boats are eye-level and 12 inches from your face, so you're constantly looking at the filthy boats drift by.
author: Eugene F.

description: I'm not sure how this place gets an average of four stars.  It's OK, but not as good as other sushi places within a two block radius.  We sat at the sushi moat (ridiculously crowded and difficult to move your arms to your plate), and although there were a few tasty things (the roe was particularly good), the basic sushi items like tuna and whitefish were awful. Especially the tuna. I didn't know raw fish could have gristle, but apparently it can. Would not go back here.
author: Michael C.

description: I have been going to Warakubune for years. It is my favorite sushi in the city and when I have sushi anywhere else it feels like I am cheating on Tiffany and Benji. When I first found the place I'd frequently go for just the sushi. Then I ran into Tiffany in my neighborhood and it was one of those occasions where I said "Hi" knowing that I knew  her but not being able to place where or how. Tiffany and I had a good laugh over that the next time I went in. Now I am treated like a rockstar whenever I come in. Benji and Tiffany will always go out of their way to make my favorite dishes. Even friends whom I have sent there and told them to introduce themselves as a friend of mine get special treatment. They are the best and not just for the food.
author: Ann H.

description: I love Warakabune. The special roll and spicy white tuna are the best things ive ever put in my mouth. the fish is awesome....
author: Leslie H.

description:
My very first 'sushi in boats' experience. I like how you West Coasters roll with that. Aside from being adorable, it also easily facilitates getting sushi quick. Prices are also very reasonable. 

For a large group, they easily accommodated us in the back room area. No entertaining boats, but you are able to go to the boat area and grab little plates to your hearts content. 

Service was friendly and they kept the hot tea a-comin' . . . quite a good taste in my mouth of how SF rolls, sushi style.
author: Deanna J.

description:
Not bad man. 

Usually floating boat train sushi places suck. But this place was actually tasty. 

Fairly priced too. I definitely enjoyed their rolls. A lot of variety makes for much needed second trip.
author: Eugenia Y.

description:
Can be hit or miss depending upon when you go, but it's basically a solidly reliable, thought mostly unspectacular sushi joint. The best part of this spot is, of course, the sushi boats. You can grab something off one of the boats immediately upon sitting, so the instant gratification aspect makes Warakubune a good choice if you're starving and craving quick sushi. 
What's awesome: The Shrimp Tempura special roll topped with avocado and crab, the asparagus tempura roll, the spicy white tuna sashimi, pretty much all of the nigiri options. 

What's not so awesome: The unagi handroll. Hard to eat, and the addition of the spicy tuna just didn't go well with the sweetness of the unagi.
author: Becca V.

description:
This place is great for sushi, sashimi and/or drinks .  I live a few blocks from this place and love to take friends who visit the city here or just go with some city friends.  The wait is usually not long (I think I waited 10 minutes once) and the food and price is great.  Also, they have actual boats that go around with sushi so it's cool to see/experience.  On top of that the staff is always courteous and helpful and very attentive if you need anything.

While there are other places with better sushi, the all-around experience here always brings me back for more every month or so.

I highly recommend the House Special Sushi Roll.  It is a huge rainbow roll with tempura in the middle and is drizzled in two delicious sweet sauces.  While it's not the healthiest roll (and likely on the opposite end of the spectrum) it is extremely delicious.
author: Bryce G.

description:
After having lived in Japan for a whole year, I have enough authority to certify that this place totally kicks ass! Sushi boats generally suck, period. However, this one is a twinkling exception.  I could stare at the gondolas and their raw drivers all night long.  

Nearly everything is served fresh and comes in peachy sizes. White tuna sashimi with ponzu sauce is a MUST!  Not to mention, their signature tempura roll covered with avoado layers and smothered in spicy mayonnaise zest....... and it's kinda rare to find sake (salmon) that actually melts in the mouth, you moan as it dissolves.

Some Yelpers whined about the decor, who cares!?! The food more than makes up.  

Freshness is honesty.
author: Jesada P.

description:
A friend of mine LOVES this place and introduced me to it.

Don't bother with the boat...sit down and order.  Sushi is really fresh and not overpriced.

It's pretty fast service.  

This place can get busy so plan ahead.
author: Diego S.

description:
Attention Sushi Snobs:
Its sushi boats.  And not especially good sushi boats.

You know, I would give this place 2 stars, but every once and awhile, i get that sushi boat craving.  and i come here, cause its close to my place, and because the sushi won't kill me.

But a word to the wise, stay away from the roe here.  It seems to come in all different colors, but it all tastes like rubber.  

Stay simple, stay safe.
author: Steve S.

description:
Sushi boats: Where within SECONDS of sitting down, a piece of sushi "swims" by and into my mouth. It's "urban fast food" and it's always yummy.

The staff are smiley, helpful and always fill my tea cup.
The avocado rolls, asparagus and spicy carrot rolls are ALWAYS good (and plentiful). Get there early cuz this place fills up quick.

Note: Only open Wed-Sun.
No sushi boats on Mondays or Tuesdays!
author: Shelley S.

description: I really do not like to write negative reviews, but this was by far the worst sushi experience I have ever had in San Francisco. The one star goes for their super fast service, since the food was just inedible. Everything we ordered somehow had a coat of some sweetish sauce on it, nothing tasted remotely authentic, and the sushi looked awful (matching the taste). It was not even cheap compared to what you can get at other sushi places a short walk from this joint. I really tried to see something positive (because of all the positive Yelp reviews that tricked us into going here), in vain. I would never go back to this place.
author: Katya F.

description:
All I have to say is: HELLO INSTANT GRATIFICATION!!! 

California rolls, avocado makki, some ridiculously good tempura roll topped w. avocado and two types of sauce...they just kept coming and coming!!! Freaking awesome.

I highly recommend the "Special Roll." As the name suggests, it truly is special :)
author: Shannon R.

description:
I LOVE Warakubune. I've been twice and both times were w/n the last week. I know the SushiBoat thing is a little kitschy, but its just the right kind of kitsch. If you're a small party and at the bar, the sushi floats around and looks lovely and delectable and some of the plates (of 3 fish, or 6 veggie) are under two bucks. You won't spend too much here..AND you'll get arguably better sushi than at most of the riitzy places in the Mission (Tokyo Go Go) or Marina (Mas Sake).

The second time back I was saki-bombing and not a waitress batted an eyelash or looked disapprovingly at the loud mess of boys at my table. I was proud to take my crowd here and can't wait to introduce it to more of my friends.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Don't be modest, grab every roll that looks good. You can't go wrong.
No Name is cheap and decent, right? But it took me too long to walk across the street and try Warkabune. Oh my god! Yeah, its not as cheap but it is so damn good. The fish is so fresh and the rolls are off the hook. I have been back too many times and still can't remember the names. So if you find your self describing the rolls with hand gestures don't worry the chefs will understand. I most deffinatly recommend the spicy tuna sashimi with the red tomato in the middle... let me know if you know the real name.
author: Erin W.

description:
Warakubune floats my sushi boat!  

This is the best Sushi I have had in San Francisco.  Makes me miss Saito's in Seattle:
  http://www.yelp.com/biz/saitos-japanese-cafe-and-bar-seattle#hrid:FgqCWg5EC6C2lhl_AQ4Luw/query:saito

If you plan on dining at Warakubune, go with an appetite and splurge.  It is an experience well worth the time, money and sometimes the wait.
author: Roger M.

description:
Unremarkable and over-priced. I have been known to throw down many dollars for good sushi as well as enjoy sushi deals at less expensive joints. This was a disappointing experience and I am surprised by the good reviews.

The service was awful. In fact, while I was sitting, a couple came in and were asked to wait. There were clearly several seats open but for some reason, they were not seated. I saw the servers walking back and forth but they didn't seem to be unusually busy. The couple finally walked out after standing there having been ignored for about 10-15 minutes. 

Unless what I wanted was floating by on a sushi boat, it took forever to get anything (cup of water, menu, check, etc.). The uni (sea urchin) did not seem very fresh, so I wondered if that rumor that "specials" are actually things the chef wants to get rid of before they go bad is true. When I pay extra for a "special" I do expect it to be very good, silly me.  I then ordered amaebi (sweet raw shrimp). When the server brought the amaebi to me, he told me that instead of the regular price on the menu, the amaebi would be more expensive that night, because it was "special amaebi." I don't know why he didn't mention that when I ordered it - wouldn't that have made more sense? Anyways, it tasted fine but nothing extraordinary. I have no idea why I was charged extra.

The sushi boat offerings were skimpy and the reason I ordered off the menu was that the same, unappealing items kept floating by.  The green salad was nice and much larger than the teeny salads usually served at sushi restaurant.  Other than that, I left feeling rather disappointed with the experience, slightly hungry, and $40 poorer.
author: akimbo j.

description:
Full disclosure:  we came here at 8:45 on a Sunday night when they closed at 9:30 and were closed for the next two days... the fish would NOT be the freshest available.

The boats had a decent amount of food, but the variety wasn't huge when we got there and dwindled as we ate.  

The fish went one way or the other... the salmon was yummy, the mackerel was not.  The white tuna (which was recommended by people on both sides of us) was good, the tobiko was lacking in flavor.  We also had the Special Roll as recommended to us by the people around us (shrimp tempura, topped with avocado and kani salad) was good, but only because it was prepared fresh and the tempura was still warm.  

Service was ok.  They were always running around, but were never there when you needed something.  When we ordered sushi it took much longer than it should have to get to us.

Since it was a Sunday night before closing there were plates overflowing with tuna and mackerel that were put on the boats as they tried to dump their supply... definitely the best value if you're into that sort of thing.

Two of us ate a decent amount for $65.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Neighborhood sushi gem that serves good quality sushi on sushi boats.  Go there often enough to know that the sushi guy's name is Ben and the server's name is Tiffany.  Not very Japanese names but they aren't Japanese and that's ok coz the food is what matters and they pass the mark. 

I love Sushi Zone but who wants to wait in that crazy line for hours.  This is the next best place to get my fix of sushi.  Don't bother going to Miyabi which is a block away on Church.  The quality of Miyabi has gone down the tube with new owners.
author: Anna C.

description: Excellent sushi. Small place but very nice ambience. My favorite part is the sushi boat in the middle mixed with tables to provide an intimate feel. I got the unagi donburi which was really good. Good portion and they were generous with the unagi. The boyfriend got the sushi assortment which was good too. Well worth the 5 stars.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
i was IN LOVE wit this place for awhile that i seriously think i went here at least once a week.  For sushi boat, this is the place to be!!  sushi boats aren't usually as fresh b/c you don't know how long those little plates been swimming around the table for, but at WARAKUBUNE, its FRESH!  

the pieces of fish are huge with just the right amount of rice.  Their UNAGI are the BEST, its HOT when it comes out and just melts in your mouth!!  they use just the right amount of sauce unlike other restaurants.  You'll find yourself licking the sauce off the plates.  

i only have 1 complain about this place, they do not have much rolls.  but the dragon roll is really good too! and if u go there enough, sake is on the house =)

PRICE : decent about $3-4 per plate.  its about $50-$60 for 2 people every time i go

Parking : depends on your luck.. go early and weekdays
author: Anna W.

description: Love that they have sushi boats. My favorite plates were probably the hamachi and spicy tuna. Also ordered the oyako don from the kitchen.. definitely not one of their specialties. Not bad, but their selection of sushi was limited, and we left hungry even though our bill was high.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Foreplay for sushi...

...it starts slow, have some tea, get comfortable in your seat, maybe get a Sapporo or some sake, take in the pleasant but standard decor, have a chat with person next to you about how ready you are to eat sushi...

...then it happens, you notice something float by that just might fulfill that urge so you reach out and gently tear it from its buoyant bedroom...

...is it going to satisfy you, who knows , maybe, maybe its just the beginning, maybe you just opened a door to dangerous land of floating fish. Maybe its the start of three hour long feast of sushi that just gets better the longer you sit there.  

At Warakubune that is the case for sure.  Before you know it your hair is messed up, you have a cramp in your left calf, your satisfied but wondering if your going to get a call the next day...
author: Don I.

description:
Mediocre sushi on little wooden boats.  Whoo Hoo!!  
I like to pretend that the sushi are little people on the most terrifying "Small World" ride ever imagined.  Then I act like a 200 ft. tall man eating little people.  
Mediocrity necessitates imagination.
author: Patrick A.

description:
I've been eating at Warakabune for the better part of a year, and I have to say it is my favorite sushi place around.  While I'm sure one can find higher "quality" sushi, even though that means something different to everyone, Warakabune offers delicious rolls at reasonable prices.  

Perhaps I prefer this joint to others because I am not afraid of going in there hungry.  I know very well that I can eat 8 plates off the sushi boats and not break the bank.  And when there is no wait, nothing is better than just sitting down and eating right away.  If you happen to have a hankering for miso soup, sake, or a special roll, the waiters are always there and very easy to flag down.  

To top off the great experience, they give the option of writing-up individual bills.  This is amazing when out with friends as there doesn't have to be that inevitable person that ends up paying out the difference between the bill and what people have offered.
author: Dylan D.

description: We have tried a few other sushi boat places in the city, and this one has proven to be the best.  Decent variety, and fresh.  Two things that are sometime difficult to find at other boat places.
author: Travis S.

description:
I am a sushi snob.  I will say that up front. :-) I usually avoid the boat places, but every now and then I try to fairly test my biases. 

The fish just isn't that great.  I have a hard time with not-so-great fish now that I know what really good fish tastes like.

The funny thing is that really good sushi is maybe only 50% more expensive than this place.  It's worth paying extra for the good stuff.
author: Matthew K.

description:
**Melody of Merry-go-Around**
"The little sushi boats go round and round...round and round...round and round....the little sushi boats go round and round...all in front...of  me.." =)

Although I'm really opposed to going to Japanese restaurants owned by Chinese ppl...Warakubune seem to be an exception for me. I've been here a few times and each time their quality in sushi was consistent. The parking situation can be quite difficult at times, it's all a competition btwn them and many other businesses and local residents, it really depends on your luck...we typically have to park on a average of two blocks away each time, but it's a nice neighborhood so we don't really mind the walk. Every time we come here, there's always a wait...they have a dry erase board by the door where you can write your name down. Average wait time is about 15 minutes. There is basically one big area for sushi boats up front and a small area for table-seating in the back right by the bathroom and kitchen. The seats around the sushi boats were quite packed...there isn't really much space btwn you and the person next to you...you can literally hear everybody's conversation around you.   

I am typically a happy camper when I come here. I mean, I come hungry and there's food ready right in front of me all-I-can-eat! What more can I ask for?! The sushi are yummy. Really made fresh and made with fresh ingredients. Like I've said before, I have been here more than once and they ARE consistent with the quality of food. I really like their unagi, kani (made with real crab meat), ebi, fresh raw oysters, and spicy tuna rolls. They are simply delicious. I don't really eat raw food so I don't eat sashimi...but the ones that I see look really fresh as well. I would highly recommend their sushi here. 

Service is usually decent here. Things get cleaned up quick, orders get filled fast, and of course getting the bill was THE fastest. Usually I have no complaints, but there was one thing that bothered me this visit. It was that I almost got ran over by the same busboy/waiter twice and he did nothing about it. I know he is doing his job very well by attending to everyone's needs, but still, don't run me over TWICE when your doing it and not even acknowledge it! A simple "excuse me" would've been nice! I HATE RUDE PPL!! I think they really should have better training on their waiters as far as it comes to attitude and manners. A successful business is not just about it's food, but it's about it's services as well. In this case, they didn't really deliver and that's why they only deserved 4 stars.
author: Winnie L.

description: Spicy white tuna sashimi...off the hook!!  It not often you can find a sushi boat restaurant that has fresh sushi.  I guess the place is always filled that it's not common that items stay on a plate for long.   What I appreciate in particular about this place is that you don't have to place large orders to taste different types of sushi (when you are at the bar).  You can always order what you like and it's made to order by the sushi chefs, who are always really cool.  Bottom line, I can always count on their sushi being FRESH and service being outstanding.
author: Adrian N.

description:
Love it. 

Alot of the right-off-the-boat sushi is pretty generic, but ask for the "house special." They'll make it for you (yes, special). 

I can eat about twelve of the special before I can't eat anymore and must be content with going home to daydream about the special for the next three days.
author: Gabe S.

description: Absolute best sushi boat place I've even been to. I'm sure there's a word for that. The kinda place where the sushi goes around on a little boat conveyor and you grab whatever looks good. Let me say, most of it looked good & most of it was fantastic. Even the roe wasabi roll which I hesitated to eat was excellent. In short, it was immediate gratification of deliciousness. Plus, it was very reasonably priced.
author: Jen M.

description:
I can't stop thinking about this place since I went there a few weeks ago. When I found out my friends and I were eating at a sushi boat restaurant, I was weary. Sushi boats don't offer very fresh items as they've been sitting out - ignored by patrons. Luckily for Warabubune, items are grabbed quickly and replaced just as fast. You might have to wait a while for a certain dish but for a first timer, it's a great way to try new items you'd never think about. The items are a great price for the amount of fresh fish they offer. 

Now, I wish I could make it out there sometime soon. I can't stop thinking about the food. This place is comfortable enough for patrons that are eating alone. I can't wait to go back!

A+ to the albacore. Mmmm.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Not sure why so many positive reviews. I decided to try this after a friend of ours went a few times and seeing such good reviews. The sushi doesn't seem that fresh and the variety not big. Flavor not that great. boring variety. Had cream cheese (??) in one of my sushi rolls. They pour alot of sauce to mask the blandness on many of the dishes. After "snacking" we spent $60! Quite expensive for the low quality. We normally can get stuffed and bring food home when we go to a fave sushi place in Sunset....or go to Sushi XXX in SM and just spend $30 more and it is quality. We won't be returning.
author: Tiffany W.

description: I LOVE this place!  I started coming here not long after moving to SF and I have not stopped since.  I've only eaten in the back room twice because the boats are definitely where it's at.  If you get here around 6pm all the good stuff starts coming out and you can watch the guys make it and put it directly on the boats so you know it's fresh!  The quality is really good!  They have some of the standard rolls but also have a lot of rolls that are unique to this restaurant.  If there's something that you want that's not floating around on the boats, it's really easy to just order from on of the servers walking around.  If you haven't been here yet, you should try it immediately... you won't be sorry!
author: Ali K.

description: Okay for me the food was somewhere between okay to great, the reason why i am giving this place a 4 star is because of the sushi boat they have inside which i find really cute. The food is also pretty fresh, which is why i decided to give this place a 4 star. The service was okay i guess, i'm pretty sure the boat makes it somehow a tad bit harder to see the waitress and order stuff, but i am pretty satisfied with this place, the uni and saba were great!
author: Cavin T.

description:
Friday night, I have a sushi craving that's out of control.  We walk down to Warakabune and entered sushi bliss. There was a short wait- not at all bad for a Friday night. We sat down and eyed the lovely sushi floating on the teensy boats. We had an out of this world spicy tuna roll, some tasty shrimp dumplings, seaweed salad, avocado rolls, some more spicy tuna, miso, edamame, etc etc. Also shared a small sake.  All of this combined was $35 for two of us! 

Only drawback is that you have to be quick with your hands to snag the sushi on the passing boat. I misfired on the quick draw and dumped seaweed salad on the boat. Ooops!
author: Dana K.

description: Excellent quality -- sushi had just enough rice (not too much) & very tasty rice too.  Sushi slices were very fresh & in generous portions. Only place I've seen here so far that uses FRESH crab for kani sushi.  Quick service & very accommodating!
author: ana w.

description: Donburi!!!  You know it was just one of those days when I was having a craving for raw fish over rice.  Not just sushi pieces.  Like fish and a vat of rice.  So I started searching for places that served donburi and that was open on Sundays.  Warakubune came up, so we went with.  Got there pretty early (a little before 6:00).  so the place was fairly empty.  they seated us right away at the sushi boat bar, which I wasn't really expecting, but when in Rome.  We had to ask for their menu with entrees etc.  And there it was.. donburi!!  They have several donburi selections.  We go the tekka and sake.  They were both delicious.  The fish tasted very fresh.  The cuts of sake were very tasty... tender and fatty.  And the rice was perfectly seasoned.  Yeah they serve one grape tomato as garnish (saw one reviewer complain about that), but c'mon.  It's garnish.  That's like complaining bc your steak came out with a sprig of parsley.  We also started chowing down on the sushi that was rotating before us.  Kind of hard not to when you are starving.  have to say, was very surprised by the quality of the sushi boat offerings.  The spicy white tuna tataki nigiri was reallly good. the mounds of scallions on top really hit it.  also good were the negihama maki and what I think was toro.  they definitely had some interesting rolls going around.  we ended up grabbing a salmon/crab/avocado/cream cheese roll at the very end bc we were still hungry.  I wasn't a fan of that roll.... too much cream cheese.  But overall, I really liked this place.  The service was very attentive.  And by the time we left, the place was packed.
author: Ash T.

description: love, love, love this place!!! great sushi, great customer service!! i love Tiffany!
author: Agustin G.

description: Excellent, came here with groupon, had Gansta, Zen Garden, and Dragon rolls. YUM! I am not a huge roll fan, but these were great. Presentation perfect, taste same.
author: Dan W.

description:
We've been coming here for about 8 years now.  It's become a place that we go to as a family because of their warm and welcoming atmosphere as well as the kick ass sushi boat.  The owners are a couple and are real nice to us and especially our son, who always get a complimentary green tea ice-cream from the mom who absolutely adores him.  The dad, sushi chef, always prepare special rolls and nigiri for us that's off the menu (special requests like no wasabi or extra dose of sea urchin).

The pricing is just right, the food is excellent, it's cozy, and the service is quick and friendly.  This place is wonderful and we'd like to keep it to ourselves.
author: Joselito S.

description: I thought this place was a great alternative for fast food. I can get my fix on sushi.  Now the price isn't too great there is about three pieces of sushi roll or 2 piece of nigiri on plate (at most you pay $3.95 per plate. the prices are set by the design of the plate the sushi was on) but if you are hungry it adds up... But it's fast. you sit down, they give you nice hot towels to wipe your hands, and you can go at it! It's Quick and tasty. They also have udon or ramen noodles on the menu. Tried the chasu ramen, wasn't bad, the soup wasn't too tasty but noodle was good and they threw in some spinach in the soup for extra good vitamin B.  This place is great  before 7p when it is less crowded.
author: Kaori T.

description: We decided to go to Warakubune to get some sake and warm up on our walk home. Hadn't been in here for years but thought we'd also get a snack too - ended up with a big pile of plates for the waitress to count up. Unfortunately, the sake was lame. Supposed to be hot but only lukewarm. Had much better elsewhere. But the sushi was great. Larger rolls and most nigiri need to be ordered. The boats were largely empty and the ones that had sushi were mostly the same. But as the seats filled up so did the boats. Very tasty and not outrageously priced. Will come back again.
author: Steven V.

description:
The food here is a little above average.  But I gave it 4 stars for the excellent service.  My friend and I came in on a Monday night and it wasn't crazy crowded but there were still people coming in and out constantly.  We stayed 3 hours and the waiter must have filled my tea cup at least 10+ times.  They didn't try to push us out or anything.  And every other person who came in knew the head waitress by name.

The sushi was good.  The cold seaweed was probably my favorite.  I'm not always the biggest fan of the sushi boat thing, but you can easily ask the chef to make anything you want.  My friend was a fan of the fried shau mei (chinese owned) but I thought it was ok.  I'd definitely come back again.
author: Chuck P.

description:
i like to review restaurants in different cities than where i live.  i think it makes me look cool.  it probably doesn't though.

when i come to san francisco, i come to warakubune.  why?  sushi boats, hello???  i'm easily entertained.  make food, put on plate, put in boat, castaway on water, me grab food.  eat food.  stack plates.  want more?  it keeps coming.  my favorite is when i'm contemplating if i should grab another and then it gets away from me.  damn boats.

the rolls are so good.  the best is the crab salad.  they make it so that the mayo doesn't taste like hellman's.  can't ask for more.

i'm gonna keep coming back (right when it opens for dinner), because that's what the food on the water in the boat does.  it keeps coming back.

(afterward, go to mitchell's down the street for some ice cream, of the ube variety.  yes, i'm filipino, how'd you know?)
author: Kris R.

description: With so many great sushi joints in the city (some even walking dist from this place), why do it.  Nice people, but no attention given to good service.
author: Aaron C.

description:
My favorite sushi house in the city.  Great rolls, great staff, and sake hookups for regulars.  It makes me look forward to sunday nights.

I eat like a viking (and drink like one) whenever I come to this place yet, despite my tower of little plates,  the bill is somehow less than I would expect.  

This place turned me on to unagi too.  If you asked me a few years ago to try some eel I would have made a sour face and said 'let's get some tacos'.  But now I can't get enough of the stuff.  Be sure to also try the special roll (avocado/tempura/special sauce.) 

I realized how good this place was when it was closed one weekend and we went to the more low-key place across the street...bland, dry, and not that much cheaper.  Stick to the 'happy boat' that is Warakubune!
author: Neej M.

description:
I'm not telling you where the best seat in the house is - if you don't know already I can't help. 

what I can tell you is that the fish is amazing, order the oysters, order the shrimp tempura roll, order the spicy tuna sashimi (you'll see the tempura and tuna sashimi on the boats - but they never make it a full rotation). 

you can come in for a quick easy meal, or sit down and hang out. don't be afraid to ask the chef for what you want - he'll make you whatever you want.
author: Jen B.

description: This is the best sushi bar I know, hands down. Every time I come to SF, this is a must do. I've never visited and not been introduced to a new favorite sushi creation. A locals favorite that is off the beaten path.
author: Bill Y.

description: After reading other reviews on yelp I thought I'd try this sushi bar, definitely glad I went. It's only a block from the Castro Muni station, so it was super easy to get to.  There were lots of options on the sushi boats and anything that wasn't there could be made to order. I thought a sushi bar in the Castro would be expensive, but this place was very reasonable. I had a large beer and five sushi plates and my bill came to $22. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Amber R.

description: The Special Roll has a crack sauce on it that makes you want to order three more servings. Extremely tasty and makes other sushi pale in comparison.
author: Stari N.

description: This place is pretty good for being a sushi boat resaurant. Usually the sushi on the boats at other places are not fresh, but this place was delicious. The service was ok, and it's a good location.
author: H. A.

description:
Love this place! 
This place came recommended by my buddy, SNX who stumbled upon this boat place when No Name was closed. Since then I've been coming here every weekend for the last 2 years. I was hesitant at first due to it being a boat place and having a Chinese chef n' all but the fish is always fresh, the rolls are deli-sh and the service is friendly.
Also, if you come enough times they will hook you up, so go ahead and try it out ,you WILL love it. Its the most affordable fresh sushi place in the city.
One a side note:
I thank thee SNX and you will always be in my sushi heart for introducing Warakubune to me...well, except when you're high as balls and barking orders for snacks (ie Whole Apple pie or Ginger cake and pumpkin ice cream from Chows), then i'll be more likely to kick and stomp on your nuts, Cartman.
Peace
author: Tak H.

description:
I had never received boat delivered food before. But I caught on fast, real fast. We ate a ton and all of it was made fresh. Because I was scared about the idea of my meal sailing around stopping at unknown ports. 

I would go back, because the instant service really hits the spot when you're starved and the food was pretty good. However it's not the sushi I dream about.
author: Angela K.

description:
What is so dear about this place is what people love in me! Cozy, sweet, and nice! Heh heh. No no, really the place is always warm and inviting on cold days and too cute to boot (also what people like in me... wow am I modest). They have an awesome sushi bar with boats of yumminess sailing by your watering and hungry mouth. I also feel oh-so-special with their willingness to make you one of their special rolls (which I recommend over the sushi boat standards).

Go check it out. One drawback and loss of star is that they don't seem to be open in the afternoon.
author: Ali K.

description:
I've eaten at Warakubune a few times and always enjoyed the food.

I usually order lunch specials and sushi on the side. I like the Teriyaki beef and tempura combo. Can't beat the price either. And the sushi seemed fresh. And the servers and sushi chef are friendly.

I will be coming back again. So many Japanese restaurants to choose from in S.F. and the Peninsula that it could be awhile. I do recommend Warakubune to others who have that craving for Japanese food and/or sushi.

If you're driving, parking can be a prob. Or just park in the corner of the lot at the Safeway on Church & Market Streets.
author: Roger S.

description: This place kicks Kirala's ass. Even though Warakabune is about 50 minutes away from Berkeley via public transit, I am still willing to make the trip once a week for what is clearly the best fish quality available in the Bay. The head sushi chef is very careful in his selection of fish - apparently he hunts down the best he can find in the Bay Area - and it really is the best. The cuts are thick, the sushi boats are always full of surpising and interesting dishes, and the servers are so friendly. It is definitely worth trying any of the tuna's - especially the tuna tataki or spicy white tuna. Basically the fish just melts in your mouth - I call it butter tuna. And, they happen to have quite a good kitchen as well in case you are less interested in the sushi.
author: Jaclyn W.

description:
Warakubune has become a Friday night staple. If not every Friday, at least Saturday or maybe a special weeknight visit. This place even got my good friend Heidi K. to like sushi. Granted she'll eat most rolls that have cooked stuff or are vegetarian - but she actually had a philly roll here and LIKED IT. It was like watching Bambi walk for the first time. 

My favorites:

the spicy white tuna with the orange sauce and grape tomato (jesus I DREAM about this
special tempura roll with crab and avocado on top
(what I think is )hirame with the green onions and hot stuff on the top
ALL the nigiri that floats by

Seriously, I have never been unhappy after leaving here. Just the thought that it's Friday right now and we're probably heading over later on is enough to make me smile. The greeting you hear when you walk in the door makes me chuckle every time. They even know that every. single. time. we come in we will ask for a large nigori sake, and they get it right away. Last time we didn't even have to ask.

The boats don't bother me at all. If anything I like it because it's like instant service. If you see something and don't get it, the chefs are happy to make one special for you. It's a good thing I can't walk here, I'd be in the poor house for sure. Prices are super super good, but obviously sushi is not cheap. If it were I might get a little worried anyways.
author: Michelle B.

description: I don't get it.  The decor and atmosphere are fine, the music was fun, but the sushi was average at best.  Best selection was the tako (octopus) sashimi, generous portion and tasted fresh.  Prices seemed higher than average.  Lots of people seem to like it though, maybe I'm just weird.
author: Brendan H.

description:
I highly recommend this place to anyone.

The sushi is good, not the best in the city, but definitely top side of good. But that's not  the only reason you come here, this place has a sushi bar shaped like a pill capsule in the middle of the main room with the chefs in the middle of a stream of water with boats topped with sushi deliciousness.

Best part of this is that you sit next to folk you don' t know, chat it up and take your time eating. Order some Sapporo and just take your time. 

Prices are a little high, but like I said its good sushi on boats, so it is what it is.
author: Mr. R.

description:
The sushi boats are tethered together and circle around forever, chained to their unrelenting, repetitious destiny. Do we love sushi boats because we are so free to choose and our freedom is that much freer by virtue of the boats' enthrallment?

Sushi was okay, liked the tuna pieces. Noticed that one of the chefs Chinese, but who am I to say a Chinese guy can't make sushi? I think they gave him the easy ones, though. And the strange thing that looked like a burrito covered in seasame seeds. 

There could be a little more order to the seating, but we got seated pretty promptly (at 7:15 on a Saturday night...though it was raining).
author: Tyler S.

description:
My friends and I come here every Wednesday!  

Favorite sushi place in San Francisco.
author: J d.

description:
Saturday night, 5/31, my husband wanted to take my sis and her man out to dinner for their birthdays (one day apart, May 26, 27).  Not sure where to go, wanted to try a new place, and Warakubune was within walking distance.
When we got there, we were seated at a table, but we switched to the sushi bar because the tables and chairs are so close together we felt a little crammed in.  Plus we weren't really impressed with the menu and thought it would be easier to just grab something we saw floating around the "moat".  
There was a bit of a language barrier at first (slightly irritating), but quickly remedied by having a small handful of people waiting our table, most of which speak and understand English.
We asked a waiter for some suggestions off the menu and was very glad we did. 

The food was delicious!  The fish was very fresh!  Along with various rolls, we had some nigiri albacore, and it tasted like a cross between toro and ono, succulent!  And the nigiri eel, the best I've had.  The service is Johnny-on-the-spot and with a smile!
author: Kelly B.

description:
This place is really excellent.  If you luck out, you'll be seated at the drawbridge (just to the right of where the sushi chefs load up the boats-I tried to put this on urbandictionary.com, but they voted me down!).

The service is always good and fellow patrons are always nice.

The Spicy Seafood Salad is really spicy.  Duh......
author: Andrew M.

description:
My favorite Sushi place in the city.  I simply cannot go a week without eating here.  The selection is perfect - not too sparse, not too overwhelming, and you will be hard-pressed not find anything tasty.

Where else can you eat sushi till you're ready to burst, down a large Asahi and two bottles of sake, and not break $100.00 for your meal... for two people!
author: Zachary B.

description:
I have been coming to this place for about 11 years and they always have fresh sushi and good service. There are things I eat here that I would never dare eat anywhere else. I trust the sushi chef 100%.
It is a great place to sit down and have a long meal or go for a quick bite. 

Try them out and you wont regret it. Make sure you get there before 7:30 on a weekend. After that it gets pretty crowded.
author: Michelle G.

description: I didn't really enjoy my experience here, but will give it 3 stars because the fish was  fresh. I feel like I want to give it two stars but that's probably not fair.  We sat at a table, not at the boats, so maybe we made a poor decision there. The rolls we saw on the boats weren't on any menu that we received. Our service wasn't very good but wasn't horrible. It was just really awkward. The seafood salad contained a generous amount of fresh fish and was a pretty good deal for just under $20. I wish I could remember who recommended this place to me so I could ask them exactly what they recommend about it. Otherwise, I probably wouldn't go back.
author: m t.

description:
My girlfriend and I just got back from our weekly sushi boat dinner date. We eat here at least once a week, it's close to our house, the sushi is fresh, delicious and the staff is always friendly. I am slightly addicted to The Special Roll. The Special Roll is a shrimp tempura roll with avocado, a dollop of crab on top, sprinkled with sesame seeds and placed on top of a delicious spicy mayo sauce, so yummy I scrape up the remaining sauce with my chopsticks. We pretty much always grab the same things, Sake, Hamachi, Toro, Special Roll and Uni (when available) and leave full and happy. 

We've noticed that when there's a wait, people are usually waiting to sit at the boat bar so we'll sometimes just choose to sit in the little room in back where the tables are. You can still pick from the boats but it's just as easy to just sit back and order from the menu. 

We'll be back in a few days.
author: Shannon A.

description:
Warakubune is awesome. It's the best boat sushi place in town, the service is excellent & the sushi is great. Their avocado tempura sushi is good, so is all the creative stuff they float. And a big plus is that it's so close to me, I can just roll of my bed and end up there.

Note: Starts getting crowded around 6:30pm. If you are late & there is a long queue don't bother waiting. Just take the tables at the back and walk over to the boats and pick the plates you like & take them back to your table.
author: Divya R.

description:
Say goodbye to your diet when you eat here!

I tend to splurge on the food here because it is fab-u-lous!  The portions are fair and the fish is guaranteed fresh.  Usually I treat myself here when I accomplish anything major as a reward, so I will sit at the bar and grab everything and anything that floats past my way.  There is this one plate with three cubes of fish, topped with tomatoes, green onions and a light buttery sauce.  It is consistency fresh and the fish literally just falls apart in your mouth.  It is so light and buttery at the same time -- yes, it is possible.  In addition, their salmon, tuna, dragon rolls and tempura rolls are perfect.  Eating here is amazing -- ethereal!  

The staff members are all friendly and extremely attentive.  This restaurant is clean and the design is nice.  It is usually crowded during the week nights and unfortunately, they are closed on Mondays.

Once you eat here, all other sushi places in the near vicinity is just plain jane."
author: myiken n.

description:
Since discovery of warakubune I've had dinner here at least weekly!

I love that they have more sushi than just your tuna varity, as I'm alleric. 

YAY for sushi I can eat!
author: Lori F.

description: Just your typical over-crowded SF sushi-boat place. Not that special. Not that awful. Not worth me trying to think of something witty to say about it.
author: Zulu Q.

description:
Some of the best cheap sushi in SF.  There are lots of seats around the sushi boats, but I also prefer the tables in the back. They only get 4 stars from me for the service - it can be unbelievably slow.  There's also not a great selection of drinks, but it's pretty hard to top the deuce-deuce of Sapporo for $5.50.  

Be sure to try the yellowtail, last time I ordered it, it was incredibly fresh.  Swoon.
author: Laura S.

description:
This place is a lot of fun. I don't go to very many sushi on a boat places but the fish here is fresh, they cut large pieces of nigiri, and it's super cheap. Not the most amazing sushi you'll ever eat, but a good mix of everything else (atmosphere, great service, very reasonable prices) to keep coming back.

If you're going to come here, come with one or two other people, sit at the bar, order a large Asahi beer, and start rescuing pieces from the little boats. The 2 dueling sushi chefs on opposite sides of the bar work like madmen and they'll create rolls or cut nigiri to order if don't see something floating by you want.

Between 3 people we ate a ridiculous amount of sushi under 70 bucks. And, I only knocked one plate of sushi off the boat into the water  trying to dive and grab a special shrimp tempura roll...so overall I'd say it was a success.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Three star b/c we had to wait a long time  to get food, but once they got cracking, it was good. If you have not been here, they have boats pass by and you grab your selection and pay accordingly.  See story below. 

5:00 pm Sushi bar opens
5:30 pm Roommate and I arrive very hungry and have seat at the bar. Empty boats pass by,  only options are inari and a California roll. 
5:40 The waitress takes the order from my roommates and walks away as I am asking for my beer. 
5:55 finally some other sushi is added to the selection but no raw fish yet. the guy next to us grabbed all 7 plates  at once anyways and we watch them sit in front of him as and we are still starving. 
Not sure how long we sat there but by the time we left  (over 1.5 hours later) there was plenty of selection of yummy sushi and the place was pretty crowded. If you need something, you just grab one of the servers.  We could of ordered from the menu, but if you want sushi you grab from the boats passing by. They also fill requests.
author: Amy M.

description:
My new favorite neighborhood Japanese restaurant! 

The first time we came here, our server, Henry, asked if we wanted to sit in the back instead of the sushi boat bar because it was more romantic. My bf and I happily sat at a table under dimly light red lights. The atmosphere was perfect. We order entrees - my teriyaki beef was amazing! The beef melted in your mouth and the bf's katsu chicken was just as good. 

We came back for the sushi boat because it's sushi on boats! How fun is that! The sushi was fresh and there was a good variety. If you like spicy tuna - this is the place to go, trust me - it burrrnnnsssss. If you have a specific craving, you can always order it with the server. 

Highly recommend if you want a fun time, good food and great service.
author: Gladys C.

description:
Aside from the fact that the pronunciation of the restaurant name is a total mystery to me, I'm a big fan. In fact, this is my favorite sushi place that I've found since moving to the Bay Area.

While I totally agree with other reviewers- this isn't the most innovative, over the top place you can find- the service is good, turnaround is great, the fish is fresh, the prices are good, and the atmosphere is so fun. This would be a great date place!

Look for the special tempura roll (tempura shrimp, avocado and a little bit of crab on top, all with a sweet brown sauce and a spicy orange sauce that is amazing- we saved the extras and dipped our avocado rolls in it) but be prepared to grab it quickly, as it seems to be in high demand. We also liked the dim sum-style dumplings and the nigiri was excellent.
author: Mariah K.

description:
Pretty good.  Fresh is important, and they do well there.  There are quite a few seats around the moat, and a few tables in back.  I used to like the gingerbread house motif that used to be there but seems to have been changed recently?   

I definitely recommend the tempura asparagus roll.  It doesn't usually last  long on the boat, so best to just order your own dish!
author: Ken B.

description: I am so sad to write this review since this is my favorite sushi place to go to, and when I'm in SF this is my go to spot. After seeing the ultra cool Yoda fountain at the Presidio, I thought it'd be great to take my 4 year old son to my favorite sushi place. He liked the boat but wasn't too keen on eating the sushi, so I ordered him a chicken teriyaki bowl. This is where things went totally wrong. What they brought out looked like pre-sliced and grilled Tyson chicken strips with teriyaki sauce poured all over it. It was pathetic and tasted so generic. This is the biggest blemish to the place. I still love their sushi boats and they have very attentive servers, but I will steer clear of anything else.
author: Kiki C.

description:
I'm not going to lie - I am a sushi snob through and through. So the first time my bestie, who lives around the corner from "the boats" as we call it, took me there I might have raised my nose in amusement at the floating fish. 
I very quickly changed my mind because it's sooooo damn good! The boats are amusing, no doubt. But the fish is always super fresh. And the sushi chefs take pride in their craft. You can grab whatever you want off the rotating boats or you can order your faves from the menu. 
My faves: 
Spicy seared albacore - it does NOT get any better. The tuna is tender, seared perfectly and melts in your mouth. It is topped with a delicate sauce that doesn't take anything away from the tuna. It also has scallions and a tiny tomato on top! Pur-tay! 
Spicy scallops - served warm. Spicy California Roll. If you think you know Cali rolls, think again. They top theirs with spicy sauce and tera root fries. 
The curry fish tempura roll is usually listed on the specials menu, but it seems to be available all the time. It is different and worth a try. 
And as simple as it gets - the tempura asparagus roll - it's divine!! I order it every time. 
So fellow sushi snobs - I say take a chance and try some of the best sushi in the city. Oh, did I mention it will only run you about $20....and that's if you order everything I listed above. No joke. This place rocks my world ;)
author: Shannon K.

description: Best Sushi in the 94114! Everyone who works there is extremely nice and the service is great. There are other sushi places around but this place has boats and dance music. The only thing that I that would make this better is if they were open on Monday and Tuesday.
author: Jose Fernando G.

description: I just moved to the city and this is one of my favorite places. Fresh delicious sushi!
author: Snazzy A.

description: Warakubune I love you and your tuna tataki, special roll, spicy tuna and unagi! I'm addicted and just can't get enough.
author: Marcia G.

description: While there is variety, the portions are small, the prices high and they rush you out if you aren't constantly picking up plates off the boats. We dropped a $100 for two and they treated us as though we didn't eat a thing shushing us out as soon as people were starting to wait by the door.
author: Eric M.

description:
To start off with, I have to thank a friend for showing me the light about this place.  I am ordinarily not attracted to sushi on boats going round n' round in circles for god knows how long, but this place was good.  Only after about 4 times going there for the convincing.

I definitely would have to recommend the Spicy White Tuna Sashimi... spicy tuna??? what, thats so blah right? but their sashimi version is really good.  The fish is fresh, and topped with a great...hmmm...I would say salsa.

The shrimp tempura roll, my god, who knew that thousand island dressing would make a roll taste so damn great.

I do have to say that although I sat at the bar with the boats, I hardly pulled anything from them.  The sushi chef was a great guy who was very attentive to my friend and I, and sometimes just being friendly with the chefs can make a world of difference.
author: Bone D.

description:
Our previous sushi boating at Japantown and then in Outer Richmond was awful!!!  Both places had sushi that had been sitting around too long and not very creative inspiration for their rolls and nigiri.  

Sushi at Warakubune was wonderful!  They really watched the speed at which their patrons ate to send out as fresh a selection as possible.  Their combination of rolls were good and pretty to look at.  A sushi joints spicy tuna is always to me, a good indicator of the rest of their sushi.  Warakubune had excellent spicy tuna.  One particular spicy tuna roll was covered with avocado and a smathering of crab on top.  Their sake, hotate, hamachi, uni was so fresh and and tender.   Just perfect.   

Their menu was varied enough where those (my mom) who like cooked foods had a good selection.  

The friendly waitstaff and sushi chefs were very good, never did we have to ask for more tea and water.   The sushi chefs were happy to take our special orders and smiled politely when we asked for repeats.
author: Regi K.

description:
Sushi was good, maybe not quite great but solid none the less. It was my first time having to deal with the boats, but that part was fine. II never got a menu to tell what they offer outside of the traditional sushi stuff...
I will still go back again!
author: JR H.

description:
I lost my sushi boat virginity last night.  Yep, until yesterday, I've never sat my ass down in front of a sushi boat.  M and J had both been there before so as they were catching up, I just kept taking good looks at the thing.  It was quite the contraption - little boats carrying dishes of fish and rice linked together in a loop with little runners on the side to make the boat glide smoothly over a well of water, all at a calculated mph rate optimal for hungry diners to grab at.  The things people come up with.

Okay, let's talk about the food.  The sushi was freshly made and good enough, but definitely not blow your socks off sushi. ( I know, I know, I've been hard to impress after dining at Yanagi's in Honolulu.)  At Warakubune, the saba was good and fatty, the unagi nicely prepared, but the hamachi was so-so and the spicy tuna roll was way too hot - i think they used too much Sriracha sauce and are they even supposed to use Sriracha sauce?  Anyways, if you need a quick, reliable and economical sushi fix, come here.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Yummy-yummy white tuna sashimi with sesame seeds, scallions, and tomato!

Melts in your mouth!
author: Tasha R.

description:
Sub-par sushi and "Japanese" food made by non-Japanese people. Save your money and go to Osaka, Eiji or Sushi Time instead and get the real thing.

We had our dinner late on a Sunday evening, and I was quite upset when I found out that they had run out of almost every type of fish after we had ordered the first round of sushi. They should have told us that before they sat us.
author: Keau K.

description:
Warakubune? More like, WHACKubune!

But seriously, just had dinner here last night and it was not what we expected after reading all the Yelp reviews. Definitely does not live up to the hype. Yes, the fish is fresh which is almost a scientific anomaly for sushi boat, but the "sushi chefs" were way too young. And not the whole they look young because Asians look young in general thing, but they seriously were young. It's a school night, shouldn't you be at home finishing your geometry proofs? They were uber slow at refilling the boats  and did not believe much in variety as they made the same three things the whole time we were there. 

Also, we know it's a sushi boat place and all, but we saw the same plate of hirame nigiri circle the bar the entire night. Other sushi bune places will pull out plates that have circled for too long as a way to not compromise the freshness of the selection. The child chefs did not do that at all. Tsk tsk.

Maybe it was just an off night, or the real sushi chefs all decided to take the same night off, but we are willing to maybe go back one more time if not only for the ankimo. But probably not.
author: Erk R.

description:
So the idea of food moving by in front of me seemed unappealing.  I mean, maybe its a bit diva-esque, but I like the idea of my food just being on a plate in front of  me, and static.  

But then, I went to Warakubune, or "The Boat" since my friends and I can't actually say the name.  It's so great.  Because of the small portions, you can try a bunch of different things.  And you can always tell the best rolls, because they go fast.  But, you can always special order, so you get exactly what you want.

The people that own the place and work there couldn't be nicer.  

Be sure to write your name on the dry erase board when you walk in, its to your right, its the seating list.   And while we're saying to-do's, be sure to close the door behind you when you come in.  Sometimes it stays open, and it gets super cold!
author: Julie E.

description:
Supreme bizness right here, folks. 

From my experience, most places that offer the novelty of a sushi boat suck. You sit there listening to happy hardcore j-pop jamz and strain your eyes on the glistening piles of disgust that no other diners wanted. 

NO LONGER. 

The sushi is mercury fresh and those the dudes behind the counter rack up 'dem rollz faster than Dozers could build whole crystalline civilizations in Fraggle Rock.
author: Cliff C.

description:
mmmm sushi boat.  I don't know the fancy Japanese names for everything. I just know what I want, and Warakubune delivers. This is my go-to sushi in the city. After a rough day, you'll find me at the sushi dock reaching for lovely rolls and fat pieces of inguri? ninguri? WHATEVER! If I want it, I take it-- I don't have to say it.

I'm a huge fan of their spicy tuna rolls-- I especially love the spicy California, with the crispy bits of fried taro on top. Those will always end up on my bill. 

Timing is everything there-- you definitely want to get there at "prime time" that's when all the good stuff comes out.
author: Pea H.

description:
good sushi right in front of you floating on little boats in water? Perfect.
sometimes you don't want to wait for your food...right? at warakubune - you don't have to or at least you don't have to wait for most of it, AND it is good AND it is fun! 

me rikey.
author: Jenny B.

description:
Their sushi rocks my tiny little world.

Absolute favorite: the spicy white tuna (ask for it by this name exactly as there are other spicy tuna dishes) these tiny pink sesame coated morsels absolutely melt in your mouth. Every time I walk in and sit down the server comes over to me and asks "how many spicy white tuna?" I usually reply "six please". Try it, you will not be disappointed.

Runners up: the special shrimp tempura roll with avocado on top and the asparagus roll 

It's fun to sit at the boat bar, but if you are with a group you can sit in back without much of a wait.
author: Nora B.

description:
By far one of my fave sushi joints and I can't believe it's a sushi BOAT! haha Believe me, I'm not much of a fan with sushi boat restaurants because of the quality and freshness, but this is one place where I don't even worry off the fact that it doesn't have covers! haha It's just an added obstacle to get to your sushi! haha

I love this place! You definitely have to go at the right time! They don't start adding stuff on the boat until 5-6pm. So, try to get there after 6pm to get the GOOD stuff! Yeah, it can get crowded at the sushi boat area, but it's definitely worth the wait. Although, I never really had to wait.

The service is just amazing! I love attentive servers especially when it gets busy and believe me, this place gets packed pretty quick. I like the fact that the waiters/waitresses make an effort to make sure you are okay and if you are in need of anything.

The sushi is very fresh and tastey! I was never a fan of asparagus, but this place completely changed my mind. Try their asparagus roll, it's far more better than any other sushi place out there IF they even have them! hehe I admit, I love asparagus now and not just for my sushi intake. I've always been a veggie lover and I never got into asparagus as a kid until now! haha

Pros: Fresh sushi and variety, service, and cost

Cons: parking
author: Sharon M.

description: YUMMY! So good - who knew a California Roll could be the best roll I've ever tasted? And no, it was not my first time having sushi. Went with my man and his friends from the Bay. We grabbed all kinds of yummy looking stuff of off the boats. Cali roll, some tuna roll with yummy sauce and crunchy tempura flakes, and ordered the spider roll. I will definitely go back next time I am in the area. We ate more rolls until we were full and only paid about 25 smackers!
author: Rassamee H.

description: Get your wet hand towels ready 'cuz its about to go down... it's awesome sushi on a boat mutha fuckas.
author: Lenza M.

description:
Good to go once or twice for the novelty, but not really a place I'd keep going back to, not the least because during my third time my inability to take my eyes off the constantly moving boats made me a little dizzy... :)

The sushi was mostly fresh since the chefs make it right in front of you, but sometimes a dish would languish on a boat for the entire length of my stay. They came up with some impressive looking sushi creations, but it's not the best place for vegetarians, though you can ask the chefs directly for specific dishes; that sometimes takes a while though, and kind of defeats the purpose of going to a sushi boat place.

(Non sequitor: I've always wondered whether the chefs jump over the barlike set up or crawl through some hidden door beneath the seats if they need a break... it looks like they're pretty sealed in...)

The different plate designs are indicative of what price the sushi on them is, so you grab whatever looks good and the wait staff figures your total based on the stack of plates at the end of the meal.
author: Jin Z.

description:
Wait? What wait? I've always got a seat immediately. 

But i must confess my favorite thing about this place...the electronic japanese greeting when you and enter and exit...reminds me of disneyland! Never fails to put a smile on my face.

It is one of those 'sushi boat places' and the service and fish are better than that other sushi boat place. I especially like the seaweed salad with sesame seeds (the name escapes me)...
author: wayne s.

description:
Ok, if you adjust your priorities a bit, you'll learn to love this place.
