The atmosphere is cheese-ball: on-the-boat sushi bar, Sanrio interior design, KOIT radio music, Walgreen's water fountains...  BUT, the staff is great and the sushi is fresh.  If you time it right, you can get seated in a flash.  The prices are reasonable as well.  It's not as cheap as the no-name place across the street, but as mom always said, when it comes to eating raw food.....don't skimp.

Hold the press....they've remodeled.  Kind of a cross between Trader Joe's and Trader Vic's....
author: bill k.

description:
Anyone that is posting less than 5 stars is not understanding that california rolls should be the equivalent of a really good tuna fish sandwich. Creamy and low-down. 5 stars all the way. And the service is amazing.

Go early or you'll be sad.
author: basil r.

description:
My favorite sushi place in SF. 

I love the boats - Being able to pick put what I want it as I want it just works for me better than trying to figure out what and how much sushi I'm going to wan that night. The sushi chefs are right in front of you so if you don't see something you want just ask. Both the crowds and the selection grow as the night goes on so you have to kind of pick your poison. 

They also have hands down the best unagi I've ever had, it never last long so it's almost always served still warm off the grill and it just melts in your mouth. 

I can't tell you much about the "non" sushi dishes, I've just never wanted to waste my appetite on anything other than the sushi.
author: Rick L.

description: I must be spoiled by some of the other AMAZING sushi restaurants in SF, because this place was just so-so. I'm not a huge fan of sushi boat joints to begin with, so that could be part of the problem. I just wasn't impressed....just a few blocks down Market  you will find a much more delightful sushi experience at either Sushi Time or Sushi Zone. Both within walking distance from here. Give those a try instead!!
author: Cindy H.

description:
Hello my little rice patties!

Joan here.

Once upon a time back in my silent picture days, Warakubune used to be my favorite sushi joint.I loved how the boats would swim past me, much like me who usually swims in alcohol. I would always get tip-top treatment from the Sushi chefs and staff at Waka Waka ( that's my pet name for the place.) It was THE place to get Sushi.

Today, the place has become less than stellar and reeks of dying fish every time I enter the Sushi bar. Mind you, I know I am an old bag and may smell of fish myself, but I do know how to mask my own smell. Waka Waka needs to do the same.

The boats have also been very empty lately and the atmosphere has also lost it's MGM magic.

Sigh...maybe sometime Waka Waka will return to its piece de resistance that it once was.

For now, I will walk by Waka Waka for now wait for he smell to subside.

Best
Joan
author: Joan C.

description: sushi boat with fresh fish, cheap prices, warm friendly service. spicy seafood salad is muy fantastico as is the spicy unagi handroll and the halved avocado with whatever fish you care to have stuffed in it. I eat here weekly...sometimes twice a week...need I say more?
author: S O.

description:
i have been a regular customer of this pseudo-japanese joint for the past two years and last night, i decided it will be ages before i visit this place again.

my favorite fresh white tuna spicy sashimi is STILL LOVE, however, i was turned off when i tried this sort of a new plate on the sushi boat which made me utter an inaudible EWWW.

this particular sushi roll looks like their nice "special roll", but inside it has mushrooms, maybe? topped with a fried tofu. it was the sauce, the horrible sauce which i really thought was inappropriate and ruined the character of a jive-ass sushi roll.

they used a chinese five spice sauce and it was straight from the bottle.
i found it certainly awful to have it use on a sushi roll.

another reason why i need to take a break from them was, their service is getting deficient everytime i'm there.

orders were mistakenly given to someone and the wait for the food is getting slower.

i really don't know when i'm coming back.

so, it's bye for now.

by the way, i noticed they were issued a YELP sticker that is meant to be displayed outside their establishment, but it was in this damp corner, languidly hidden by the sushi chef's ice box.
author: Nelle A.

description: I love this place.  A friend introduced me several years ago and I've been a fan ever since.  My friend and I used to meet here regularly, it was our "spot", our friendship has since faded but not my liking for this place. It's good simple sushi. You can see the guys making it in the middle of the sushi boat river. They have some good rolls and if you find yourself waiting too long for what you want you can place an order. I'd say it's on par with other sushi joints as far as price.  I also find it to be a great place to dine alone, sometimes I want my sushi time to be me time and that's when I'll head to Warakubune.
author: EVA G.

description:
my friends and i have been going here for the last 8 years we've lived in san francisco.

even though it's a sushi boat place, the fish is super-fresh.  

favorite dishes: spicy white tuna sashimi, bonito tatake, spicy scallop or tuna, and now the spicy seafood salad (similar to ceviche). 

it's our regular weekly sushi place.  we've tried so many others, but this is the place we consistently come back to.

sometimes they close for a whole week during holidays, and we count the days till they re-open after those breaks.
author: kim n.

description:
Arghhh...  so when you tell people you will meet them between 7-730 you wouldn't expect them to be there at 630 waiting for you would you? =p So I get there only to see Tracy and Juliane already waiting for me complaining that they're hungry. Here I am making my way from the East Bay on my bike in 95 degree weather wearing my motorcycle jacket (because I'm such a responsible rider) I don't know if it was that or if it was really just that hot inside, but I was still sweating when I got there... gross. 

I don't think I have ever been to a sushi place that serves sushi on boats with FRESH fish. Usually everyone opts to not eat it or it's been sitting there going around in circles the whole night. Granted there were some of those dishes, but for the most part this is the freshest sushi boat place I actually have been to.  It was kind of rare to find a dish I wanted, but I managed. The only trouble was actually catching the dish as it flew by you at warp speed. Tracy actually tried to grab a dish only to have it snatched up by the party next to us... would have been nice if they gave it to her, but they didn't. I figure they didn't see her try and grab it, because they tried to get one for me later on during the meal.  Prices go according to the type of design on the plate. Basically you stack your plates and they tally them up at the end. Ten plates ended up costing me about $40, but I guess that is kind of normal for my sushi habits. I would suggest you get there early as later in the evening a line starts to form and you'll have to wait who knows how long.

drawbacks:

- dragon roll had to much sauce beneath it... it was like sauce soup with a dragon roll.
- had to wait awhile to get dishes you actually wanted
- rather small place 
- what's the deal with a women's restroom and a unisex restroom? but no MENS restroom
- boats blazing by before you could grab what you wanted

the good:

- reasonably priced
- servers walking around all the time and good with refills
- fish fresh... not so bad
- asparagus tempura roll was actually quite tasty
author: Steven T.

description: I'm such a fanboy for this place.  I go so often and I never get tired of the sushi.  It's so fresh!  I recommend a few of their specials: spicy white tuna, tuna tataki, and the special roll.  You can order a large order of each of these from the waiter and it's delicious!!
author: Dan D.

description: If kaiten sushi has ultra cheap acceptable fish, its alright by me.  Thats the point of kaiten sushi. In and out and satisfied.
author: Wakako U.

description: I finally had the guts to try their spicy seafood salad. And like everything else on their menu, it was mouth-watering. If they had a frequent eater card, i would have one. If i lived in the neighborhood, it would be my dinner every night. The latest and greatest after their seafood salad is their spicy white tuna dish. You know, i've thought many times about reviewing this place because it's already busy and the wait is long if you come past a certain hour and i don't want to wait. but, i'd rather wait than deprive this city of the great food this place has. so please come and try it. you won't regret, i promise.
author: S K.

description:
i like this place for three reasons:
 - the sushi is really fresh, 
 - you can (if you time it correctly) do an 'in-and-out' in 20 minutes and kill that sudden sushi-craving, and
 - it's conveniently close to me.

What I don't like is that it's closed Mondays and Tuesdays..and that they have a stupid white-board-queue system and you can end up  hanging around for ages to get a seat.

If there are more than 3-4 people in front of you...leave and go down to the Mission.
author: Rich S.

description:
It is kind of funny how I ended up going here tonight.  

Earlier in the day, I was at my last day of work before I go off to L.A. for thanksgiving.

It was a busy day with lots of customers coming in.  It is pretty amazing that with the current economy we are so busy, and I am very thankful for it.  So, this one gentleman and I start talking about yelp, as it is the new "thing" I am "into".  Turns out he is a yelp reader, if not poster, and we exchanged a bit of knowledge on our favorite places in the area.  

Funnily enough, one of the places he was raving about was Warakubune, a little sushi den that I could probably throw a stone at from where I work.   Lucky for them that I am not so violent.  Anyways, it has been on the list of someplace I need to go for a while now, but it just has never worked out, until tonight.

At about 4:30 my girlfriend comes to meet me before I close and is "dying of hunger", so I say... well I heard some good reviews about that place across the street that we have always wanted to try.  Coincidentally, she was craving Japanese, so off we go.

This is the second time I have been to a conveyor boat sushi spot, the other being in Japan town.  I found the fish here very fresh, and while some of the chef's were rather young, everything was delightful and delicious, including the service (less delicious, more delightful).  The fish was creamy and melted away in your mouth, without leaving a fishy aftertaste behind. (Delicious part)

We ate a lot without regard for what kind of dish we were selecting and I also had a large Sapporo.  Next time we might eat a little more carefully because we racked up an 80 dollar tab, but there will be a next time.
author: Adam C.

description: God I love sushi!  When I went last Friday night to Warakubune the back was full so we sat at the sushi bar.  It makes me so nervous...am I going to tip over a boat?  What if I grab the wrong thing, am I allowed to put it back?  What if I want something that is not in a boat?  Thanks goodness that the staff is super friendly AND miraculously I was not my usual klutzy self. Yay me! Everything was delicious: Spicy White Tuna Sashimi, a California Roll topped with spicy tuna and thinly sliced fried taro root strings,a Shrimp Tempura roll topped with avocado and sesame with a spicy cream sauce, Spicy Seaweed Salad, and the Tempura Asparagus Roll. Everything was melt in your mouth perfection.  Eat here!
author: Stacy R.

description: We practically go here every week - we love this place. The service is fast and friendly, and bar with the boats makes it easy to just grab what you want. The sushi is made right in front of you and you can make requests to both the waiters and the sushi chefs. Sitting in the back is ok - the sushi service is not nearly as fast as sitting at the bar. Get there early - it jams up after 6:30! Love the California Rolls.
author: Nicole T.

description: I came here with nine friends and we were seated in a small dining area towards the back of the restaurant away from the sushi boats.  It was a great place for a party our size.  Comfortable, vaguely mood-lit, and not too loud.  Unfortunately, the service bordered on terrible.  We had to flag down a waiter to take our order, and when he brought us our food he couldn't figure out who had ordered what, and we were missing two plates at the end (which we eventually got when we pointed this out).  The sushi was actually quite good for a sushi boat place.  I had the tamago, the sake, an unagi hand roll, and a spicy tuna hand roll.  Rice was a teeny bit on the dry side, but the rest was great.  Shame on Warakubune, though, for that terrible ramen.  My friend made the mistake of ordering it, and me being the pig/ramen enthusiast I am, I had to steal some.  I realize Warakubune isn't a ramen house, and that even ramen houses get ramen wrong all the time, but please.  Get that abomination off the menu.  The broth was okay, though it tasted a bit more like chicken soup than miso, but the noodles were so thin and overcooked I'm surprised they didn't dissolve by the end of the meal!  My dear friend Shin and even Maruchan make a much tastier, chewier noodle.  Still, I had a good time here and the sushi was very good for the price.
author: Steph C.

description: We went to this place because someone told me about the concept of the little floating sushi boats and I had to see this for myself! They were so adorable, and I'm so glad I checked them out! I think the boats were full perhaps 40% of the time, though it was a Saturday night, and that meant things were getting made fresh very often. The only problem I had was that there were several items in 5 categories, represented by 5 different patterned plates. So, if you are unfamiliar with sushi you might not know what's what, OR, realize you just grabbed a $5 plate when you might not have wanted to. I kept the menu near me to refer to but they kept taking it back and I had to keep asking for another one so I could try and guess what was on the little plates. This all might sound annoying, but I do love sushi so it was kind of a game grabbing things and I ended up trying a few new things and enjoying them. We had a good time!
author: S S.

description: Love this Place...  Love the fact that I can sit down, eat and drink and finish up in or about 25 minutes.  Love this place because I can eat  & drink everything my little heart desires for under or about $25 (including tip)
author: Cris B.

description: Typically I stay away from sushi boat places. Warakubune is totally different. The sushi is super fresh and super cheap. Not like no name up the street. This place actually IS good. I would even go so far as to say it is my favorite sushi bar in the city.
author: M S.

description: I was pretty disappointed with this place after reading the reviews.  The sushi was sub-par, even asking them to give me stuff that they were making fresh, rather then waiting for things to come around.  The only thing I liked was the sweet rice wrapped in seaweed.  Pretty sad.
author: Mitch A.

description:
excellent fresh fish for reasonable prices, wonderful friendly service. very happy to live 3 blocks away :))

 try their--
butterfish
spicy white tuna
spicy scallops in half an avocado
hamachi
salmon

ask the chef to make you something :)
author: Yula P.

description:
Yay, I love this joint. Sort of like Cheers where everyone knows your name except it would weird me out if they did. I know it can be frustrating when the boats are a little behind since there are only 2-3 people making sushi for the entire restaurant but you can always put in personal requests and the quality of the fish and price makes it worth it! I try to avoid the crazy rush hours of Friday night between 6-8 and find that I end up coming here at LEAST once a week. 
I have come alone, with old friends and new, vegetarians, carnivores, foodies, my parents,  you name it! Everyone I have brought has raved about their experience. 
Personally, I love the Uni and the Amaebi (they fry the heads and give them to you, yum). The chef is hilarious, very fun and nice, he even adjusted my orders recently to fit into my health and diet plan. The staff are attentive and polite. Most importantly, they don't make me feel bad about the one or two times I may have over imbibed on sake. 
I am a japanese food snob. This place is my favorite for its personality and its quality. Hooray! Just writing this review makes me want to go back and I was just there less then a week ago.
author: zorina c.

description:
such a bummer because i wanted to give them 5 stars so bad!  i returned here after a memorable first meal with my cousin and left a bit disappointed.  perhaps i had built it all up in my head?

we sat at the bar with the little floating boats and ordered varous sushi.  the fish was very fresh - no complaints at all.  my problem was with the rice.   it was so dry and hard!  like it had been undercooked or sitting out there.  so sad.

the miso soup is really hearty and they even give you a spoon.  service is very friendly and efficient.  i'll have to give it another try....
author: Josie M.

description: "We had eaten at Warakabune beforehand. Mesmerized by the jeweled sushi, and seduced by the saba and the eel and the seared albacore. She kept teasing me because I couldn't stop looking at the fish sailing by, and I kept adding plates to the ones in front of us when she wasn't looking". I confess to having a secret fetish for sushi boat places, and Warakubune is a great example, with some special things I never see elsewhere. Actually, I might even  give it a 5 star rating, if only they'd play better music.
author: Stellah D.

description: We're always happy at Warakubune. The service is sweet. My favorites are the shrimp tempura special roll (in a perfect world, everything I ate would be topped with the pink sauce) and the tuna with the cherry tomato. Plus a sushi boat is an economist's dream come true--real time preference fulfillment!
author: Mia B.

description:
Canvassing the Bay Area for noodles that are worthy enough to be included in my usual rotation is hard work. You start to get really picky and end up sticking to out of the way places that are mentioned in by people in the know. You drive out of town chasing the dragon of rumored broth greatness, special toppings or some other minute specialty. When my noodle partner said he noticed that Warakubune offered ramen, I balked at the idea. A sushi boat place in the middle of the parking hell that is Church and 16th? I had also long forgone my once in a while forays into the budget sushi places, instead saving up money for high quality, once in a while dinners.
Warakubune is a very popular and it's not just the neighborhood that is bringing in the customers. We ordered 2 assorted sashimi platters (12 pieces ~$13), one assorted nigiri plater (10 pieces),  ~$12), 3 orders of uni nigiri that were on the specials board ($6 per order), tako sashimi, edamame, and some bowls of ramen. Most of the sashimi was decent, some pieces were a bit tough or fibrous, but not bad for the price. The biggest surprise was the uni, it was some of the best I've had in town. Creamy, silky, cold, and sweet. The nigiri were attractively presented but I didn't try any of them. Edamames were a tad over-cooked, so the beans were on the mushy/mealy side.
As for the ramen, I don't think I would go back for it. The broth was overly salty and lacked depth. I ordered tonkatsu ramen, but the broth that came out was a coffee hued beefy color unlike all other tonkatsu ramens I've sampled. The only toppings in the bowl were some spinach and 2 or 3 preserved bamboo shoots, but the set included a nicely panko crusted tonkatsu cutlet on the side. I haven't had very many bowls in SF that serve the pork fried and on the side and am more accustomed to bowls served with the standard set of toppings. Noodles were the right thickness but were already past al dente when the soup arrived. 
We polished off 2 or 3 carafes of nigori (unfiltered cold sake) before we wised up and asked if we could buy the whole bottle (not mentioned on the menu). At $5 per carafe or $20 for the huge bottle, bottle is the way to go. Our waiter was nice enough to bring us a large metal bowl of ice to keep the monster bottle chilled throughout the meal. The hot sake was on the acerbic side (I'm not one for hot sake anyway), so I would stick with the cloudy sweet nigori.
We were in the small back room which is ideal for parties. The service was obviously busy with the crush of people waiting for a seat at the boat counter, but they were nice and did all that they could to accommodate our somewhat drunken party. Adjacent to the J-Church and a good value, I'll keep the W-bune in mind when I'm in the hood. Good times.
author: Candice L.

description: Tonight at Warakubune was my first experience with floating boat sushi, and it was great! I had low expectations and was surprised to find it fresh and tasty! I didn't know what a couple of the things off the boat were, but it LOOKED good and everything was yummy. We also ordered the special hamachi kama (cheek), which was wonderful, along with the tempura udon. The broth was a bit salty for me, but otherwise the udon was pretty good. It came to a total of about $60 for the three of us. Definitely coming back.
author: S. D.

description: My favorite sushi place in the city.  The only sushi boat I've ever been to, so I had no idea that sushi boats usually have a bad rap, cause this place rocks my world...  My girlfriend and I usually eat here a couple times a month, cause we can actually afford it here.  Cheap, fresh, yummy, friendly, and rarely a wait.  Minus points for being closed on Mondays and Tuesdays which happen to be the two days a week I crave sushi most, and also for the $35 corkage fee.  Lame!
author: Jesse Lu S.

description:
Su---shi, su---shi, yummy, yummy, sus---hi.

First eveaaaa sushi in San Francisco. I was devirginize (I  wonder if this is a word???)anyway let me just say, it was worth it!!!! The establishment is friendly and even though the wait is long (arriving from 5pm to 8pm wait can generally be 45 minutes to an hour), the service and food is good. The floating boats which holds all the different varieties of sushi is fun to see. And ranging from  $2.75 to $4.75, depends on the dishes design, the sushi is relatively fresh. Just watch out for the sushi that has been floating for a while. If there is a special request you want to eat, you just ask the Chef to make it, which will roughly take  5 to 10 minutes. Oh, if you decide to eat at one of the table in the back room instead of eating at the bar, I would highly recommend that you don't. The party I was with, was at least 8 people and the food took forevaaaaa to arrive. The service was not adequate and it was just poorly run. And many of you are wondering why I'm giving four stars for this place, will  because the service is wonderful at the bar and the food is very good and I just love them boats!!!!
author: Kathy T.

description: Not terrible but not great.  I just got back from an extended stay in Japan and when I'm not keeping my friends awake until 3 am so I won't be lonely, I'm dreaming of good sushi.  I've been spoiled by serious sushi so take my three stars for what you will.
author: Honey L.

description: Heard the comments regarding the long wait. We went there last night at 7 pm and were able to get 2 seats. We were lucky. My girlfriend had never seen the sushi boat before. We were already so starved and perfect timing...we could just pick the boat and ate the sushi right away. My gosh, sushi was really fresh. We couldnt stop eating sushi and we were like uh, the bill would come high. When the bill came on our table, we were so surprised to see the total of $40. We were like not bad, we gotta come back again. Thumbs up.
author: Melody S.

description: Long live the sushi boat!! I love this place, although the problem with the boats is that you can get carried away grabbing everything and spend more than planned, but it is all so delicious!
author: Kelly L.

description: I was not a sushi person until I came here.  The rolls floating by on little boats were so pretty and non-threatening, and so reasonably priced that I was not afraid to try them.  Now I am a big fan.  The service is great and they always remember you.
author: Heidi K.

description: Rockin' the Bune on a Sunday is the best time to have sushi. Traditional style sushi served in boats. Amazing salmon and yellow tail nigiri. Small and cozy atmosphere with great waitstaff, the past couple times I've been here has been phenomenal. Excellent yellowtail, spicy tuna and salmon. Not the best, but they're pretty consistent and friendly.
author: Michael E.

description: My favorite sushi boat restaurant! Really awesome dishes come constantly, and you're never disappointed! And VERY reasonable! The service could improve a bit though.
author: Rachel A.

description: I wish I could get all my food by boat.  Great variety and creative rolls -- many of which I had never had before.  It's a nice neighborhood find.
author: Tim G.

description: My go-to neighborhood sushi restaurant.  Although there is sometimes a wait, we always stick around because this place is worth it.  They have huge delicious bowls of ramen (a rarity in the Castro/Haight area), so on cold days I don't have to get all the way over to Japantown.  The service is friendly and efficient and we're always greeted with a smile.  However, it is the quality of the fish is really what keeps bringing me back. The albacore here is out of this world, a must-try.  Sit down, check out what's floating around on the boats, look at the specials board, get a menu, and get what you want. Also, the back room can accommodate a good size group (10 or 12), so it's a great place to go for a small party or celebration.  My only complaint is they are not open on Mondays and Tuesdays and that's always when I seem to want sushi. But it's forgivable!
author: kate m.

description:
best salmon in town. this place is seriously soooo good. something about the efficiency of the sushi boat delivery system allows them to serve up top-quality fish at a not-totally-outrageous price. i always sit at the sushi-side by the door rather than the roll station in back: even though the boats keep rolling past, the owner at the front making nigiri and sashimi will still stop what he's doing to make you whatever you're in the mood for that may not be circling at the moment. 

this is close to home and there are many, many, many nights i'll head over here solo for a quick bite. they can usually squeeze one in at the bar even when it's super busy (this is when the freshest stuff is circling and keeps getting restocked instantly).

i only wish they stocked unfiltered nigori sake - but i guess choices like that go to show that they focus on one thing: serving really high quality fish as cost-effectively as poissible. 

god i love this place.
author: Hunter H.

description: I've been here several times and have never had anything but an amazing meal. I usually pass on sushi boat places, but this one is so fresh and tasty. The fish does not sit around like at other places. The white tuna, hamachi, salmon, and oysters are all fantastic.
author: Karin F.

description: Warakubune is my favorite sushi boat restaurant and it has been such since my wife lived in the Castro in 1999 - crap we're getting old. The chef and staff are great, the basic rolls are good, the special rolls are where it's at. It may not be as good as other more hard core non sushi boat places... but the joy and instant gratification that the little boats bring... it's just so good...
author: Fred A.

description: This place is like my kitchen. I have never left this place unsatisfied or hungry. I go there enough that they recognize me so I always ask what's the best fish of the day, something one should always ask at any sushi place. I would say the prices are great for the quality of food. Lord knows I have paid more for less! Remember that you are not limited to what is on the boats. I recommend the hamachi cheek! If you're feeling a bit more adventurous, go for the monkfish liver (my personal fave) and the Uni is always fresh. Anything with the spicy mayo is also delicious and, should you go for something extra spicy, grab the red tobiko and sweat. It is so easy to walk in and stuff yourself and walk out happy, it's that simple.
author: Ethan T.

description: Ok, sorry, I wanted to love this place, but for whatever reason the sushi we ate was sub-par. The sake nigiri was served about 2 degrees above freezing. The crowd was fantastic though. Everything from lesbians on dates to young families with their babies to girls nights out to solo diners, bound together in their hatred of that bastard up the line who snagged the last plate of unagi (me!).
author: Tom L.

description: My devotion to this sushi place is never-ending. I never liked boat sushi until I went to this place, and I am convinced that it's the best boat sushi place in the world. I have been going to this place for ten years. My favorites from here include asparagus tempura roll (try it!) and caterpillar rolls. Other than this, everything is good and fresh.
author: Darren M.

description: Warakubune has taken up a small existence in my life. The service is immediate, the sushi is top quality...the albacore literally dissolves as it touches your tongue. Known best for their Nigiri, they have recently added some tasty and funky rolls to the river; One, a California roll topped with Sriracha style spicy tuna and thinly sliced fried potato strings; the other, a shrimp tempura roll topped with avocado and sesame, swimming in a sea of spicy cream sauce. I rarely have to order anything from Benji, as the floating selection is always varied.
author: Nicholas M.

description: We refer to this place as "the boat" but that's NOT to be confused with The Sushi Boat. Big, fresh pieces of nigiri -- the sake (salmon) and albacore are some faves. Specialty dishes like spicy albacore with a mild-spicy orange sauce, sesame seeds, garlic, scallions, and a tomato garnish rock. The staff is really friendly and if you're there when it's busy, the wait's not unbearable. Cheap, too!!
author: Jen W.

description: I adore this place. It's not that it's the best sushi, it's mostly that the ambiance is down-home and comfortable, the food is always the same and basic (but good), the prices aren't overwhelming, and the group that runs this are super nice. Used to be my "altnerate kitchen," it's now one of the key reasons I come back to this hood. Many people use this as their alternate kitchen, as well. My order: seaweed salad, a big beer, hamachi, their special fish (whatever that is), and usually someone gets a spider roll. Very yummy.
author: Anna B.

description:
I live pretty close to this joint, so I frequent here at least once a week. I feel I know how to navigate these waters without a compass. All aboard, it's time to go angling on the S.S. Warakabune (Sushi-Boats).   
      
     First of all, climb aboard at your own risk. You could be moored down for quite some time if you arrive dockside, late, oh...say after 6:30PM. The trick is to get here as soon as they open (and preferably alone or as a pair) @ 5:30PM. This way you can take care of that "uncontrollable urge" (thanks DEVO) and catch a seat, port side. If you can do this, it's smooth sailing from here on out. If you can't make it here at the afore mentioned times then you are in for some rough seas. Gale force even. The only problem and it's a small one, is the seating hierarchy (or lack of). It's on a first come, first serve basis. And of course, everyone wants to be first. So keep your wits about you or you could drown in a sea of bodies. Another problem is that if you arrive with a large party, it's almost impossible to plot a proper course for your entire crew to dine at the trough. So, make a couple of them walk the plank, that way you can plunder the gully in a timely manner.
     The catch is usually fresh, which is due to the fact that they tend to target certain species (Ahi, Hamachi, Sake etc.). No by-catch here...exotics (Kanpachi, Aji, Ankimo) tend to be tossed overboard or are harvested on the weekends (most times). Therefore, if you are the truly seaworthy type, come on the weekends to indulge in your epicurious cravings and do arrive early. Landlubber are ye? Than order from the galley, they have most of the cooked Japanese fare. 
   They have just recently swabbed the decks, the mess hall is brand spanking new. I like the new decor, it's a marriage of Tiki-hut chic and captains' trophy-room. 

All in all, if you book your route accurately, it's a smooth cruise through tranquil waters.
author: Gabe T.

description: The best sushi in town! The chef Ben is known for being the pickiest around when selecting only the freshest and best fish. The size of the pieces are HUGE, and doesn't hurt your wallet. We eat there about 2-3x per week! XOXOXOXOXO LOVE LOVE LOVE. Watch out though, because you will be hooked and then can't go anywhere else because it will not be as good.
author: sarah d.

description:
yummy yummy yummy I got fish in my tummy... 
Warkabune is our neighborhood pick for consistently delicious sushi. Good atmosphere, great fish, and I like it so much I even ignore my rule about not eating sushi in a restaurant with boats!  yum, I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: E Q.

description: WOW WOW WOW I Absolutely LOVE LOVE this place!!!! This is definetely the BEST tastiest most freshest sushi I've ever eaten. The white spicy tuna is to DIE FOR!!!!! OMG, I could eat that every single day. There special rolls are amazing as well. LOVE IT!!!!!
author: Martha A.

description: My female friend brought me out here so she could take advantage of me and make me pay for her dinner. 60 bucks later, I must say it wasn't too bad. Not the best sushi I've ever had, but it's pretty decent, and who doesn't love sushi bune? Nothing like little boats delivering food to you personally. The fish is kinda fresh, the sashimi is on point and the rolls are okay. I felt like there wasn't a whole lot of variety on the boats so I'll have to visit this place again to really see how I feel about their sushi.
author: Edmund C.

description:
if you don't see what you like then ask for it. it's nice and novelty.
cute space, nice staff
good for those who don't take their sushi too seriously
author: kiki b.

description: The thing about Warakabune is that I sort of don't want you to know about it.  I'm selfish like that (but only about sushi).  This is hands-down my favorite sushi place in the city (and yes, I am including places that charge 5x as much).  The chefs are so friendly.  At this point, by the time I sit down, my favorite roll is already waiting for me.  So.   Go find your own cheap, delicious, amazing, friendly sushi place that has cheap, good sake.  Dammit.
author: Sheila W.

description: I love the boat. Sometimes I just come in here order a 7-Up and watch the boats go 'round. Ok - not really. Who has time to wait for a sushi order - just grab a plate as it sails by and enjoy. See how high you can stack your empty plates and win!
author: Colin S.

description: Decent, cheap sushi delivered by boat.  If all you want is absolutely acceptable sushi RIGHT NOW, this is your place!  It's not my favorite sushi restaurant by far but it fills an important niche in my rotation.
author: Jess L.

description: 4 years after my review and this place is still awesome.  Perhaps better than ever.  The only downside is that since No-name Sushi burned down across the street...now I have to wait
author: Aaron C.

description: What else can you ask from a sushi place. It is clean, their sushi is fresh, excellent saba, and very friendly staff. I've been a sushi fan for several years now and I never had a bad experience with them. Try the special roll with Avocado and Unagi and the seafood salad if you are very hungry. In case you are very thirsty, go for the unfiltered sake
author: Candido B.

description: The best sushi-boat place in the City. I would give in five stars, but sometimes I find myself waitnig for a seat for almost 45 mins (I think it's because it is just that good though). Service is great, food is cheap, and the people that work there are really easy to get a hold of. And the sushi is the BEST I have had in the City. And it is insanely cheap for a sushi place... oh and the sake is pretty good too (and cheap). I would seriously move closer to Church street cause it is just that good.
author: evan Y.

description: Okay... I've never been here but everytime I say the name I feel like I have a speech impediment. That's awesome.
author: Selino V.

description: Great service! most excellent sushi. try the asparagus tempura roll and the sashimi with the tomatoe on it (that's all I have to say and the waiter knows what I mean-- I like that!)
author: Jenna E.

description: If you see something you like - grab it or you might not see it next time the little boat comes back. I kinda-love this place! Much better than "no name" across the street - for sure.  A great neighborhood joint  - definitely not worth it to cross a bridge for. Those little plates can pile high so keep track of them - $$$. Long wait too so make sure you're not hungry when you show up - otherwise you might be tempted to sneak a roll or two off one of the little boats.
author: Frank R.

description: The wait is always crazy, but worth it. I've only lived in the city for about a year, and at one point lived right around the corner from Warakubune, and this is some of the better sushi in the Upper-Market, Church Street area. The prices are fair, and I like paying for only what I eat. Wish it was like that everywhere!
author: Melody H.

description: I have been dining here since it opened (used to be a bad Chinese place) and they used to be open for lunch but stopped :(  the sushi is amazing as are the rolls the servers recall m y son who was 7 when he first stated going now he is 17...they are so very sweet to my family ..my mother who is in a wheel chair gets accommodated without attitude.  The price is right and the boats well we love the boats. I can't wait to take my new honey there soon! I must say get there early as lines build fast and people are rude and pushy about waiting and it' annoying to bring a kid after 7pm...
author: Kitty L.

description: I love this place! Very fresh sushi, perfect portions, interesting combinations, great neighborhood. What's not to love!? The sushi goes down so smooth, the only downside is that it's too easy to spend $30 on your meal! This place also seems to attract nice patrons, so it's a throughly enjoyable experience.
author: Nicole C.

description: chicken terayki is bone dry and hard to eat and digest!!!  It should be super moist and succulent marnated in the sauce !!!  the rest of the meal was ok !!!!     they need to work on the chicken BIGTIME !!!!
author: Andy W.

description: The most enjoyable part of eating here is watching the beautiful fish float by, and competing with your neighbor to catch the best plates. Sometimes  the variety is a bit lacking, but generally it picks up as the night goes on, and they'll make you anything you ask for. The fried shrimp balls are awesome. I generally go in here and accidentally gorge myself, because I can't stop taking more plates. For the fun and variety, the price is nice. I just always spend way more than I thought I would. Perhaps because of the gorging.
author: Cheryl J.

description:
love love love love love love love love.
basically.
ive always been sacred of sushi boats,in fact this is the first one ive ever been to. i am also allergic to many types of raw fish so i need a place thats super fresh and carefuly to not contaminate. 
that being said, i ate here last night and the night before and left full, happy, a bit tipsy and not broke. (and clearly not dead, thats a plus)

enough said.
author: Candy L.

description: sushi boat was fun but everything had wasabi in it. it's not to say the food or the place is bad but i just don't like wasabi at all. so i don't know how i should rate this place. i'll just give it something in between then...a 3. =)
author: Helen L.

description: I'd really like to give only 2.5 stars because sometimes they don't answer the damn phone when I call for take out. I know it's just around the corner, but at times, there is a mentally ill guy on a rant and rampage outside my building. It takes about 10 minutes for the food to be ready as well as the crazy man to move along. Because the folks at Warakabune are so nice when I get them on the phone or at the restaurant and I'm pleased with the food, I'll keep it at 3 stars.
author: Theda E.

description: What a hidden gem!  I've been by this place tons of times and never paid any attention to it, in fact I used to be sorry for it because I thought it must be pretty empty due to the other popular sushi places nearby...I was so wrong!  they certainly don't have any problems getting patrons!  Very cute, intimate sushi boat place with great ramen soup bowls.  A bit packed like sardines eating tekka but it's understandable.  The food was excellent and great value too...I was telling everyone about this place I enjoyed it so much, can't wait to go back!
author: Debbie Y.

description: It's a boat place but it's a good boat place. Tempura asparagus roll, spicy tako, saba. Billy Ocean on the radio every 20 minutes to chew along by.
author: patrick g.

description: Good sushi joint if you are looking for good (but not great), inexpensive sushi. You'll find better quality sushi here than any of the other "cheap" sushi joints I know (e.g. We Be, Kitaro, etc). Come here if you're in need of a quick, cheap, sushi fix.
author: Sunny Y.

description: I did like the atmosphere of this restaurant. I guess we got there right about opening, so things were just getting started. They were quick to refill tea and the service was excellent. The food was also excellent. My only complaint was not enough variety. We saw california roll after california roll coming around. I kind of felt like we were waiting for something to come up forever. But, this was my first experience with sushi boats, maybe later in the evening there is more. The spicy tuna roll was excellent as was the seaweed salad.
author: Erin O.

description: Not the freshest sushi, but I love...love the fried asparagus sushi roll...holy shit, I could eat that all day. I would not typically recommend a sushi boat place, but Warakabune is good. They have awesome salad dressing for the little iceberg lettuce salads you can get.
author: Colleen B.

description: Of the few times I have been here, the salmon has just been so-so. I expect a melt in your mouth, buttery smooth salmon and what they usually have is rubbery and tasteless.
author: matt m.

description:
I used to go to Warakabune almost once a week when I lived in that part of San Francisco.  Since moving, I haven't had the chance to go back as often and I miss it.

There is so much to like about Warakabune.  The staff is incredibly nice and attentive.  The boats are just fun, but if you prefer you can get a table or you can watch the boats and just order off the menu.  The qualilty isn't the best in the city, but it's decent and fair for the price.  They aren't super creative nor do they offer a huge variety of items, but what they put out is of quality.  This is my solid, affordable and dependable sushi pick for SF.
author: Erin K.

description: I really enjoyed most of the rolls, they was one in particular that was so good it melted in your mouth. So damn good! (do not go to these types of places with children, they'll try to sink the boats, hahahah!) Anyway, the rolls were delicious, but watch out with the prices because I just grabbed and grabbed stuff and the bill ended up being pretty high. I'm pretty spontaneous like that too! Oh and HUNGRY!
author: Gina R.

description: This suhi boat place rocks my boat, baby. Delicious sushi, totally visually stunning treading its way across murky waters. Trying to grab it before someone next to you is always fun. Not too much sake or I get violent. The spicy tuna is the best in the entire city. I had some kind of a dragon or a spider roll that was too good to believe. My friend and I used to sit at the bar and casually nibble for like three hours. We ran up a bill to finance the owners kids' education, but it was fun. I need a new replacement since he moved to NY - any takers?
author: Liss C.

description: My friends and I love this place. Once you sit down, there's no waiting for food. Instant gratification. And the sushi is actually pretty good (I'm from Japan so I'm very picky). The only thing about this place is that it's usually very crowded right around dinner time (any day of the week) so be prepared to wait a while. But don't go too early--one time we went so early that there weren't any sushi boats out yet! Had to order from the server which kind of defeated the whole purpose of going to this restaurant. But the food was still good!!!
author: Kanna L.

description: Good sushi, very friendly staff, 5 minute wait on a Saturday night, kicky music, and lots of apparant regulars -- always a good sign.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
cool little neighborhood spot for some sushi boat action. i found it to be very basic, very clean, very no-frills. i would recommend if you are looking for a sushi boat joint in the area, but otherwise, i would skip it the next time and head over to Miyabi down the block. 

i found the sushi to be very fresh, but also very basic. no special rolls, just a couple and i have to say the price isnt the best. i also dont like places where they already have the wasabi in the nigiri rolls-- some people dont like wasabi or like to control how much they use. also, for some reason, it took about 20 minutes to get our little order of unagi nigiri (they said it was cooking). salmon and spicy tuna rolls were good, but again, basic. i didnt find anything that stood out to me there. 
i felt like i kept seeing the same rolls drifting by again and again on the boats.
author: Miss Lili F.

description:
Initially, I was a bit worried because I came with my friend who is not into sushi/sashimi.  She's a California Roll eater kinda gal.  I also am not into the conveyor belt idea, but since we were with a group I tried it out.

I was pleasantly surprised.  I had the miso, 12-piece sashimi plate, and a spicy tuna hand roll.  The sashimi platter was a good variety, with good sized pieces of various fish.  The fish was all very fresh and delicious, and my companions also enjoyed their sashimi plates and various rolls. 

The spicy tuna hand roll was a bit too spicy (and I actually really enjoy heat) because it took away from the flavor of the tuna...not enhancing it.

But, I enjoyed being able to sip some cold sake and sit with my friends.  We didn't have to eat at the counter because of the little room in the back was able to accommodate us.  

Service is what you would expect for a sushi joint, but they were able to answer the questions we had and delivered what we needed in a timely fashion.  

A nice experience, overall.
author: Victoria S.

description: For me this place ROCKS.  Fun, cheap, easy, and friendly better than other sushi bars in the hood. we go at least once a week for their special, I like watching the boats go by, and it's great for a solo dinner.
author: rhiannon B.

description:
fresh sushi on the boats, nothing really sits out for very long.  the chefs are very quick about making special requests, great variety, attentive and friendly servers.  plus - it's just so dang cute.  

i love sushi boat!
author: Jessica L.

description:
this is our favorite sushi place, hands down.

we've been coming to warakubune for a few years now, and really miss it since moving to the east bay.

the staff is always so over-the-top friendly, the prices are very reasonable, the setting is casual and intimate.  of course, they've got the floating boats but we prefer to sit at a table.

favorites here : edamame, california rolls, unagi and the ultimate : a special shrimp tempura roll with a spicy/tangy red sauce that we've yet to find offered anywhere else.  (ask for the 'special tempura shrimp roll' ... it's not on the menu but the waitstaff knows what it is.)  soooooo good!
author: Noah C.

description: I love the sushi here!  I come here often.  The fish is fresh and unlike some sushi places the chefs don't pre-slice the fish -- it's sliced as they go.  They are generous here and their special rolls are very good.  I don't think there are names for the special rolls.  Or I haven't discovered the name.  I just see them on the boats and grab them as quickly as he puts them out... sometimes they don't make it all the way around.  I like their tataki tuna and shiro maguro.  The hamachi is also very good here.  The wait used to be much longer, but it's not so bad lately.
author: M. T.

description: Lots of things in Japan didn't make sense to me. One thing that did make sense was serving hot hand towels before meals. Genius! Thank you Warakubune for giving the public the hot towels they deserve.
author: Daniella C.

description:
Warakubune is Japanese for hole-in-the-wall.  Not really, but this restaurant is pretty small!   But that doesn't matter because my large sushi appetite was sufficiently satisfied here.  Fresh, beautiful, and plentiful.  Every time I go here, and it's been many times now, there is always a wide variety of sushi choices going around on those adorable little boats.
The prices are pretty reasonable too... especially for a guy whose plate stack nearly touches the ceiling... kidding.  I'd suggest getting their unfiltered sake.  It's refreshing and most importantly alcoholy... is that a word?
Sometimes the wait for a spot can be trying... but be patient and keep thinking about the delicious seafoody treats about to enter your piehole.  
Oh yeah... here's a little secret.  
Anytime you eat at a sushi boat restaurant.  Be sure to stand up while they're counting your plates and yell... "Sushi boat... toot toot!"
I always get a discount... ;-)
author: Greg H.

description: Sushi on a boat, one of my favorite ideas of al time.  6 minutes flat will get you fed and paid up. I only come here when noname across the street is closed.  They are friendly though.
author: Geronimo G.

description: I'm editing my previous three star review to a four star review, because the spicy white tuna has redeemed Warakubune!  You have to wait sometimes but you can order a drink while you are waiting.  You are seated uncomfortably close to other people but it's a chance to make friends if you feel social.   A moat filled with fixed price sushi plates encircles the chefs....order the spicy white tuna, seared tuna w/a sesame coating, spicy mayo (i like to call this jesus jizz...it's straight from the heavens), scallions and a cherry tomato garnish.....OMFG. divine.
author: regina k.

description: This place is by far my favorite sushi joint in SF. I love the whole grabbing your sushi from a boat thing and the price is quite reasonable. There are tables in the back if you're not into the sushi boat thing, but in my opinion that's the boring section back there. I've been so many times yet still never get tired of it. The staff are very nice and courteous and always greet you when you enter and leave. Just writing this review makes me want to go there now!
author: Alan W.

description: I don't know if Warakebune has the "best" sushi in the city, but it's pretty damn good. 5 stars is because I just love this place. Food is ready when you get there, just sit, watch the boats, and eat. If you don't see something you like, the friendly chefs and staff will hook you up. A fresh, cold 22 is always only a minute away. I don't know the actual names, but I highly recommend the asparagus rolls, the california rolls with spicy tuna and 'chips' on top, and the seared white tuna topped with cherry tomatoes. Not the cheapest but worth the investment if you're a sushi lover.
author: Yotam L.

description:
The BEST sushi value in SF!  I have lived in the Castro since 1987 and have been to at least 20 sushi restaurants in SF and many more outside of SF.  The key to great sushi is a selective chef who controls inventory so the food is as FRESH and SAFE as possible.  I am big into VALUE and this place wins hands down.

Owner Ben and his wife Cynthia are super hospitable and reward regulars with little extras, e.g., if you order something like uni (sea urchin) and there is only enough for one piece instead of two, they make it and offer it free.  

The best uni is from Santa Barbara and often Ben will not order it if it is not available from there.  Lately he has had uni from Alaska and Japan so he must be happy with the quality coming in now.

Service is fast and friendly such as tea and water being refilled often and they hustle to bus bar seating to get the next person in line seated.  The staff is eager to take special orders if you don't see what you want.  Credit cards accepted, take out is fast, recent remodel is sophisticated for a neighborhood place.

Unless you eat at many sushi places, it would be hard to compare this place.  The nigiri is larger than many places and the fish tastes more moist and succulent.  The rice is just the right amount of moisture and corrrect temperature to compliment the seafood.  They won't put oysters on the menu unless they are in the "safe" season.  The monkfish liver (Ankimo) is homemade and like butter!  I'm adventurous and enjoy Tobiko with Quail Egg, Ikura, Uni, Oysters ... and I've been HIV+ since 1988 with no problems from eating at this place since it opened.  

Some sushi joints don't have liquor licenses ... Warakubune has wine, saki options and great beer selection ... all reasonably priced.

Yeah, no one ever wants to wait in this town of type A's.   But I like to see a family owned small business do well.  As it gets busier, I think of the how hard these folks work and wish them great success.  They are good people with class and a great work ethic.  That alone makes me want to support them.  But I can say that I have been to Blowfish, all the places in Japantown, Todai, Nikko Hotel, We Be Sushi, Godzilla, places on Clement, every place in the Castro, Ebisu, and more ... but if I had one last meal on this earth, I'd have the ambulance swing by Warakubune for take out!  Pass the wasabi ...
author: Gary V.

description:
I love LOVE love this place.  It's the only japanese restraunt i will go to willingly in the city.  I have been frequenting this place weekly for a couple of years and have only the best to say about it...where do I begin?

The sushi comes around in boats- big plus, it is made fresh and just keeps coming.  There is free green tea and the waiters are so quick you never have an empty cup.  The prices are great and its always a pleasure to dine there.

I heart Warakabune!
author: satya p.

description: How I love sushi boat.  Cheap, fast, variety as soon as you sit down.  Plus the entertainment of the boats.  This place is by my friends apartment, so I've been there a few times.  The first time we went, the boats were consistently awesome, especially some pieces of tuna sashimi in sesame sauce with chives.  It was the first time I ate sashimi and it was, if not life changing, then at least appetite changing.  I crave sashimi all the time now.  However, the second time we went the sushi was pretty so-so, not as much variety as the first time, so you had to wait a while for something appetizing to come around.  I had the tuna sashimi again in the end and it was just as good as before.
author: Emily G.

description: The sushi is delicous and fresh! The customer service is always friendly, but the lines are just ridiculous and that's really the only thing that prevents me from going sometimes. I like their blend of Chinese and Japanese flavors such the friend shrimp shu mai. You dip it in the hot mustard they serve it with- I love the combination of the tender shrimp and breaded crunchy crust. Also- the ginger Albacore specialty is one of my most favorite nigiri rolls i get there. It's topped with scallions and this spicy ginger sauce. The Albacore is soft, not slimy, and a hint of buttery ta ste. YUM! Last, the sesame seed super white tuna with cherry tomatoes is almost to die for. They have this spicy aioli sauce that accompanies it and it's just sooo goood! The prices are great and definitely not too expensive at all. We're talking 2-5 bucks a plate.  If you haven't tried it, try it.. just know it might take a little to get to the table.
author: michelle s.

description: Sushi and instant gratification your thing? This is the place for you. The sushi is excellent and goes around on little boats so you can grab til your hearts desire. Not cheap, but excellent and fresh!
author: RED L.

description: to be completely honest...i decided to try warakubune because i had a craving for good sushi...i yelped the restaurant & i saw pictures of the spicy seafood salad (which looked absolutely delicious) so i decided i should give it a try...the restaurant has floating boat which i felt like didn't have a lot of variety...but we ordered the spicy seafood salad and it was delicious & very filling...i felt like it was a neverending plate of sashimi!  :)  i will definitely be going back again for the spicy seafood salad...
author: Vicky C.

description: 4 Stars for food but HUGE points off for the "Hover" system...I hate walking into a place with no real seating system...this place has a board that youre supposed to write your name on but NO ONE uses it (mostly cause no one knows its there), therefore you feel like you have to memorize who came in before you/after you and hope that everyone is doing a good job at memorizing the order in which they came in as well.  And while you are eating everyone is standing around and staring at you waiting for you to leave.  Its a very nervous experience.  That said the boat sushi is very fun and since there are so many people there all the time, its fresh and theres a great variety.  I love the small portions, so that even if youre a small party you get to have one of everything!  Avoid Friday night, or come when it first opens.  I love the "Instant Gratification" of it all...sit down and pop one in your mouth!  One to avoid:  The oysters, they leave something to be desired.  I will definitely be back on a weekday!
author: Cathleya G.

description: Love the atmosphere and love the sushi boats. It's not the best sushi in town and it's not especially cheap because the ala carte items add up quickly. That said I keep coming back because there's something I just love about eating at the rock. If you're a regular the free house Sake is a nice touch too!
author: Todd H.

description: Great place. Good sushi. Disappointing that this place isn't open for lunch. Guess they don't realize the amount of profit they're losing by doing that, huh?
author: Stephen A.

description: Darn good sushi for the price and the convenience and the cute boat factor. I've eaten ALOT of sushi and this is the place me and the S.O. keep coming back to. Dont come here for exotic ten dollar throw in the kitchen sink roles. We've been to Sushi Zone - not that impressed (too much mayonaise). Come here. Or don't -- its too crowded already.
author: M T.

description: I am here at least twice a month.  I am not a seafood lover, but once I tried the spicy white tuna (the cubes with the green onions) I fell in love.  I have to start and end my meal with it.  Get the big plate of it-- you will have no trouble finishing it.  The service is always great and I never have to ask for the siracha spicy red sauce.  Delicious!
author: J P.

description: Sushi boat is always fun. Warakubune has a good variety of sushi, rolls, etc. The fish is fairly fresh even for a sushi boat place! However, it's not cheap and it's not the best sushi I've ever eaten. However, if you like choices and don't mind a quick dining experience, this is a good place.
author: Cecilia W.

description: It is a little tricky to write a review for this place.  As a sushi boat place, it is actually pretty good.  As a straight up sushi place however, it is only average.  They're not super traditional (was that a piece of dim sum that just floated by?!?) but that's OK.  It is all about serving you up a good meal, fast, and at a reasonable price.
author: Joseph S.

description: went to go check out this place after all the great reviews and my oh my! im glad I did.  Went there this past saturday with this guy i have a huge crush on and had a great sushi experience.  I'm usually not into sushi but since then I'm craving it!  Had my first raw sushi and so did he, and it was pretty good.  the sushi boats are sOOo cute and i liked the fact that you can sit down and eat right away.  What made it fun too was that on each of our sides were two sushi-experienced couples that helped us in making good decisions.  the vibe was really friendly, and we all talked to each other. The service was good.  Everytime i take a sip of my tea and look away, I'd look back and my cup is filled to the brim.  nice swift work for the waitress ladies!  the guy making the sushi was quick and made any special orders promptly. OH and MY GOD the special rolls he made with the avocado and tempura were the BEST!!! my mouth is watering just thinking about it.  IT's 2 in the morning and I am feening for some right now!!! At the end of our date we had about well over 10 plates.  totaled almost to $40.00.  We had such a nice first time raw sushi experience together, that we bonded and the date lasted all night until the next morning..
author: ShayShay G.

description: I love this place.  I often feel like I would be happy to move in and just sit and watch the boats go by, eating what I like.  I would be very happy if that were possible.  After I went to Tokyo my idea of what good sushi is changed quite a bit and this is the one place that I want to go back to constantly.  Fresh fish, delicious food, friendly efficient service.  What more could you want?
author: Mara K.

description: small selection. not japanese owned. horrible sake. i once ate like 10 special rolls here because they are pretty addictive like big macs.
author: christopher a.

description: Depending on when goes, one might see the boats carry the same item for a while, like when it's slow. But during peak hours, the boats are frequently rotated and of course you can always ask the chefs/waiters for specific dishes. SF has tons of great sushi places, so it's a bit like splitting hairs trying to distinguish between them. However Warakabune keeps me coming back because the waiters & chefs are personable, the quality usually high and the price very palatable.
author: gary a.

description: i come here when i need a quick meal on sunday evenings.  the sushi boat selection is pretty good and they'll fix up whatever you want on request.  the servers seem friendly enough and the prices are reasonable.  not much else to say besides that it is definitely worth swinging by if you need a quick japanese fix.
author: Steven C.

description: it is exciting to actually find a sushi boat place that is decent -- more than decent even.  we had a bigger party so didn't actually sit at the boats, but i plan to go back and do so soon.  everything we ordered was fresh and fantastic, plus affordable.
author: e w.

description: I went to this sushi place by my house last night for a quick dinner. It's called Warakubune and is located on Church St. between 15th & 16th, across the street from "secret sushi". It has the moving sushi boats on a conveyer belt above the sushi bar. I know this can be a turn off for some people, but there's something very pleasing about having endless options of perfect sushi rolls and nigiri floating by. You have to react and hand select each dish. And the portions are smaller for the larger rolls (3 pieces), so you can sample more. You can also order off of their menu & order rolls/sashimi from the sushi chef that you don't see on the boats. Everything I tried was very good and the fish tasted incredible fresh. There are defintiely cheaper sushi spots in the neighborhood (secret sushi & Miyabi), but I really enjoyed my meal here. The service is impecible and fast and the atmosphere is fun. I'm not always into eating at the counter because you're shoulder to shoulder with your neighborhood (I know, that's SO American of me), but the food here is worth it. My friend and I ordered a large Sapporo and about 10 plates off of the boat. Our total was $38, which seems like a good price for what how much we ate and how high quality the food was.
author: Ariel D.

description: I've been coming here for at least 8 or 9 years and it's been our steady go-to sushi spot...the staff and food never disappoints. The house special roll, the spicy white tuna, tempura asparagus, and salmon roll are my favorites. Plus, the guys who make the sushi always welcome requests.
author: g C.

description: pretty solid sushi. they've got sushi boat seating in front, and a few tables in back. the ambiance is pretty cute, and for the quality of sushi you get, it's not that expensive. they also have udon, donburi, and a good assortment of appetizers. we were happy with our food, but not blown away. the waiters were really friendly.
author: monkey l.

description: This was the first place I ever ate real sushi - six years ago. I was a latecomer to the genre. In the following years, I have become obsessed with sushi, eating it wherever I can. And yet, I have NEVER had fish of such freshness and tenderness as at Warakubune - which I only learned the name of two weeks ago, having previously referred to it as "sushi boat across from no name". The waiter last night explained to me that the two favorite dishes there - the spicy white tuna (topped with green onion and ginger, resting delicately in a spicy creamy sauce) and the tuna tataki nigiri (topped with ginger/ garlic garnish) are exclusive to them. Which is why I will never stop going. Crafty, eh? And I have to disagree with Stellah D.'s opinion of the music. Last night they played only eighties hits from movies, so in addition to the best damn meal ever, we got to play 'Name that 80s Soundtrack Hit'.
author: Katy F.

description: we didn't actually come for the sushi boat part, took a table in the back on valentine's day. got there around 5:30 and there was no wait for the boats or the tables. had the veg tempura which i would skip in future, the veggies were sliced kinda thin so it was was more battery than veggie. the california roll, the eel, and spicy tuna rolls were pretty standard. HOWEVER,  the specialty shrimp tempura roll w/ avocado was well received by my partner and i - delicious! and the red snapper was so good and melty, mmm... we had a really awesome server too, he was very helpful and nice.
author: Toisha T.

description: great sushi place if you're in a hurry. you can just take the plates floating past you on  little boats. the chef takes requests and makes them quickly. i find that the fish is really fresh. i love the atmosphere and the service is always good. great sushi place at a great price. arrive early on fridays and saturdays to avoid the wait.
author: City G.

description: After searching relentlessly for a place to call "my favorite sushi spot", my long journey ended after my first visit to this restaurant. They always have super fresh fish and oysters. Their delicious aioli on the seared tuna is to DIE FOR! Good food, excellent service, and a nice, kickback atmosphere. What more can you ask for?!
author: Kacey K.

description: it's true grab anything that looks good...and if you dont see their special rolls floating around, ask the chef for an order, your tongue will melt with the creamy spicy sauce, a really comfy place to have sushi boats and drink sake
author: binh l.

description: the owner of this jap cuisine is a couple from hong kong, the wife acts friendly to every one, but turns her face right after she goes back to the kitchen and start talking about shtt of the customers; the husband is an old school gangster, well, he's all rite.
author: Jex H.

description:
it's chinese american sushi and it rocks. 

my best friend from tokyo always insists on coming here for the "mayonaiseey california rolls" whenever she's in town. 

favorites:
- brian maki (not on the menu)
- spicy white tuna sashimi
- tataki
- no-name "special" roll (with shrimp tempura, avocado and spicy mayo)
- agedashi tofu (not the soggy, rubbery tragedy that miyabi serves!)
- purple yam roll with macadamia (only on special occasions)
- curry fish tempura roll
- kani salad roll
- asparagus tempura
- spicy kim chee udon

been going here for almost 10 years now and the couple who runs the place are amazingly nice. while i'm thrilled they're having so much success, it means i only go about once a month now rather than twice a week... the line is just too long most of the time.
author: Brian K.

description: Great sushi, Great service, Great prices, Awesome selection, and SUSHI BOATS....what more could you ask for?
author: Jack D.

description: Wow, this was the 2nd time I had been here, but not for about 8 years at least.  The sushi was so fresh.  We had ahi belly, unari, philly roll and about eight other great plates.  Prices are really reasonable, with most plates averaging about $3.50.  It's not very crowded on a Sunday which is great.  Sitting at the sushi bar with all the other folks can be a bit cramped, but well worth it.  The people who work here were nice.  Definitely up there with my other fave, Zushi Puzzle.
author: Brian L.

description: oh my gosh i forgot to tell you guys something i just LOVE the special roll. it's soooo yummy in my tummy ;D lolz and i love the tuna. it's just soooooo fresh there
author: teri c.

description: I've been twice, and both times the sushi boats were more empty than full. The chef would put new plates up once every ten minutes or so, and they'd be picked over pretty well before they got around to me. In a city with SO many good sushi options, this doesn't begin to hold up.
author: Mike B.

description: this is my new favorite sushi.  relatively affordable, totally delicious
author: Andy R.

description: on sunday i decided to try a new sushi place.I LOVE the Unagi dinner!  the special roll and the spicy white tuna is da bomb! i LOve their salmon, it's super fresh! The scallop and hamachi is great! i LOve the Tai. Their fish is just so fresh!
author: edwin q.
